Outside is enough. I saw the building from the outside only and was very impressed, it looks much older than roughly 100 years. I passed the building both in the daylight and at night and it is equally awe inspiring at both times, maybe even more so when it is lit up from ground level.

Interesting building yet hard to visit. The parliament building is one of the most well known spots in Budapest. Too bad it's being renovated most of the times and getting to visit the interiors is almost impossible. I've tried two times - during both my visits to Budapest and failed. Seems that getting in the line to the entrance after 7 in the morning is the only way to get inside.

amazing looking building. wow what an amazing building with so much history....... well worth looking at during a night time river cruise, when its lit up you can see the bats flying high in the sky above... absolutely amazing site.
Unexpected surprise.. Building is beautiful! !! Even though the building is not old its beautiful. It is copy of the UK parliament. Great!
A Must. Make reservations in advance before you leave home or you will not be able to see. Magnificent building with incredible history.

Stunning Inside & Out. Visually stunning from pretty much every angle, the seat of the National Assembly of Hungary is one of Europe's oldest legislative buildings. Take a tour of the interior, if at all possible. Tours are approximately 45 minutes and they are offered in several languages at varying times throughout the day. English, German, French, Russian, Hebrew, Italian, and Spanish languages are offered for tours. You must go through security (like at the airport) before entering the building. (Note, pocket knives are not allowed) A new visitor's center is now open which organizes your paid admission, the tour groups, and security area. Washrooms are also available. EU citizens pay a lower admission fee than non-EU citizens. Try to book in advance as certain languages have very limited options. There are many steps on this tour, but a lift service is offered. Our tour took us through to the Assembly Hall of the House of Representatives and to take a look at the Holy Crown of Hungary (Crown Jewels) in the Central Hall. Amazing ornamental staircases, lush carpets, interesting historical and contemporary commentary with the tour. Non-flash photographs were allowed inside except for the area where the Crown Jewels are displayed - no photography allowed.
Renovated , like new. The place ,wich daytime you can wisited for some cash, and in the night is , woahhhh,My wife was really impressed!
Half an hour tour. Building is beautiful, but 20$ for not even half an hour tour? I think it's a bit too much. It's definitely a beatifull place to visit, hear a bit of history.
Beautiful building. The building is beautiful inside and outside, but the crown jewels are nothing special. The tour is about 45 minutes. The have it in about 5-6 different languages.

National Day 20th August. Parliament from outside is absolutely stunning especially lit up at night as seen from the Danube. We also had an escorted tour inside which is so interesting. You get to see the crown which is the basis of Hungarian history.

Visual treat. Even though I didn't go in (except for the tourism office attached to the complex) my walk around the exterior did not disappoint. It's a beautiful, complex building overlooking the Danube. Politicians should be thinking good thoughts and acting wisely for the benefit of their citizens working in a building like this.

Excellent place to visit and well worth the tour. Be warned take you ID with you as it is 4000 ft if you don't but only 2000 ft with an EU identification for Adults.Tour was good and informative and the building amazing to visit.

Must See in Budapest!. I had the privilege of touring this breathtaking structure with some Hungarian friends. However, even if you do not have the opportunity for an inside tour, a stroll around the outside is well worth your time. Night views are perhaps even more spectacular.
Amazing. Beautiful inside and out, amazing statues. Pictures can not be taken in certain areas, but the tour guide was very knowledgeable.
a must see. we didnt go right over as we didnt have time, but we had lunch in a boat in front of the building! it was a great view! a must see next time we head to budapest :)

Iconic building identifying Budapest. Stunning architecture abounds in this city and this is one of the most photographed and easily identifies this glorious city . We walked around outside and inside and marvelled , a must to visit

Beautiful Place!. We were thoroughly impressed with the Parliament building. Its quite a sight to see. We did not do the tour but I am glad that we went and walked around the exterior. We were stunned at the size and beautiful architecture of the building. The river in the background from the square makes it a wonderful setting and a great place to take photos. There are a lot of impressive buildings around the square. The guards outside must have the most difficult job in dealing with the tourist and picture taking of them. It was amusing at times and I give them credit for their composure. I am glad we went and would recommend a visit.

Worthwhile. Of course you must see the buildings lit up at night. Tours leave every 15 minutes in various languages, so check ahead the day before to buy your tickets online. Popular times may be sold out, as group size is limited. Be ware that the tour guide does not use a microphone of any time, so arrive early if you want to hear everything she says. Photography is allowed in most areas and many of the small sculptures up on pillars are worth shooting. The decoration and artwork throughout is outstanding.

Exquisite building. Had a tour privately booked and it was worth it. I thought it was unique that the actual front doors are on the Danube side. Once inside the toothpick recreation of the parliament building was something I never expected to see and it was cool that someone took the time to recreate the building utilizing toothpicks. The interior of the building is grande...the lighting, the high ceilings, stained glass, etc just everything is beautiful. Good to see the Hungarian crown Jewels which are housed under the dome-and NO pictures are allowed in the room/of the jewels. Obviously guarded and was able to see the changing of the guards guarding the jewels. The assembly hall of the house of maneates was also pretty cool to see-its where Parliament conducts their business- beautiful fresco in the background and the cigar holder outside the hall was neat to see. Did not feel rushed at all, but thought we would see more of the building. Still enjoyed it nonetheless.

Pricey but so beautiful. We stayed on the Buda side with a fabulous view of Parliament so we had to take the tour. We booked the tickets on line so we would have a reservation for an English speaking guide. We walked right in, no line. We were in a group of only 20 people with a very good guide. If you want to see Crown Jewels, go to London, but the inside is amazing. Just beautiful. The guide provided a tremendous amount of information and could answer any question. Although pricey, I don't regret paying for the tour. The rotunda is so beautiful but the view across the river with the bats, not birds, flying around is an absolute must.
eurotrip. This is a magnificent and well built structure which looks fabulous. try getting a view of the same from the castle district for some fab snaps.

Magnificent !!. A magnificent building, impressive beyond description, dominates on the Pest side of Danube, day and night. One of the most distinctive buildings in a city full of architectural gems. Its view from the hills of Buda breathtaking.

Stunning exterior. This building was modeled on Westminster Palace - it isn't as good but still looks lovely. It's a large parliament building and iconic on the banks of the Danube. Inside is a different matter. They just haven't got the gist of volume crowds at an attraction with one person taking payment and printing tickets. Once inside it is ornate in places with an interesting history. It might be worth the painful process to get in if you don't mind being hurried and herded like sheep once you are there. They seem to want to rush you through and out as quickly as possible in 35-40 mins. To be honest I would give the inside a miss and admire the external facade and get photos there.

Worth visit. Great building, great gardens & also "special effects" on street... if you are there at the right time!Worth doing the inside tour, well trained people telling you the most important facts of the building. You can only this way see the crown with the twisted cross. You have to buy tickets in a building in front of the Parliament, you may also leave your back-pack there in some free lockers, cause you cannot go to the mail building with them. Have to see it.

Poorly Run Tours. We arrived at the Parliament Building at around 10:00 am to see whether we could get in on one of the tours. The lineup appeared to be relatively small. It led into the Museum of Ethnography and only went out as far as the tram tracks - it looked to be around 30 or 40 people in front of us? We stood in line for at least 1.5 or 2 hours. It took a ridiculously long time to get into the building and to the ticket booth. There was one ticket booth with one person handing printing the tickets - it took her 5 to 10 minutes per person when all was said and done. It was incredibly slow!On a side note, we visited in May of 2014 and they were currently building a new underground visitors centre which might be open now. Hopefully it will have alleviated some of these issues.The tour was very interesting but felt highly rushed. We were told that, because parliament was in session, only half of the normal tour grounds would be open for viewing (the tickets were half price). We were comfortable with that, but unfortunately the areas which were off limits were the most popular and 'magnificent' areas... or so we were told.All in all, the Hungarian Parliament is a mixed bag. On the one hand, it was the most painful part of our time in Hungary. But on the other hand, it's one of those "need to see" attractions while you are in Budapest. I would recommend going, but hopefully you are more prepared for some of these problems than we were.

Stunning. The Orszaghaz is an inspiring work of architecture - as grand as Westminster, but much less dour. I really like this part of Budapest. There is something incredible wherever you look. Consider going on a Sunday if you aren't keen on enduring the long queues to tour inside - it's lovely to walk around when it's relatively uncrowded.

Impressive building. This is one of the largest government buildings in the world. It is very impressive from the outside, even more so once inside. The interior is, in some respects, like a museum, rather than a working government building. The actual room where the parliament members sit is as ornate as many European cathedrals. Note that in the corridor outside the main hall are numbered places for the members to put their cigars!

A must, especially for Hungarians. The building is majestic and beautiful. The guides are excellent, the cost is half of what you pay for the entrance fee to one of the bath complexes. Our guide was witty and well informed, she'd been working there for more than 18 years. She had plenty of historic info and fun stuff to share.If anything, it should be mandatory for Hungarians to take a tour, it would make them feel more proud of their nationality and inheritance.On busy days, book your ticket online in advance, there's a limit to the number of people per group.http://www.jegymester.hu/eng/Production/480000/Parlamenti-latogatas
Worth a vist for everyone!. Very beautiful parliament that everyone should see. A place you must go to if you have a couple of days in Budapest

Absolutely over the top at Night. This huge structure is one of the highlights of a visit to Budapest. The enormity of the structure, the Neo Gothic facade and the history all come together. If you have the change, visit at night. The illumination of this wonderful building complex is breath taking.

Parliament or Mini Castle??. Really a mini castle, rather than a typical Parliament. The art, the design and the grand staircase are something to be seen. You need to book a tour, and the guides, although bored are still very informative. Make sure after your tour you walk along the Danube to see the Shoe Exhibit too.

Don't be disappointed if you miss it. Now that the construction work is finished around it, the Parliament has recovered its outside beauty, this is free and makes great photos, especially if there is no wind and you can use the reflection pool. The best view being actually from the Fishermen's Bastion on the Var.For the inside part, that is another story. It used to be 3500 HUF, suddenly in one week the price jumped to 4000 HUF (almost $20) - honestly not worth the treatment you get. For that huge price you expect a group of 20 maximum with proper guidance in your language since they have designated times for different languages and enough time to take some photos.What we got was a group of 50 herded like cattle, the end of the cattle could not hear a word of the guide yet was being pushed by guards to go faster, faster, faster ... When you are 50, it is hard to all take the same photo, you need to wait - not allowed, move it! No photos of the crown jewels either (get a photo of the copy which lies in Matyas Templom on the Var!).The guided tour is about 40 to 45 minutes, no more - the rest is queuing and passing metal detector machines.As a group you expect a group price - not here. If you wish a private tour it is 10,000 HUF ON TOP of the individual ticket.If you wish to secure your time (and avoid the queue or worse queuing for nothing) you may go on line but you will be charged extra.Bottom line: beautiful but not worth the hassle - perhaps in bleak cold months when there are fewer tourists the experience is more enjoyable.

Terrific!!. This was one of my favorite sites when I visted Budapest. I had a river view room from my hotel over looking this amazing structure, at night it just looks like a ferry tale castle. Go and take the guided tour. it is well presented and fun and gives you a unique view of the inside of this great monument.

Bewautiful building, enchanting history.. The building is spectacular. The tour was so-so. A lot of the building is off limits. And the organization for handling people was a mess. That said, I would still recommend that one go there. Make sure you notice the cigar holders in the halls.

Wow A great building!. The parliament can be reached by metro red line ( M2 ) at Kossuth Lajos ter or Tram line 2 which runs along the Danube on the Pest side. You can enjoy watching the change of guards and take a pleasant walk along the Danube to see the ' shoes on the Danube ' nearby.
amazing place. An amazing place, especially the view from the Fisherman's Bastion. At night from Gellert mountain looks magic

Awesome!!. This has to be one of the most amazing parliament buildings I have ever seen, with the exception of our in the UK of course. The architect first tried to sell the design to Berlin, but they rejected it and now it sits as an impressive icon of Budapest. It's castle like structure fits in so well with the presentation of the city, and having been to Berlin I could not imagine this anywhere other than Budapest. The building is worth a visit during the day, when you can get up close and look at the ornate architecture. But, it comes into its own at night when fully illuminated. My advice, find a restaurant on the other side of the river, and wait for sun to set to see the awesome lighting up of the parliament, and if you look carefully you will see birds flying around the roof, illuminated by the lights and looking like little fire flies.
See House of Lords. A majestic building, beautifully designed. The House of Lords is rather too luxurious. The guided tour was well presented and fun.

Beautiful!. Did not get to go inside, but the outside is so beautiful! Right next to "the Shoes" Holocaust memorial, and is such a great sight along the river. I enjoyed the Parliament building more than the actual Palace!

Must go there at night!. Do you want a magic feeling? Go to Parliament at night, really breathtaking when you see it all lightened. Also there are nice views on Danube river and bridges. Have a look at Fishermen Bastion - it looks like a princess castle from the fairly tail, my daughter was totally amazed.

Best seen at night. This site is best viewed from the Danube at night-- the lights truly let the building "glow". In daylight not quite as magnificent but very accessible and offers excellent views of the river and across to Buda.

Spectacular. This is truly an amazing building. It looks great in the morning and evening and gorgeous at night.I saw this first in the afternoon since the Number 2 Tram stops on two points close to the building. In the evening glow from the sun it was truly photogenic. And at night it is well lit and can be seem from the river or walking around the building.From the distance at night there seemed to be some artificial flying objects over the building> I came closer look one at midnight and it was hundreds of birds circling on top of the building, lit up from the lights shining from below. Truly amazing. There were a few people around the building but no rough looking characters. One can come with a tripod and camera after 10- 11 PM and shoot wonderful slow shutter shots without having any people in the photos,The tour was very good. We had no problem booking an English tour an hour after we were in the queue. The lines were not too long in July, unlike what other had experienced. The toilets were clean and free. Only thing missing was a water fountain since the day was hot. Unlike USA, drinking water fountains are almost non existent in Europe. What a shame. The tour lasts 40 minutes and is $20 USD for non EU citizens and half of it for EU citizens and children and students.There was some restoration going on but the exterior was good for the most part.I find that something is wrong when neither this nor the Castle district is on the top of the attractions list, and top spots are occupied by Shooting club, TRAP team and Claustrophobia. I have not traveled 4000+ miles to one of the grandest cities in Europe to do such things that I could very well do at home. That is not what Budapest is famous for.
See it from the Buda side. We didn't tour the Parliament but did love seeing the building at night from the Buda side. Very beautiful.
wondeful. Very beautiful building, it's worth it to see both the Castle Hill and from up close. Most impressive in the evening when it is beautifully illuminated.

A stunning building. The Parliament building is almost like a fairy tale castle. It stands by the banks of the Danube an is allegedly based on Westminster. Some element of the UK parliament design can be seen but Hungary's parliament building is a far more glorious edifice. There is a pecular water feature to one side of the building. On a paved area a mist/cloud was generated which attracted folk to walk through it. By the tiome I made my mind up to explore it more closely the effect was turned off. I'll have to revisit it in the future to see it again. It is open to the public by appointment but I didn't pursue the option to go inside.

Beautiful and impressive exterior. Definitely one of the landmarks of Budapest. Strongly recommend making your way there to see the building. The tour of the interior was a little disappointing -- it costs 4000 Forints per person, and it is over in half an hour. You see a couple impressive parts of the building, but we were left with the feeling "is that all there is?" Still, depending on your interests, you may find it worthwhile. If you go, I suggest booking the tour online -- we didn't, and we found the lineup long, and we were only able to book tickets for several hours later.
Perfect!!!. Gorgeous! Beautiful!!! Must see!!! One of the best places in Budapest. You can see it by foot or with a boat on Danube which I highly recommend!

Spectacular building especially at night. This very impressive building sits at the edge of the river and from the water you get a very commanding view. It is the seat of Hungarian Parliment, it is Europe's oldest legislative building and the largest building in Hungary. We were fortunate enough to see the building from the river by night which makes for an amazing view and one not to be missed.

Stunning building and a great tour.. This very popular tour of this amazing iconic building is well worth making the effort for. It's just as grand inside as out. You can only buy tickets on the day of the visit. We were able to book online and print out tickets at our hotel which helped.

Impressive arquitecture. This is an impressive building. Very pretty. I recommend taking a photo from the other side of the river, because its the only you can get a full photo of it. And if you wait for a while you will include some boats also on the photo. Dont forget to take a picture from the back if the Hungarian parliament, because there are some flowers behind the building that help composing a great photo.
Awesome building *-*. Most beautiful building in Hungary! *-* Most beautiful building in Hungary! *-* Most beautiful building in Hungary! *-*

Very interesting, and a beautiful building. This a very beautiful building. The best view is from the river. In the rotunda they change the guards every hour. They are guarding the Crown Jewels in the rotunda. Well worth a visit. Best to go with a guide so you can get an early appointment.

Very interesting, and a beautiful building. This a very beautiful building. The best view is from the river. In the rotunda they change the guards every hour. They are guarding the Crown Jewels in the rotunda. Well worth a visit. Best to go with a guide so you can get an early appointment.

Amazing!!!!!!. Amazingly restored. The square around is very beautiful. I like the fact that cars are not anymore allowed to pass through the square.cthe change of the guards is interesting. Overall excellent!

Spectacular. We didn't have a chance to go for the tour inside, but we were glad to have taken a Segway tour that passed by it. The building is huge and beautiful. Awesome up close and awesome view from Castle Hill as well.
The most beautiful parliament on the earth.. The Hungarian parliament is the most beautiful building on the earth. Very unique architecture standing tall on the river side.

Unimpressive Tour. The architecture of this neo- Gothic building is impressive, we enjoyed it immensely, we walked around took some great photos. It is beautiful inside as well however the tour leaves you feeling unimpressed, first you can't even hear the guide as there are so many people following this one person around, when she points out something you can not see over all the people to even know what she is talking about IF you can hear her, the less than enthused guide & tour left us unimpressed. A few members of our party got bored just standing in one spot forever and started laughing about something, the guards came up behind and angrily said IT IS NOT FUNNY. Also we had one member that had a hard time going up ALL the stairs, she was struggling, we were not offered use of an elevator, not certain if they even have one. Our tour guide was not allowed to show us around inside which would have been nice so we had to do the group / MASS tour.
The most beautiful building in Budapest. The building dominates the area and it's beautiful from wherever it is seen - especially from the walls of Buda
Impressive architecture.. Quite an imposing building, the detail is fantastic. This is on the subway stop for the shoes on the Danube attraction.

Amazing exterior. Saw the parliament during the daytime and at nightime and it takes your breath away. The tour inside is lovely, but the guide goes on and on with too much information. They should offer two types of tours. One for people who want a general sighting and overview and a different detailed one for those who care about tons of facts!

Visit Budapest for Orszaghaz. I spent two days in Budapest and visited the Castle Hill and Orszaghaz, the Hungarian Parliament. Even if I had been here only for an hour and had visited the Parliament, my visit would have been worth the value. Look at it from any angle, it is magnificent in every respect. The best part is that they allow visitors inside the building. This tour though costs HUF 4000, yet it is value for money. If it is magnificent from the outside, it is simply lavish from the inside. The Grand Staircase, the splendid lobby, the elegant House of Magnets, the beautiful sculptures, the appealing frescoes - these are all just fantastic. A must visit while in Budapest or may I say Budapest can be visited to have a glimpse of this imposing building by the side of River Danube.

Magnificent building!. Didn't have time to go inside, but just viewing the building from the outside is an experience. Our tram went right by it, so we saw it during various times of the day, and were lucky enough to pass during the changing of the guard! Also saw it from my boat tour. Really one of the highlights of the city! And at certain times of the day there are mists that go off outside. Very beautiful!

a building you cannot stop photographing. The outside of this building is wonderful, one of the most inspiring buildings in Europe. It is worth walking all around the building to enjoy its fairy like architecture. New walkways and statues make this very enjoyable.
Inside is most interesting, with similar features to Westminster and very beautiful

Wished it were longer. Short tour lasts about 50 minutes tops which includes going through security. You see four rooms. You can only take pictures in three. Great place for history and architecture buffs.

Outstanding architecture but passable tour. The behemoth and intricate design of the parliament is a sight to behold . However it is not worth shelling out 4000 forints for a short 40 mins tour in the parliament . You are given limited access to the building for a rather hefty price tag . The exterior is more awe aspiring and do go in the night , with the flooded lights , the parliament looks stunning .

Reminds me of London Parliament. The building is beautiful whether looked at close up or from far away during a river promenade. We couldn't go in because the parliament was in session, but still it was great to see. Close by the parliament is the shoes on the river memorial.

The Blue Danube. I took the Danube River Cruise from Vilshofen Germany to Budapest Hungary with friends on the AMA waterways ship, I have never seen such beauty and foliage as we seen along the way ! BUT, Budapest was the best surprise of the trip, the market place, the architecture , Horror museum, the Seven Horseman Park. We had a wonderful walking trip around Buda & Pest, The American Embassy was a pleasant surprise with the statue of Ronald Reagan in the City Center. I hope to go back one day and take in many things I had no time to enjoy.

Well worth a guided tour.. You can only visit here with a guided tour. The entrance is located underground to the left of the building as you look at it. Fantastic interior and interesting and amusing tour from our guide. Lots of opportunities to take photographs. Only one room where you cannot take any photos.
Nice looking buildings. The Parliament buildings are a great design. Situated on the banks of the Danube, the setting is amazing. A must see in Budapest.

Beautiful sight!. A beautiful sight, especially at night. I love the architecture and how big it is. Its near the subway and tram line. So if you are nearby, i really recommend that you take a small stop there.
Architecture is great. Walked around the building and took lots of pictures. We were here around 5-6 pm when they took the flag down. Pretty pictures and grounds to check out.

Very interesting!. The tour of the Parliament was not to be missed, but with more than one tour going on at the same time in different languages, it wasn't always easy understanding what our guide was saying. Also, at the beginning they 'mentioned' that anyone interested in taking the elevator should do so. Since the announcement wasn't all that emphatic, we decided to start climbing ... and climbing ... and climbing. I think I counted 127 stairs, and most folks were breathing hard by the time we got to the top. The building itself was the attraction to us - the tour and guide, not so much.
beautiful and monumental. Unforgettable experience of this wonderful architectural structure. I was strucked the neighborhood of history and modern technology.

What an amazing building. Not only is this a stunning building on the outside, but the inside is even more beautiful and interesting. We took a guided tour and learned much about the history of the building and the rooms we were guided through. A must see!

Danube must be happy.... Having such beautiful attractions along the Danube must the river itself feel really happy especially when the dawn comes and lights are turned on at the Parliament and the Castle Hill. I like how governments use, even small portions, of such buildings which is a way of paying some respect to all these people that were involved in creating this beautiful structure! I suggest you wait on the other side of the river until sunset and you will not regret it!

Magnificent architecture. I must say, I fell in love when I first saw the Parliament. It's so huge and beautiful and majestic. Not to mention it has the best spot to enjoy the Danube, but it also looks good from the other side of the river. Definitely the true gem of Budapest. Too bad didn't have time to go inside, but looking at the exterior is already spectacular.

Themost beautiful parliament I have ever seen. The delicate exterior architecture of this extremely largebuilding and the superbly crafted interior makes this a musts see site. Don't miss the view of the lighted up exterior at night.

Favorite Governmental Building in the World. I will admit, I am kind of obsessed with this building. It is breathtaking, especially at night. By far one of the most ornate seats of government (I was told they could build a whole town for 40,000 people with what it cost to build it), but it is simply spectacular to look at.

Beautiful building!!. This building is incredibly beautiful, and really symbolizes Budapest to me. You can see it from the Danube, from Buda...It is beautiful by day, and glows at night! It is lovely from all angles, but as a previous reviewer mentioned, really spectacular from a Danube river boat.We did not go inside the building on this trip, but I have been inside it in the past, and the interior is incredible also! Unbelievably beautiful architecture!

Fab on the night cruise of the Danube. I loved the View from the river Danube on the night cruise. Breath taking. Be sure if you visit Budapest to visit the Pariament houses and the Palace and do a night cruise. You can do a one hour trip which covers the main sights. It is a must

Pacemakers allowed.. This is a stunning building from the outside, set just off the river front with a large plaza out front it oozes class, riches and importance. The only permitted way to see the inside is with a guided tour (sorry can't remember the languages except for English) and I recommend booking in advance in some shape or form - we went early in the day, booked and paid ventured over the Danube for the afternoon and went back to our enjoyable and educative tour later on. The prices was very reasonable for a student (with student ID); only a couple of pounds if I remember correctly. I'm normally one to avoid a guided tour if possible but in this case it certainly added to the experience. Don't attempt to take in any knifes, guns or tools through the airport like security but you'll be glad to know Pacemakers are allowed.

Fabulous. Well worth a visit, simply stunning at any time of the day, take the inside tour if your a history buff, but the most spectacular views can be got at night from one of the many Danube boat tours.

Huge outside but the trip very short. The hungarian Parliament is one of the biggest in Europe and one of the most beautiful. Situated in a beautiful area just at the banks of Duna. It looks tremendous from the outside and that's why we decided to take a tour inside. At about 1 pm we went to buy tickets. The first english tour that wasn't fully booked was at 5 pm so don't think that you would just enter and go to a tour. There are also tours in other languages (spanish, german, hungarian and russian- all that I remember). Tickets are cheap if you're an EU student (1000 forints - 3-4 euros) and more expensive for non EU citizens (4000 forints). Tour held for 30-40 minutes and we saw only few corridors, one of the chambers, a dome, a hall with the crown and staircases. Maybe it's not a big tour with lots of things to see but I think it's worth it's prize. Guide gives you lot of information about the history of Hungary.
Great architecture. Extremely beautiful building. Best seen by taking a river cruise along the Danube or viewing it from the Buda Castle or Fisherman's Bastion.

Impressive. This building, enormously built and based on the parliament in London is very impressive and was built so large to symbolize that Democracy is at least as powerful as royal reigning. We did not go inside, I believe there is a fee with a guided tour which didn't seem that interesting to us, but that's personal, the area offers a lot of great views!

Magnificent well kept old Building. If you want to feel that you are back in the last century?!Take a Tour of the Parliament. It is a must with a Guide.You will see the Gold Crown that all the Hungarian Kings wore (under 24hr guard) You'll learn about the Hungarian polltical system past and present

Get inside. Not only the outside but the inside of the Parlament is beautiful and interesting. You can take part in a small group guided tour quite often. It is about an hour and you get detailed informations about the building including technical datas, legends, history and miths. You can see the Holy Crown of the Hungarian kings. It is free of charge for Hungarinas and Eu members so book well ahead if you want to see.

Reserve online. Tickets can be purchased online ahead of time which means that you don't have to join the long queues to buy tickets. Tours are frequently sold out and you may wait in line only to have to return hours later for your tour. You must print your tickets, though, so make sure that you can do that or arrive early to have them printed for you.Our tour started a few minutes late, but the tour guide was pleasant and informative. The building is stunning and she offered some interesting stories to make the tour more interesting. You can take photos everywhere except for the room with the crown jewels. This means that views are frequently obscured by the selfie brigade. Stay at the back of the pack for time to enjoy in peace (the guide allows plenty of time). There is also an interesting exhibit of photos taken during the restoration of the building; they aren't the typical photos, so allow yourself time to look at the artistic shots. There was a changing of the guard just before our tour and it was nice to see-- the guards even allowed people to get close and take photos with them once the ceremony was done. This was a great experience and we were glad to have the opportunity to see inside this gem of a building.

Hands down the most impressive building I've seen. I first saw Parliament while on a night cruise of the Danube. I had been looking towards the Buda side and while my eyes circled back to the Pest side I was in awe. It was lit up which definitely does it justice. It is even more beautiful in the day. A sprawling structure - it is difficult to get a full picture of it without crossing the Danube and taking a picture from the Buda side. We took the tour which lasted about 45 minutes. There is heavy security to get through but once you are in you have access to some beautiful parts of the building: governing body chambers, a lounge, the Crown Jewels and the main staircase. All of these were incredible and well worth the tour.

Not worth the tour. While the building is very beautiful and huge, the guided tour lasted 15 minutes and cost around 2.200HUF (if I remember correclty). They only showed you 3-4 rooms (and the crown) and that's it. I think that it wasn't worth the money or the trouble (you have to walk ~150 stairs to get to the rooms you'll see). Also they change the time of the tour each day and you cannot book ahead from the previous day, which I think is unacceptable.

This is the image of Budapest. Very pretty structures with needle steeples and a rounded dome. It looks East European. You have to reserve a viewing time to see this thing t might be right away or the next day.

second only to the houses of parliament in London. Beautiful building right on the river Danube. You would never believe Budapest had gone through a communist regime. The buildings throughout the city are truly stunning.

A Must See. Who can come to Budapest and not visit this iconic landmark of the city? We couldn't! I believe we saw this building pictured in every brochure and book we read about Budapest. It is a beautiful building with classic architecture and art throughout the building. There is a lovely new ticket center and central area where we waited for our guide (check the time for English tours) and an interesting museum after the tour is over. Be prepared to climb steps (they do offer an elevator for the disabled). They do allow cameras inside and pictures are allowed in all areas except one. this is worth a visit!
Beautiful Building!. Book the tour online in advance. saves you lot's of time.Lots of stairs inside...The view outside is just stunning.

online reservation makes it so much easier. highly recommend reserving a tour online through the parliament building's website. Otherwise, the wait for a tour in your language may take awhile. There is a new visitor entry with toliet facilities and it is easier now to wait ( not too many seats available). The only problem is that once you book your tour, you don't have any idea where to wait or who to ask. as your time approaches, a person suddenly comes out and says something and everyone rushes towards the security screening area. They won't screen you until your group time is called, so this causes a bit of a delay in getting everyone inside. The building is beautiful on the outside and it is also highly recommended to see the inside as well. something special about it. You need to stick close to your guide in order to hear everything. They proceed quite quickly since there are different groups walking around at the same time.

Stunning building. This place is definitely worth a visit! It's not expensive to get into if you're on a budget, it's worth every penny though, the building itself looks brand new, the staff are attentive and will answer any questions
WOW. Gorgeous architecture! Such a big building.... A must see. It's right on the Danube but also has metro going to it

Book a tour in advance. It's a must. This is the biggest parliament in the world with amazing,stunning design, detail. You must do a 45 min tour. It's very worth it. The guide speaks excellent English

Not Much to See. Definitely not worth the 4,000 HUF. Each cattle like tour is about 50 people. The guide could not speak loud enough for everyone t hear. We rushed through the 40 minute tours. Other than the King's Crown, not much to see. You can buy a postcard of the Crown for about 160 HUF.
a tour trough 4 capital in middle Europe. It was the first time i visited Budapest and the Parliament is really more beautiful than i supposed!!!!

Grand Building. You cannot fail to admire the architecture in this building. Like lots of other Parliament buildings it is imposing and grand. For us we took a walk around the city and stopped to admire this seat of power.

Impressive and unmissable!. It is difficult to decide whether this building is more impressive from the outside or the inside. We took a tour with a company because the companies have a good proportion of the tickets and if you are short of time or do not wish to hang about to get a tour in the language of your choice this is the best option. However what we were not aware of is that there are various concessions for EU members and others which are not passed on.

good historical heritage. we were Russian language listeners..only 2 times entrance per day...at 12 afternoon, and 16:00. I was very impressed by the architecture and how they saved it for so many years and during the war...

Spectacular . Very well organised tours. We just showed up thinking we could go in. The only tour we could get was two hours later but it was well worth it! Amazing architecture, interesting history, incredibly clean, and a wonderful tour guide who had lots of stories, facts, and a few jokes to tell along the way. Beautiful setting as well. Plenty of tours go on in English, but if you do have to wait as we did it's extremely pleasant just walking along the river to a nearby Cafe. Wonderful trip, a highlight of the holiday.

Beautiful Structure Inside & Out. We were there just a week in to the new visitor's center opening. Although the tour costs a fair amount of money for just a 45 minute tour, seeing the inner workings of another country's government, especially one with a history of both communism and democracy, was worth it. If you can't do a tour inside, make sure to look down side streets to get special almost alley-way views of Parliament, not to mention views from Castle Hill across the Danube to take in its enormous river-side beauty.

City tour. We visited the parliament building on a city tour. It's an amazing building visible from many parts if the city but perhaps best seen from a boat trip on the Danube. Our guide said it was modelled on the British Houses of Parliament. Make sure you get to see it.

Another masterpiece. We have not being inside the Parliament, but both, City Bus Tour and boat tour take you past it. It is a beautiful building with some unique molding and sculptures. Can’t say enough about the splendor of the building.
Beautiful day and night. Truly impressive building on the bank of the Danube. Walk around it during the day and to see if lit up after dark is a must.

incredible building. Really amazing building.Located directly on the bank of the Danube and it is the first thing that catches your eyes when you come in the city. Unmatched outside and even more amazing beauty inside.

We were incredibly impressed in this building.. I had no idea how ornate it would be on the inside. The tour is definitely worth doing. Check for tour times/languages before you go. If you have to wait for your tour, it is a short walk on the Danube to see the shoe memorial.
Georgeous. This Grand building cannot be missed on the banks of the river, an absolute masterpiece Your visit to Budapest would not be complete without a visit,

Go by this place at night!. I saw parliament on my first day at Budapest. It's quite a marvel - on my last night while we were looking for restaurants we happened to see it from afar and just had to go back there. The place is so beutifully lit after dark that it's almost like a whole other building.

Fantastic . Maybe being British I'm simply desensitised to the Houses of Parliament and I'm doing them a disservice with this, but to me it seemed that the Parliament was a stunning building without real equal from any similar building I've seen. Situated on the Danube, at sunset with the light shining on it and glimmering off the water in front it's an incredible sight, whilst the architecture and squares around it are beautiful. A real must if in Budapest.

A wonderful day. This is really worth going toI thought Parliament - Nah -But I am so glad I wentThe building inside and outside is magnificentWe caught the soldiers changing the flag which was worth watching
Stunning!. One of the most beautiful buildings in the world. It seems it is made out of lace. The view in the evening is breathtaking!

Beautiful area. Unfortunately did not have the time to go in to the building but walked round the outside,the architecture on the outside is awesome and looks a lot more modern than it actually is.The area round the outside has lovely landscaped gardens and plenty of benches so it a great place to sit and people watch.

Fascinating. We don't have time to go inside, but seeing outside is more than worth it, the history really interesting, the decoration, structure completely amazing, over all this is one of the impressive architecture of Budapest
nice!. nice place to visit. it is not very big, but nice. mind that there are lines to buy the ticket. come earlier )

Breathtaking. Photographs do not do justice here - you have to see and walk past this complex to appreciate this beautiful architectural masterpiece. Make another visit after dark to see it lit up with spot lights. Any visit to Budapest would not be complete without seeing up close the Parliament Building. Highly recommended.

Awesome. Did not have time to go inside this building but managed to walk around it. The size and structure of the building is amazing. If you are short of time in this lovely city at least try to find the time to view it.

walking tour. Was on walking tour of Budapest. Stopped at Parliament building. Was not able to go inside. Outside of building is amazing architecture. Very beautiful. At night when building lit up it is spectacular.Then there are the pigeons flying in the light from building which is a beautiful sight. Very impressive.

Wow! Wow and Wow again. I thought this building was amazing on the outside but it is well worth a tour on the inside. The history, the crown jewels, the architecture, the decoration - it's all completely fascinating. The guide was very good. You can't take photos of the jewels but it is amazing being in the cathedral of a room with them and two gorgeously uniformed and armed guards
One of Budapest's Highlights. Easily accessible, beautiful exterior and interior, tour rickets not expensive, commanding view of the entire city, featured on most advertising photos of the city.

Fabulous Parliament. We booked our trip to visit Parliament before leaving the UK. The day we went nearly all the UK language trips were full so booking in advance proved worthwhile.Entrance is now via the new visitors centre..
The inside is absolutely fabulous with gold leaf everywhere. the tour guide made the visit interestingand the tour lasted about 50 mins.

Superb!. As beautiful inside as it is out! Make sure you book in advance (we got there at 8.30 and booked onto the 9.45 tour before going over the road for breakfast). Our tour guide was great and the interior was spectacular. Shame there was no gift shop.
Spectacular shows. he breathtaking view of the river, near the place amazing feeling. Looks impressive and formal, certainly honors the parliamentary sitting in this building.

Great building.... I can never bee tired of visiting this beautiful building. I have a fortune to see the Parlament from a privat boat trip on Donau also visited inside and saw the gorgeous halls and the crown of St Stephan.

STAIRS STAIRS STAIRS. Less fit or elderly people should be aware that the tour involves a LOT of stair-climbing. Three or four of the people in our party were quite distressed, and wouldn't have come they'd known before. The tour's quite expensive and it lasts about 45 minutes. (Plus perhaps 30 minutes standing about waiting to go in.) Among other rooms, passageways, corridors, staircases, etc, you get to see the room where parliament meets and the room where the crown is kept. Very impressive, in a nineteenth-century, faux-mediaeval, creating-a-national-myth sort of way.Is it worth it ? Maybe, but don't feel you've missed much if you don't go.

Excellent tour. a gorgeous building with 696 rooms. Saw not only parliment hall but the Hungarian crown jewels. Tour guide was excellent. A spectacular building not to be missed. Booked tour on line and paid on line about 30 days in advance. English tours are limited so don't exspect to walk in for a tour. One of my 21 day trip highlights

Amazingly beautiful building, interior is ok. The Parliament building is beautiful.You can see it from the Buda side hills (Fisherman's Bastion for example).I would even recommend taking Tram #2 that runs along the Danube to see it from up close.The visit inside takes 30 minutes and in my opinion is nice but nothing more. The building is symmetrical inside so the tour will take you through half of the Parliament.The only interesting thing inside is the Crown Jewel, which is under the central dome, guarded by two soldiers.If you do decide you want to visit the Parliament with the tour - book your visit online through their site to avoid standing in line at the tickets desk.

A bit short for the ticket price. The website says a 45 minute tour, but it was 30 if that. Interesting and beautiful place - a shame they don't either make more of the tour or lower the price. Website is out of date and you can get and print tickets at the visitor center, which is at the opposite end from some construction and near a large monument (I walked all the way around in the hot sun before finding this out!). If you have limited time in Budapest, don't spend it here, but if you have a week (like we did), it's worth your time.

Advice for ticket collection, July 2014. In general I agree with everything Lize H says about the tour, stunning building, annoyingly large groups. My husband said it "was not as bad as Versailles" which, if you've suffered through that experience lately is a fairly condemning comment. Not being EU citizens we paid about $32 USD for a 30 minute tour which wasn't really worth it. I can offer some good advice, though. Although they haven't updated their own website yet, tickets no longer need to be printed across the street at the Ethnographic museum. As of June 1, 2014 they have a new visitor center to the left of the building and down some stairs. You can show your tickets on your mobile phone at the desk right before your tour. And here's some errata: Why does such a tiny country have the second largest Parliament building in Europe? Answer: (according to the Hungarians) Because originally they had a lot of land but everyone (Germany, Russia, Checkslovakia, etc., took their land so now they are a tiny fragment of their former republic. But they still have their big Parliament Building. Interesting fact to know and tell: The U.S. forces, after WWII, took the "Crown Jewels" (which would be the actual crown, scepter etc. of the King of Hungary) and stored them in Fort Knox for safe keeping. Jimmy Carter, as President, after deciding their country was democratic enough, returned the crown to Hungary in the 70's, a gesture still remembered and appreciated by Hungarians. I've attached one photo of the interior, so unless you really need to see those crown jewels, I would call this attraction a "maybe if you have time".

Worth the effort to get inside. My teen son and I visited Parliament in June. I had previously visited 2 years ago but was unable to take a tour of the inside as the online system was only accessible to groups at that time and although we went an hour before opening twice; they were always sold out. This time I used the online system and was able to easily book and print off tickets for our desired date. The grounds of Parliament have undergone quite a renovation in the past 2 years. They are not quite finished but we could see there will be an underground exhibit to the 1956 uprising, a large visitor's centre, new statues, water features and even mist spraying out of the pavement in front of Parliament (a welcome chance to cool off!). It looks really great. For our interior visit we easily found our meeting spot and followed our english speaking tour guide through the guarded gate at our scheduled time. Our group had about 25 - 30 people so was very manageable. The interior is beautifully decorated and our guide gave great explanations and even some humorous little stories. A highlight was seeing the Hungarian crown jewels (the only part of the tour you couldn't take photos). We really enjoyed our tour and wouldn't hesitate to go again.
Awesome building. This building is simply awesome! it looks great from outside, but take the tour inside, really impressive, a must see: should be on your to do list.

Too big groups.. Well, the building is stunning from outside and beautiful from inside. We managed to get a tour in there with a help of our tour guide. As we both are citizens of EU, we only had to pay the half of the entrance fee.The english speaking group was huge. Most of the time we spent walking and waiting for the rest of the group to arrive. The guide was talking loudly, but still, the group was too big, so not everyone could hear her.The tour seemed also too short. It felt like a big conveyer. But fine enough, now we can see that we have been there and seen that. Would still suggest it to others, but don't set your expectations too high.

Magnificent. The building is magnificent. You can view from the museum side, the other bank of the river or on a boat in the river, at day or night. Just gorgeous. The tour is good and recommended. Leave some free time in case your tour start no immediate after your arrival.In summer, the exterior light of the building is on around 9pm.

Decent. Just for context, my wife and I are in our early 30s and are somewhat well-traveled.Big building, nice square, didn't go inside. There's a lot of big, nice buildings in Europe. This didn't stand out really one way or the other.

Center of Government in Hungary. The Parliament buildling dominates the Pest side of the Danube just north of the Chain Bridge. It's a huge and spectacular building. Plan ahead for the tour(book on-line), but it only lasts about 45 minutes. Worth seeing.

Absolutely stunning.. I'd like to start by saying we didn't have time to take a tour inside the Parliament Building. However, from the outside, it is one of the most beautiful buildings I've seen. It especially appeals to my love of symmetry, but the revival Gothic and Renaissance styles are always appealing.Viewed from across the Danube, in Buda, or on the water from a river cruise, this building captivates the senses with its beauty. Probably best viewed at night, when it is lit, it is well worth a stroll over the Chain Bridge after dark, or a romantic sunset dinner cruise when the light is warm, in order to appreciate this building to the fullest.Although we didn't tour inside, I believe it's free to enter if you are an EU resident and you bring your Passport/National ID Card, but there is a charge for those outside the EU. The building is quite large and perfectly symmetrical, so I would imagine a tour would take a couple of hours, unless you chose to quit halfway 'round! ;-)I've attached my night shot of this stunning building with the hope that it might convey the drama and romance of this beautiful building. I hope you enjoy it and beautiful Budapest!

Beautiful landmark. This largest, tallest building in Budapest is a must see for any tourist and local. Appreciate the Gothic style from the outside, at a distance for the best effect. My boyfriend would wait until 'golden hour' to take the most gorgeous pictures of Parliament facing the River Danube.There was some construction outside that we had to photoshop out of the pictures. I understand that the construction is ongoing due to the handiwork. I didn't want to pay the admission price, which was higher for non-EU citizens.
the great architecture. it is one of the most magnificent buildings i've ever seen. Better to see it from a river side on the boat trip. Fantastic view!

Okay to Miss This One. . .But it is Beautiful. I was all hyped up to go and see the Parliament Building. There is a slightly buggy website you can access to get your tickets, but our hotel front desk did it for us the day before (Mondays are tough to get in because the legislature "has meetings"). We went there on the first day of their new Tourist Herding System, in other words, the new visitor center. It will be very nice once they get the bugs out, but this day not even the bathrooms were working.Because we are not EU members, we paid about $20 each for this tour. We arrived at the time on our tickets, 1:00 p.m. They had to herd us all through security (they were doing two tours--one in English and one in ?? at the same time, so stand close to the tour guide so you can hear). By the time we got through security, it was 1:10 p.m. Our guide was fabulous, speaking an English we could all understand. On the tour we saw a hallway, the main legislative chamber, a receiving room, the crown jewels chamber (no photos in this one, but OK in the other ones), and then stood at the top of the Grand Staircase. Then it was over (it was 1:35-ish). The rooms are ornate, beautiful and the guide's talk was interesting, but twenty bucks for 25 minutes? Really? Later that day we went to the Opera House, and although we only stood in the lobby, I think I would rather have gone there. Furthermore, a friend's cousin, a local who lives there in Budapest, didn't put it the top ten list when they visited last year. Maybe it's only for tourists? That night we took the subway to the first stop across the river and joined the few people there taking photos of the building. It is gorgeous, but I wish I'd spent my hours going to the baths or something else. (Still can't get over that it was about a dollar a minute.) In addition, if you want to pay attention and listen to the guide, you won't have time for photographs, as a very severe looking guard shoos you on into the next room. Listen to your guide, but snap away.
Fantastic!. worth the wait to stand in line. Be sure to check when Parlament is in session, as it may be closed to visitors and you'll miss a magnificent building - inside and out, full of history.

Great experience. I spend in Budapest only 2 days and I wanted to see as much as possible. tickets not that expensive, and in my personal opinion the tour was pretty good. Before you go, check the availability online, and also times of the tours (English, German, Russian, ...etc) I wish it would be a little longer and I could see a little bit more. Time - 45 min.

Buy your tickets in person the day before or early morning to avoid disappointment. In the summer there are five English language tours during the day. These fill up very quickly and it is recommended that you buy your tickets early. We arrived at 11:30 am to take the noon tour, only to be told the next one with space was at 3:00pm the last tour of the day. So I would suggest you get your tickets as soon as possible to avoid disappointment. Go buy your tickets, then walk to Margaret island, stroll the streets, go to St. Stephen's Basilica, have lunch...kill some time before returning for the tour.The tour of the interior takes about 45 minutes. The building is very ornate, the dome is huge, the crown of St. Stephen's is rather disappointing, but over all I enjoyed the tour. However, It does cost nearly $20 per person (4000HUF) so it isn't cheap.

Fabulous building!. This was my first visit to any parliament buildings and I really liked it. We took a tour conducted by the building office and it was fabulous. She was just perfect!!We also saw the building during our night boat cruise and you really cannot explain the beauty. I will recommend the trip to this building.

Stunning. It's a can't miss site. Make sure you see it from across the river and then get up close to appreciate the history of the square and if you are lucky catch the changing of the guards. Bring a tour book or read up on the history before you get there, it will make the experience that much better.

Wow!. We sailed past this magnificent building on a boat cruise. It is spectacular. It is even more breathtaking at night when it is all lit up. If you can you should do a night boat ride so you can see all the illuminated buildings along the river in Budapest. It was one of the most memorable parts of our cruise.

Kidding? Right??. Ahhh....maybe its me - but what is the fuss? I mean its nice but this is so trumped up there is something wrong here or Budapest doesn't have a lot to offer. Really nice city, great transportation system. Baths, castle, river tour - all cool and well worth it - but the parliamentt tour and the crush to get in felt like a marketing plan executed well to gin up tourist dollars....Also - first day they wanted a passport to get in then second we showed up with passports and they didn't. Huh? Old commies lurking around?

amazing building - disgraceful tour guide!. absolutely stunning building- really a must see in Budapest. really beautiful inside! unfortunately you must see the inside with a tour run by the building..... it was the WORST tour guide i have ever had! (luck of the draw i guess... it was on July 3rd in english at approx 10am). firstly, the group was much too large (around 40+ ppl). the guide lead the pack, and once at her stopping point, rattled off whatever she had to say in a monotone disinterested voice, and then kept walking!! the back of the group had not even reached the stoping point- and certainly had no idea of what she said! it was terrible! my friends were so disappointed. i went and addressed the issue about halfway through the tour - the guide just nodded at me, and walked off. having done many tours in many countries- she was one of the worst ive experienced.

By day and night it will delight. Had done some homework and seen from other reviews that there were mixed thoughts about the tour. As such, we spent our time wandering around the building(s) themselves, both by day, night, and from the river itself. You will be impressed by the iconic beauty of the Parliament. For us, it was about sitting, looking, watching, and photographing at different times of day and night. They were experiences that we loved , and that you too should experience.

Amazing! A jewel. The Budapest Parliament is an architectural delight. It is in pristine condition and a tour to the building is a must see if you visit Budapest. You can only enter with a guided tour, but they are very easy to book online and the price is worth it.The exterior is breath taking and the interior is a tasteful and colourful display of decoration and architectural techniques. Corridors, meeting rooms and the chambers are richly decorated. You can also get to see the original Hungarian crown which is being guarded at all times by two soldiers.

Grand theatre of Architecture.. Budapest, from wherever one stands on the side of Buda in the west, is dominated by the Danube, the Chain Bridge and this monumental work of architectural art. But what do I know ? This design is based on the British Houses of Parliament which dominate the skyline in London, and state Parliament house here does the same. One can tour the building (guided) and see the original St. Stephen (Istvan)'s jewels and crown in an oval office in its interior. A top 5 attraction.

"Impressive Landmark". We saw the Paliament building from all angles.This building is almost visible from anywhere along the river in Budapest ,but the best view is from the Buda side.Don't miss this Impressive building at night.We did not do a tour of the Parlement Building.

Nice architecture - tour less than impressive. We took a tour of the parliament. The reservation process is quite easy and the english tours fill quickly. Built in 1896 as part of the celebrations and modeled after Westminister palace it is a must seeThe Hungarian Parliament is one the main attractions of the city but the tour was a disappointment. I have visited other parliaments in other cities - and the group size, time allowed to spend and the number of rooms shown is disappointing. The english tour groups are always full and has a lot of people and they just herd people through rooms in short time not allowing to absorb the magnificence, grandeur and the architecture of the place. They should really consider having more english tours and lower the number of the people in the group

Absolute must. Having seen all of the more renowned landmarks in Budapest, I must say the visit to the Parliament was one of the best. The guide was very informatie providing both historical facts and anecdotes about the building and the interiors were definitely worth a see. The whole tour takes around 45 minutes which is perfect cause it's neither rushed nor unnecessarily prolonged.Be sure to book the tickets online 24 hours before your arrival if you wish avoid the queues (from what I saw they don't tend to be too long but it's always better to waltz straight in than wait, right?).
Stunningly beautiful site. Walked along the river and past the Parliament building. Its one of the iconic sights of Budapest and well worth a visit

Expensive, but beautiful. Do not make the mistake I did and plan your day with a certain times for your tour. I had the tour times and arrived for the noon English tour, well that was sold out already. The next available tour was at 145. I think If demand has it they will add more tours, but get there early. The price was approx $20 AUD. But you only see about four rooms, so in that regard it is quite expensive. St Stephens crown is in the dome, but photos there are not allowed!

Beautiful inside. We visited the parliament building and took the tour, but because of all the construction we were herded into a waiting area and you weren't really sure when your group was leaving and you weren't leaving before your scheduled time. Each nationality had their own time slots, we took the English tour and it was excellent and the guides spoke very good English. The tour was excellent, the halls and rooms magnificent, and you were always accompanied by guards. I would highly recommend this tour as you go right into the chambers where the members sit, quite a sight if you have never been in your own countries parliament. There are miles of hallways and beautiful staircases.

Spectacular, over-the-top architecture somehat diminished by a poor tour.. My wife & I took an English guided tour of the Parliament Building on Sunday 5/11. In summary, we loved what we saw - not only the over-the-top external Gothic gingerbread, but also the exceedingly ornate interiors, rooms, & appointments. This is a signature, must-see part of Budapest that we photographed by day & night from two different river boats, from Castle Hill in Buda, & during our tour. The imagination & workmanship are amazing!Having said that, our enjoyment was somewhat diminished by the clumsy, time-consuming tour arrangements & the relatively perfunctory, brief tour of the interior. We had to first meet at a bus near a lot of hotels, wait on the bus, drive slowly thru clogged streets to the Parliament, then wait for 30+ minutes outside before our group could enter the building - all taking well over an hour before the interior tour began. Then our tour guide was brusque, impatient, & often inaudible to many of the tour participants. And he practically ran thru the tour in less than 30 minutes. Rude! Nevertheless, what we saw was fascinating with extravagant details wherever we looked. By the way, the "crown jewels" were interesting but anti-climactic: rather limited & crude that paled in comparison to London & Copenhagen.I don't know whether you can tour the building on your own, but if you can, I suggest doing that.

to many stairs. no information is given about the many stairs you have to climb, you have to have a great physical condition !not a free entrance for EU-citizens (as mentionned in capitol guide).Only guided tours available, the English tours are always fully booked.

The Scots could learn a lesson from this. This is a very recently built edifice but its classical Gothic styling makes for a harmonious relationship within the area in which it sits. Its facade makes quite a statement from all viewpoints both close up and from across the river. It makes the Scottish parliament look frankly crude. It is surrounded by memorials to major events including the Soviet invasion of the 1950's.
OK. Like a XIX century castle. Best place I visited in Budapest. Many statues from Hungarian history. A great place of art.

Unique candy sugar building. Now the building has been cleaned, it overlooks the Danube in all it's white splendor. You should see it close by looking at the details, but also from the opposite site of the Danube it's impressive. Not to be missed.
Beautiful. A really amazing building especially the views from the river Danube. We took a lovely trip down the Danube and found the views to be the best.

A wonderful experience. One of the most wonderful Parliament in Europe! The ticket is not expensive at all and the visit is to be done! Super wonderful outside, very nice inside! It perfectly represent the majesty of the hungarian people.
Budapest Jewel. We enjoyed seeing the beautiful Parliament building in Budapest. It is the crown jewel of the city's sites. Very lovely to see it across the Danube River.
beautiful. lovely to see at night in a boat on the Danube river, it's not expensive and it was a beautiful experience
Very Grand!!!. The parliament building is simply stunning, the whole area round about is just beautiful and very grand indeed!!!

Bummer... get your ticket early. WE got there at 9am and every ticket was sold out for the day. If you desire the tour, arrive when the ticket window opens. The out side of the Parliament is gorgeous. Very similar to London. There are many important statues on the property. The Jewish shoes exhibit is on the Danube side. There are many things to see.... if you don't get the ticket, sigh

Beautiful building with an excellent tour. The Parliament building was surrounded by construction work when we visited in January, but this is to be expected when you travel during the winter. Nevertheless, it was absolutely beautiful and it was clear where tour ticketholders should go. Guided tours are excellent value and the interior of the building is absolutely beautiful. You’re allowed to take photos in the majority of the areas you visit, with the exception of the Dome Hall. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and spoke very good English, and she was good at providing people with time to take pictures.My only complaint about the tour is that you only cover a small amount of the building. For example, you see the chamber that is no longer in use, rather than the main parliamentary chamber. However, you can’t expect a great deal in 40-45 minutes.

An amazing building. This is a phenomenal building, probably like none other as a seat of government. The tour was interesting and comprehensive as well as educational. Tours are given in just about every language (ours was in English and easily understood).

Don't miss this & pre-book the tour. One of the most beautiful and impressive buildings inside and out. It is a must see, truly amazing. We booked our tour on-line and were very happy we did. There were several who tried to buy tickets that day, only to find out there were sold out. The tour is approximately 45 minutes long and very informative with stunning interiors. The tour is given in eight different languages. The price depends on nationality and age. Go to www.hungarianparliament.com. Within very short walking distance is the Shoes on the Danube, another must see.
wonderful!. Walking along the shores of Danube this building is the first thing that you can see. It's wonderful in the night with all the lights.

It's beautiful, but i had higher expectations. Don't get me worng here...the parliament builing is absolutely wonderful and its beautiful architecture makes it the true gem of Budapest...however I have travelled a lot in my life and I must say in this review that the visit to the inside of the building fails to impress for several reasons, first being the massive waiting time you have to stay in the queue having waited more than one hour to get in; and secondly you only get to see four rooms inside the building in a really quick tour...and then you think...ok i just wasted one hour to get in...what about the rest (of the building)? So I was quite disappointed from an atraction standpoint, since you get to see so little and it's way too touristic. Perhaps if they had made a longer tour, and used a part of a building to make a "parliament exhibition" with pictures of it being built and such, it would have felt like someting more consistant and with more content. Sure the interior is beautiful, but it felt there was so much left to see.
gorgeous!!. Didn't go inside, but the views both from the chain bridge and close up really show of the beauty of this building. Worth seeing- it's the second largest in Europe and third in the world!

Nice and impressive. Nice place to see, impressive palace!In the city center so easy to place on a daily visit! Not long tho, after 15 minutes outside you are ok. Some guard shift changes can be seen.

Stunning buildings. We didn't pay to visit the inside of the Parliament buildings but the exterior is stunning enough. Set majestically on the banks of the Danube these are some of the largest parliament buildings in the world.

Make sure you book your ticket online. There are guided tours available in various language, however I would recommend taking an English tour (German was not so good).It is highly recommended to book the tickets online, because one can select the time and there is no need to queue up.
Good tour. You have to be in a small group as only so many can go round at a time. Some rooms you can take pics, some you can't. This is a must.
Parliament at night time. We walked by the Parliament in the day time and thought it was outstanding but at night time it is a grand site to look at and take pictures. Just beautiful!

wish we could have seen more. What we saw was nice-but tour seemed so short. Wish we could have seen more of the building. The replica of the building in matchsticks was amazing, as was the art work. It is confusing that you have to go across the street for tickets and even then it was confusing where to go in the building for the tickets. We stood in the wrong line for quite awhile before we found out it was the wrong line.

new visitor center. If you buy your ticket on site, you will not have to go to Museum of Ethnography anymore.A new visitor center was opened on the north side of the square (near a huge statue with stone lion on the top). The center is under the ground, so no more queuing on the sun. Not just the ticket office, the bar, the Parliament Museum and the toilets are there, but the security check and the tour also launches from the visitor center.Certainly, you can use the toilet if you do not intend to visit the Parliament.

An Impressive building. This is a very beautiful building from every angle, it is surprising how close you are allowed to get near it.It is visible from the Dunube and from the Pest side.The area around the building is pedestrianised and you can watch the change of the military guard and have your photo taken with them.It is well worth taking the tour of the inside , which gives you a glimpse of how they operate their Parliament.A couple of tips , buy your ticket on line as you won't have to queque to purchase one.They like quequing and it can take some time to get your ticket.If you purchase your ticket on the day take some ID to prove you are an EU citizen as you get in for half price.The tour is in English but only at certain times of the day so check before you decide to buy.

Pricey, but beautiful!. You have to purchase the tickets across the street at the Ethnography Museum; WAY ahead of time. So get there early in the day to get a tour ticket. A little pricey, but the inside of the Parliament is absolutely gorgeous! You should definitely check it out.

not easy to get tickets. but this is worth the visit. Inside and out are beautiful. Take a walk around the piazza out front, get your tickets at the Ethnography museum across the street. Best to go in the afternoon when there aren't so many cruisers!

Visiting the Parliament. Visits to the Parliament are only permitted in organized groups led by our tour guides. A tour takes approximately 45 minutes – including the security check.Please be advised that as you enter the Parliament Building the Guards of the Parliament will carry out a security check. If you refuse to undergo this check, the Guards may deny you permission to enter the Building.The sections of the Parliament you will visit during the tour are as follows: the Main Staircase, the Great Dome Hall, the Holy Crown and the Hungarian Coronation Jewels, the Lobby and the Session Hall of the former House of Lords. Please note that this route may be altered or shortened due to parliamentary or state events.There are no guided tours on national/bank holidays: 15th March, 20th August and 23rd October. There are also no visits to the Parliament on the following days: 1st January, Easter Sunday, Easter Monday, 1st November and 24th-26th December.http://www.parlament.hu/english-page
A GRAND BUILDING. The whole building is spectacular - very large, very beautiful and steeped in history. We went on a guided tour which was well worth the small cost.
fabulous. an amazing building which is the most visible from the Danube. Very impressive and you can watch the guard change there - have a look at their way of walking (especially feet) :)

Beautiful building. This is a really beautiful building. Clearly a lot of work has been done in recent years to make the area around the building pleasant. We were lucky enough to be there when there was a military display in the square at the back of the building it was spectacular with such an amazing backdrop. You can have tours inside the building but we didn't have time. I understand it is worth seeing though and I will make the time next time I visit Budapest.
As impressive as the Houses of Parliament. Taken round on a private visit some years ago, before it was open to the public. You must put this on your things to do list, it is marvellous.

Hungary's architectural gem. Hungary's Parliament Building is definitely one of Budapest's main tourist attractions and shall be high in the list of any visitor's must-see sites. Long lines of visitors are to be expected in the high season. So it would be wise to book ahead and avoid the queues. The tours are very well organized both in terms of punctuality, language and content. The building ityself, outside as well as inside is an architectural gem and doubtlessly one of the most photographed places in Hungary. Yes, your time and money will be well spent on a visit to this iconic landmark.

Architectural Eye Candy. What a fantastic and awesome landmark. Well worth a visit inside. The inside tour lasts about an hour and is not expensive. The interior is spectacular and you can take pictures everywhere except in the area that displays the royal crown. This display has an honor guard whose ritual is worth seeing in itself.
