Magical building. This is such a landmark--so spired and beautiful. It was under repair so we couldn't go it, but well worth a look.

We couldnt go in. Unfortunately, that amazing building entrance tickets were fully sold out when we tried to enter last week. In addition to this the other facade of it is not that welcoming as many construction works are being done and the scene isnt that pretty anymore. However on the Danube river side, this parliament building can be spot from all over Budapest and the gothic style of it and the grandiose architucture is not to be missed.

Closed for Construction. While it was closed for construction in May 2013, just the sheer size of it and the magificent architecture, made walking by worthwhile. We were sad to be informed by our tour guide that much of it is now vacant.

Breathtaking. The Parliament is the 3rd largest in the world which came as a great surprise to me. While we did not go inside the Parliament itself, the entire architecture of the building takes your breath away! That and the fact that the Parliament is situated on the banks of the River Danube make it a rather imposing piece of architecture!

Worst organisation ever met. This morning I checked on my iPad about ticket availability for tomorrow June 5. There were plenty of tickets available in the languages that suited us. As I have no printer with me, I thought it is better to buy the ticket at the ticket booth at the ethnological museum. When we arrived there, there was no queue, but the guard told us that no tickets would be available any more. I insisted and he showed me the way to go to the ticket booth. There three ladies were chattering with each other. When I asked for tickets, she told me she could not "see anything". What ever that meant I did not know. I told her that I would like to visit only tomorrow, she repeated again "I can't see anything". I told them that all this is ridiculus and left quite in anger.Back at the hotel 4 hours later, I notice that one can still buy plenty of tickets online. Finally I decided, that this organisation does not deserve my visit.

Nice to visit only if you have reserved online the tickets.. Take into account that nowadays there are contraction works outside the building which make it hard to get an impression of the facade.buy your tickets online on the parliament website in advance since as i understood it's the only way to buy tickets (3,500 HUF for non EU citizens,1,750 HUF for EU citizens).the building from the inside is beautiful and impressive.

Magnificent from the river. The major landmark and a magnificent building, best viewed from the river. All of the land based side was under repair when we were there (May 2013), so we were disappointed on that side)

Very impressive. The Parliament building is huge, the second tallest building in Budapest. It is most impressive lit up at night, but you need to see it during the day too to admire the great symetry and architectural details.

EURAMA TOUR IS BEST. excellent tour, worthy of westminster uk...neo gothic interior,including hungarian jewels,halls and assembly,. well worth the price,,,a guided tour is best as too long queues.. and limited places... see the guards saluting the holy crown and orb...

Don't even bother. Tried to visit this place which looks very attractive architecturally. Didn't in the end because 1 the place was surrounded by building works on our approach, there were no signs directing us to the entrance, or where to buy tickets, so we had to guess where to go. We arrived at a guard in his small wooden box, he was most unfriendly though he did direct us where to go.2 we arrived at the Museum of Ethnography (where you buy tickets) but before going in, noticed how long the queue was.3 there was a notice near the queue which said that there was no cloakroom, so if you were bringing a bag you wouldn't be allowed in. I was carrying a medium-size rucksack so decided I wouldn't be allowed in, so we gave up and went elsewhere.Dreadful.

One of the nicest in the world. As we arrived at night in Budapest with a Viking Cruise ship, we saw the parliament all lit up with other buildings and structures. Unfortunetly we could not visit because of renovations, I must say that this is one of the nicest parliament buildings and I have seen many e.g. England, Canada, Austria etxc

Crown of the Arpads. The exterior of Budapest's Parliament building is a stunning feature along the Pest side of the Danube, but there is really only one compelling reason to tour its interior - to see the gold Byzantine-style crown of the Arpad kings (the so-called "crown of St. Stephen"). The crown, a scepter, and a later sword are all displayed in a case under the huge dome at the center of the Parliament building and they are guarded by two soldiers in splendid uniforms. Admittedly, the light is a bit dim, and one cannot get very close, but the fact that this crown - which dates from about 1,000 AD and was spirited out of Hungary during WWII (held securely at Fort Knox!) - is back in its rightful place in the free nation of Hungary is worth celebrating. It is a potent national symbol and a beautiful object.

Awesome Parliament. Just wow!!! every view in Budapest features this huge neo-gothic structure. Built in a similar style to our own bar the huge Dome it provides a grand and graceful backdrop against the Hungarian skyline! We walked along the river towards the Shoes display to see it in the flesh,there was some work going on but that didnt really detract from the magnificent carvings and ornate stone towers and alcoves! We didnt go inside,I think my teenagers would have killed me after after all the walking we had done that day,definately worth a look close up! We also drifted past it at night on a cruise of the Danube,well all I can say is Wow,again it looks like a palace when lit up, a truly beautiful building!

construction site!. a lot of renovation work is going on all around the Parliament building, which does spoul the view, and make it very noisy and dusty. we booked a tour online, and arrived with our tickets, we only saw the entrance and the crown under the dome. The rest of the building was closed. Security bag search and scanner to go through before entering.

Beautiful Building. I love this building....it is a gem! It is currently being renovated but that does not take away from the charm. The tour is too short and does not show you enough. To be honest I was a little disappointed about the inside of the building. I guess I was expecting something more grandeur. Still worth the tour though!!! Walk across the Chain Bridge and get a picture at night when the building is all lit up!

You don't see much, but what you do see is magnificent. The massively impressive parliament building is awash with gilt and grandeur and worth a visit. However, you'll only get to see three areas - the grand staircase, the dome area and one of the parliamentary chambers. A bit off-putting is the security overkill: unnecessary queues, airport-style scanners, a soldier accompanying every guided tour, and instructions to stand several yards away from more soldiers guarding the Hungarian crown. Someone should remind them that the Cold War is over.
Parliament building. This is a beautiful building best viewed from the river or the castle side of Budapest. The building is beautifully lit up at night which adds to the ambience.

Such a short visit. We thought it would be a wider coverage of the Parliament Building but came out disappointed as we were limited to only a small area despite the enormous complex.
The interior was very grand and impressive and made me wonder how much it had cost to construct the place.
Currently Under Renovation. This imposing building is situated on the River Danube. It was undergoing renovation when we were there so unfortunately we did not get to go inside.
Fantastic Building - Tour too short. The building itself is wonderful, however the service from the staff and the length of the tour (English) left a lot to be desired.

nice tour. Very nice tour, it is important to book ahead or go early and stand in line
We arrived at 930 and we were able to get tickets of a tour of 12 and we were the last
Beautiful building. The best view of this building is from the Fishermans Bastion where you can get some great photos. We never managed to get inside unfortunately as building works were in progress.

Beautiful interior still under renovation. The guided tours through this building really don't take you very far, but gives you just enough to get a sense of the history and you get to see the Royal Crown and the Parliament area. Very ornate. You can only take pictures in designated areas. Be prepared for airport style security and military guards. You have to go with the group and pretty much it seemed like there was a scheduled admittance time.
Beautiful!. Definitely worth viewing from all angles as this is a classic, and the view across the Danube is just amazing. Remember to view it at night as well!

Better than expected. Did not intend to visit the Hungarian Parliament, while out on a long walk decided to see what was doing. Found the ticket office and booked up for a guided tour an hour and a half later with English speaking guide. In the interim visited the Museum of Heritage. Guide presented the tour in a very easily understood format and made sure that everyone got enough time to see the main attractions. The original House of Lords was the highlight for me.

Interesting visit. We bought tickets online in advance and did a morning tour. The guide showed us the inside of this very beautiful building and explained the history and structure of the parliament. A worthwhile hour.

Worth a visit. If you're a EU citizen take identification and can then get get reduced price admission.Didn't know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised, it was very interesting. Were allowed to take photos wherever we wanted apart from under the main dome where the Holy Cross is. The main stairs are fantastic as is the dome.There's a lot of work currently going on at the front of the building at the moment so it's a bit of a mission to get there

Perfect View from Buda, Terrible Construction View from Pest. Skip the walk to Parliament right now because the construction, dirt, and noise is overwhelming. The Danube view is better long distance, although one can walk (sort of) this one side of the great cakelike building!

Book ahead of time.. If you are an EU citizen you can get in free, but I have heard that you need to queue up for tickets. If you are not a member of the EU you need to pay so you might as well book a ticket online. The signs out front say that tours start at 10:00 am, but online there are tickets available for tours as early as 8:00. You can pick your time and your language easily so you can plan your day accordingly. If you print your tickets at home you don't need to be early- just show up at the time of your tour. You wait outside for a few minutes then you get divided by language and proceed through security. Our English speaking tour guide had a very thick accent and the acoustics are not the best, so try to get up close (but let the kids in front of you so they can see). When the guide tells you NOT to take pictures in the dome area, take it seriously. They will give you time to take photos WITHOUT flash after the explanation. If you take a photo with flash the entire group will be asked to leave the dome immediately. I am not sure why this is, but it happened to our group. Everyone was given five minutes to snap some pictures but one lady let her flash go off. The minute it did the tour guide freaked and we all had to leave. She said it was good that it happened after the explanation or we would have missed the entire room. The building is pretty and the information provided is very interesting. FYI, there are no visitor restrooms.During the construction it is tricky to find the entrance, but just ask the construction workers or anyone else on the street and they are nice and helpful.

Stunning and Impressive. We booked on line for the English language tour, I would suspect that there is little capacity for visitors who just walk up seeking to join a tour. One realises how important Hungary and the Austrian-Hungarian influence was on central Europe up until WW1.The State Crown, which the guides call The Holy Crown is sacred to the Hungarians, so no Flash photography of this national treasure, and they mean it.

Spectacular Building - Beware of Construction. During our visit in mid-May, there was a significant amount of construction surrounding the building. The structure is magnificent from every angle - whether you are standing in its shadows on the Pest side or viewing it from Castle Hill Buda or even Margit Island in the middle of the Danube.

Must See. Although there is a lot of building work on the outside and is confussing as to where the tickets are bought from and where the entrance is,it is well worth the visit. it is stunning inside. we had a tour in English, you are escorted round with your tour guide as well as a member of their armed forces.

Worth a look - especially if you're British. The Hungarian parliament building was 'copied' on Westminster. The only external difference is that, unlike ours, the Hungarian version is symmetrical. You can take a tour - ticket in advance - but, right now, the entire area around the building has been dug up and looks like a bomb site.

A "compulsory" visit and very beautiful building. I am impressed of what beautiful building from outside and insideThe Spanish guide was not so good also not really friendlyYou must be very formal with the military who keep the crown and guide you, because if you are not, they can make your visit shorterBut any way was a good and very recommended visit
A Noble Palace. Built not long after the Palace of Westminster and certainly on a rather grander scale! 46 kilos of gold leaf included in the decoration. Well worth taking a guided tour.

Not their #1 attraction. Though filled with treasures and a crisp changing of the guard ceremony, our guide was hard to hear unless you were a few yards from her. She had the most heavily accented English of any guide in Budapest--one in every five words was decipherable. We went there because the DK guidebook said it was the number #1 sight in Budapest and because we hoped for a description of Hungary's history. It was neither. What we could discern of our guide's presentation was statistics about height of the towers, length of the room, and where the legislator's placed their cigars.

shame its having work done. We went to see this place and it was shame that we could not get near it as they are doing building work on it and have fences surrounding it and work men everywhere.If you go on a cruise down the river though then you can see the other side of it which does look beautiful. Its just a shame that we could not get near the other side of it.

Arguably world's most beautiful building. I have traveled around the world and would only put Taj Mahal along with the Parliament building in Budapest. Set along the Danube, this stunningly complex, white stone, and deep red roofed building, glistens both during the day and at night when it is lit up spectacularly. The best places to take in the beauty of the parliament are, due to its huge size across the river. There is a walking path parallel to the river, but if you want more perspective of the building go up to the fisherman's bastion close to the palace on buda hill for a sweeping view of the old city from a beautiful castle wall in front of the colorful roof church. It is certainly worth a tour to view the opulent interior of the parliament building but the view from across the river should not be missed.

Good to see. Was quite a quick tour, about 45 mins, but bear in mind part of that is getting through security. Tickets are purchased in the museum of ethnography while all the road works are being carried out. We arrived about 9am to purchase tickets and all the English tours were available apart from the 10am. You get to see one of the grand staircases, as well as the crown jewels and one of the debating rooms, and some other interesting bits. All very opulent with some great photo opportunities.

Free Entry on Some Days. This building itself is amazing, and the interior follows through with that theme. We were there on a day when entry was free. Normal entry fee is not much though.One thing that was odd was the line to get in. We had to circle all the way around a maze, when there was NO line of people waiting at all. Made the walk very long and circuitous when we could have been able to walk a straight line in, for about 30 feet. Instead, it seemed like a quarter of a mile around in circles! This is a must see experience. Outside, there were vendor tents selling various souvenirs and food.

Just an Amazing Building. You wouldn't know it, but this beautiful building is the largest Parliament Building in the EU or in general, Europe. The architecture really shows the hundreds of years of influence between the Ottoman Empire, Romans, and other wonderful cultures that have lasted hundreds and hundreds of years. A definite must to see. You won't be disappointed.Enjoy...the traveler from Southern Ca.....
Wonderful architecture. The visit inside takes about 30min, not really enlightening but it gives a good impression on how the republic of Hungary works. The outside is magnificent.
breathtaking. it is truly worth visiting, the inside is really incredibly beautiful and amazing, lots of gold leave

Buy tickets online and come in time. There is a chaos in front of the building because of the construction work. We bought tickets online and came in advance (in fact, too early - it is enough to come, say, 10 minutes before your tour starts and find out where people with tickets are waiting). The 45-min. visit definitely worth money, the building is very impressive.

Recommend booking in advance!. Lovely from the outside, restored after WW2 (saw the pictures from the air raid bunker of it during the war!). We didnt book and it was sold out - recommend booking in advance online.Lovely landmark, based on Westminster.

Chaos getting in and major roadworks outside. Be warned - the whole area around is being renovated so there is a long pedestrian badly signed diversion. The tour tickets are available from the Enthnographical Museum but when we arrived there was a massive queue and only one kiosk open so we missed the tour we wanted to go on. We rebooked for 10.45 tour ( which is not advertised anywhere ) stood in another queue when we got there to get in and then it took ages to get through the scanners. By this time we were losing the will to live but we are glad we stayed as it is a very beautiful and impressive building. You get in for 1/2 price if you show your Europassport ( some guidebooks state free but this was not the case ) so that is a saving worth getting.

Stunning. The building is amazing!! It's amazing that it's still being used today and in such great shape, especially after WWII. I didn't have the issue with tickets, as I came with a tour and they took care of it for us, so I can't speak to that end. The tour takes about an hour, and being able to see all the interior detail is worth coming to visit. The crown jewels are impressive- it's amazing to look at something that's 1000 years old. Be aware that you can take photos of the crown jewels, but with no flash. If anyone of your group takes a photo with the flash, the entire group gets moved to the next room! Also, there are no public restrooms here, so be sure to go if you need to before entering for your tour. Our guide was good, spoke English well and was informative. Worth the visit if in Budapest!

A lot of effort but worthwhile. I contemplated about this place when planning the trip. It just seemed so much trouble to make a trip to book ticket and then another trip to visit. But after the visit, I think it was very worthwhile. This was no ordinary parliament. The exhibits inside were special and the building was of course very beautiful.

So-so attraction. We didn't know about buying the tix in advance so that messed things up for the beginning of this quest yesterday. We were told to come back today to buy them. We did, only to find out that we had to come back 2 1/2 hours later for the tour. By 1:00 or earlier, they were sold out for the day. Our guide was okay but it was hard to hear him as he spoke softly and swallowed a lot of his words. The most interesting part was seeing where the House of Commons meets but there were so many in our group, I had to wait for him to finish and the group to exit that little cubby hole, and then dart in to glance around and take a few pix. It is a pretty place inside but really, the outside is the impressive view. If you don't want the hassle or are short on money, walk around it... better still, go across the river and see it from there... or from a tour boat at night. Now that's spectacular!

hard to get inside. If you get the chance, try to arrive at Parliament in time to tour the inside. The outside is majestic and best seen by night from the river, but do make sure you see what makes the people most proud.

Book your tour in advance, they sell out quick. As with any online booking in Budapest, you must be able to print your ticket....so go to an internet cafe (you can't book in advance at the ticket office). Whilst here, take a walk down the Danube and you'll find a memorial to the Jewish murdered during the Holocaust (a collection of shows lined up along the embankment). Worth a visit.

Under renovation!. Getting tickets for this was like something out of a cold war spy movie. As you had to show your passport and then be escorted to the ticket area. A grumpy ticket seller and the irritation of queuing for a long time for the ticket only to have to return much later to take the tour. The tour lady was interesting but was quite difficult to understand as she had a very strong accent.

Grandiose. The tour of the parliament shows the Budapest of an other age. When money was not an issue, when beautiful buildings were built.Worth a visit while in Budapest. No superlative enough to describe the visit.
Parliament house in Budapest. A must to see when in Budapest, even if you have to wait some time before the ticket box, great architecture and reflection of an great culture.

Fine Architecture. Once again we didn't go in but from the outside the building is a work of Art. Again beautiful illuminated at night. Designed on the UK Houses of Parliament there are definitely similarities.

Stunning Parliament. The tour doesn't last too long (45 minutes) but you will be astonished by the beauty of this building. It's stunning, the marble is gorgeous and there is gold leaf everywhere. The cost is appropriate and you will enjoy.

Very informative. I think if you follow TA as we did you would see that it was important to book your tickets ahead on line as we did. We walked straight to the building and had no trouble with ticket collection. One tip - we had a picnic lunch packed with a small cutting knife. There is a strict security system at the Parliament and we had to leave our utensils at their security check. if we had realised we would not have had the knife with us.

Very bad organized sales of the tickets. With Parliament being one of the main attractions in Budapest you would think that sales of the tickets would be better organized. We were waiting hour and half at morning (in the line there were maybe max40 people) to get tickets for 5.30PM. Nobody could tell why the line didn't move at all. Half hour tour was very informative and it is worth seeing Parliament inside.
Beautiful and interesting. Must book:a complete tour of a wonderful place, with very kind guide and a very interesting history.

Among the biggest in Europe, Beautiful building.. The Parliament is one of those "can't miss it if you are in Budapest" monuments, it is one of the biggest in Europe and has a lot of history behind it. This said, some of the guided tours can take up hours, so it depends what you are into, personally, I was happy to just go check it out from outside.

must visit but must plan ahead. this place really live up to the expectation eventhough the tour is abit rush and would love to have more time for photo but also understand all the constrain that this place still need to serve it main function. you can book the ticket online which we found it very easy and don't have to worry to come early to buy ticket. I think you need to pay small extra fee but totally worth it. Just need to make sure that you get here on time.

Worth a visit. Booked online on the morning of our visit, which was wise as there was a long queue to buy tickets onsite. Due to all the reconstruction work it was hard to know where to enter, there should be more and better signs. Once inside, we were taken through a few very ornamented staircases and halls by a good guide giving us the story behind the building and some interesting facts. The tour lasted 45 min incl security control. I recommend it.

Book in advance on internet. I could not be able to visit parliament because it was difficult to buy tickets. I have been told from many people to book in advance because of issue with lack of tickets. If you want be sure to visit it book in advance.
Worth booking a trip.. Beautiful building both inside and outside. Being cleaned outside when we visited so a bit messy. Worth going around with a guide, beautiful inside and very interesting.
Buy tickets online!. We didn't buy our tickets in advance and stood a long time waiting , we didn't get in........Very nice building though.

So beautiful!!! But reserve your tickets through internet.. The first time we went, we couldn't find the entrance at entrance X. The surroundings of the parliament is being reconstructed at he moment (end of april 2013)When we found a small entrance without X next to the big stairs, the tickets for that day were gone. We heard you could buy tickets through internet. The next day we immediately bought tickets by pc. We had to go to entrance XII, we couldn't find it and went to the small entrance we had found, which was good. Inside the parliament everything was very beautiful.

Breathtaking building. Parliament is Hungary's legislative centre, built in the Gothic Revival style. It is the 2rd largest Parliament in the World (England's is the largest). Unfortunately we did not get to see the inside, but the outside is the most beautiful building I have ever seen. Viewing it at night from the river ship cruise was breathtaking. You may have to book on line a day or so ahead to be able to take a tour.
Beautiful building. I was surprised to see how beautiful the buidling was inside, definitely worth a visit! We booked the tour with a guide the same morning ( in english).

Parliament. The Parliament is one of the most important sights of the city. There are organized tours to visit inside, but you should book quit earlier because there are no tours every day. You can book it in the hotels or travel agency. It's a very beautiful building outside and inside as well. Inside you can see the painting of the famous hungarian painter Munkácsy. Unfortunatelly now there is reconstruction on the Kossuth square so you can not have a beautiful wiew to the building with the park, statues together.
Boat trip. Fantastic building. If you like architecture you will love this particular building. This is a must see.
Tons of gold. The most beautiful building in Budapest, the carvings and paintings are unmissableEU travellers get a reduced ticket, so take your passport

Spectacular building. Apart from the scaffolding and construction they were doing to a big part of the building, it was a spectacular building, hugeeee, much better than our parliament building haha!You got great views of is from across the river

Don't bother if you're not from the EU. It took us two days of lining up in the morning for 1 hr + to get a ticket for a guided tour to the Parliament in Budapest. When we were finally allowed into the ticket office we were dismayed to find that although the visit is free for EU citizens, we had to pay 20 Euros EACH (no student discount!) as Australians. The tour itself was fine, but short compared to others we have been on, and the guide was really just running through the motions. It went for less than 40 min, despite being advertised as a 1 hour tour. The building itself is very beautiful, but more impressive from the outside than the interior. Would recommend that non-EU citizens take in its beauty from the outside, or better yet, the view from Castle Hill across the river. Alternatively, go on the Opera tour instead - full of fun facts and myths about its building!

Under construction. This is a beautiful building inside but the whole front plaza is under construction and a total mess. You can't see any of the statues or figure out where to go. Book the tour online ahead of time and leave time to find your way. Once you're inside, the place is beautiful.

Privileged inspection. Unfortunately, there were substantial road works being undertaken in the streets outside and we were unable to catch the tram to Parliament, but the walk was very interestin anyway. We couldn't get to visit immediately and had to wait for the next tour, but we were able to spend the time in a great restaurant nearby, so no problem. The Parliament Building was very ornate and apparently modelled on the English Parliament Building. The Gothic vaulting was magnificant. I am so pleased that we were able to visit.

Beautiful building. We booked the trip on the Internet, Viator, who picked us up at the hotel by taxi, took us to their office and then by minibus to the Parliament Building. We could have walked there quicker! It was worth booking in advance to avoid the queues. The guide was very good. There is a lot of building work going on around the outside of the building. The tour was very interesting and informative. Well worth a visit.

Put this at the top of your list. This is one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen, anywhere. Order your tickets online for the next day-- you're almost certain to be sold out at the gate. The tour is relatively brief but very interesting, and the exterior of the building, especially at night from the river, will take your breath away.

EXCELLENT! TERRIFIC ! WONDERFULL ! UWAW BUILDING ........... What can i say about Budapest's Parliament !! I saw this wonderfull building only from outside in a tour with bus , from the ferry in our Dunabe's River cruise and on foot as i cross Chains Bridge going from Buda to Pesti.This building is amazing even if you see it in daylight or at night as it is illuminated.I felt really very sorry that i diden't visited inside the building,but i promised myself that this will be the reason to visit another time Budapest, even is along queue or the ticket expensive, i will do it. What i saw from peoples pictures,the building is Brilliant inside and is worthwhile to have this experience.Maybe is equal or better than Versalies or Shcobrun.

Unless you book online, prepare to spend a long time queuing!. We never actually managed to get inside down to the extremely un-organised staff. There are different language tours going on at different times of the day so you will need to find out in advance what times the tour you want to take are at. Try to book your tickets online as we went to get tickets at 11:15AM for the 12PM tour in English. There were two queue's, the one on the left is where you wait to buy your tickets and the one on the right is where you queue to go inside. There is absolutely no sign-posting telling you which queue you need to be in so we had to rely on asking other people. They only allow about 3 people at a time through to buy tickets and then you need to join another queue. Note: At no point does anyone tell you that the tickets for the tours have sold out and we had to wait until we were about to purchase the tickets and then we were told! A complete and utter waste of time because the next English tour was at 1:45PM and we had to leave for the airport. We tried to get on the next tour which was in French but this was also sold out with nothing indicating that this was the case!

sheer elegance. We walked to the Parliament house in the snow, queued for 30 mins and when we realised the queue did not move much, I then proceed to the front of the queue to read the signboard. We decided to go back to the hotel and asked the concierge to book the tickets online. The website is http://www.jegymester.hu/eng/Production/480000/Parliament-visitThere are many tours available throughout the day in Spanish, English, Italian, German and French. We were advised that if there are delegates visiting the tours won't run. Adult fee is 3500 HUF, non EU citizen is 1750 HUF. Groups tour the building for 50 minutes, proceeding through the main staircase into the Dome hall, surveying the coronation paraphernalia, on to the parlour, and the upper chamber's room. It took a while to get in as they have to conduct security checks just like at the airport. The problem is they only have 1 machine in operation therefore we had to wait 15 minutes. Worth a visit? Definitely!!

Tour of Parliament. You can usually turn up on the day with your passports and get a guided tour of the inside of Parliament which lasts 30-40 minutes and is informative but lacked a lot of detail about the history. When we went in April 2013 there is a lot of renovation going on at the front which does restrict the photo opportunities, but worth going to the otherside of the Danube to get some fabulous photos of the dark red roof and the sandstone facade.

Queues!. In theory, holders of EU passports can get in free of charge but, having queued twice to no avail in hot sunshine, we gave up. You can buy advance tickets online or through your hotel at a cost of around £10, I believe, but we noticed that there were still long queues, even for those with tickets pre-purchased.However, the building from outside, especially from across the river on the Buda side, looks absolutely beautiful in white stone. There's currently a lot of work being carried out on the north side of the building, causing disruption to trams and traffic in the area.

Changing the guide.... Little bit pain with the reconstruction arround...no clear signs where people should go...not a nice waiting lane but a masssss of people pushing each other, shouting between each other which group is now going (english, german, hungarian, spanish) with the help of turists, not the organisators!It is very nice, worth to see it, but our guide in english could be much better (also with info, also with pronanciation in english. Her name was Ilona). As a german speaking group was before us (started cc. 10 minutes earlier) first our group reached them, than overtook them..and ended the tour earlier. As we spoke also german in half time we sneaked to the german group. Much, much better explanation, much more interesting information and details..Definitely an online ticket. With queing hours for a ticket is a no go!

Very worth a visit.. I've been going to Budapest for about 6 years.I was determined togo to the Parliament building this time.The tour lasts about 45minutes.lts very worth a look.The guide takes you around the building very quickly.So make the most of your photo's.You don't get alot of time to take them.

Don't miss this opportunity!. Very beautiful and impressive building – and the interior does not disappoint! The tour is interesting, but be sure to get there early to reserve a spot, because this is a very popular place to visit. Remember to bring your passport or identity papers. You are allowed to take photos inside. It is free for european citizens

Must see building. The Hungarian Parliament building is absolutely incredible outside and inside. It was built in 1896 and has nothing as grand, expensive and beautiful to compare with. If you have any time, please take a small boat tour (south of Chain Bridge) to see the Parliament from the Danube River.

"this is a truly must-see ". Do not want to "own the truth", but this palace or building is a true work of art ones can just enjoyed from almost any site of Budapest. Budapest Parliament is the third largest in the world and represents one of the city's architectural masterpieces. With a neo-Gothic style and located along the river-side it looks similar to London's Houses of Parliament.

Beautiful. It's amazing that they actually let visitors inside that building. Too bad Europeans have to pay now too (not much, but still). Better order your tickets in advance to avoid loooonnnggg waiting lines.

At present large scale renovation works taking place. At the moment there are large scale renovations taking place to the rear at the Parliament and so all the best pictures are only from the river side, also if you wish to visit we recommend pre- booking by internet because by the time we arrived all slots/times had been taken and so we did not get inside the building.Best views are from the river or from the Buda side.The guards do not explain very much, entry is in the centre at the rear.

Budapest must see. Inside tour is a must. We learned how fortunate we were to not have to wait and not be turned away after we had completed the tour. The outside, especially at night from the Buda side is also a must.
Lovely building. The building itself is spectacular especially on a sunny day from the Buda side. Nice views from the hill

Well worth a visit. We booked this tour online and it was a good move. There is security scanning etc. that makes entry a slow process but once inside our English speaking guide made the visit very worthwhile. It is a beautiful place to see and houses the crown the kings were crowned with it from the twelfth century onwards.

Beautifully decorated interior. I took the guided tour around the parliament.Tour took around 30 minutes in which we learned some interesting facts about building and Hungarian history. Interior is nicely decorated with a lot of gold. Main attraction are crowning jewels which are the oldest Christian crowning jewels perceived till present. If you are planning to take the tour (which I recommend) buy tickets in advance through internet. It will save you hours of waiting in line.

difficult to get in...not much to see... but must see !!!!. to go to the parliament get M2 to "kossuth ter station". A very long queue to let you go to the ticket window, then another queue to get in the building, then a very strict security procedures before you "practically" get in... then after all of that, the tour is "half an hour"!!!. They let you see very little of the inside of the building. So prepare yourself for about 4-5 hours waiting time, and half an hour visit... But you can Not visit Budapest without seeing the Parliament.. Try to think positive, and get the best out of the visit.

Buy your ticket online!. If you intend on visiting buy you're ticket online first. The queues are ridiculous at times and no one will tell you where to go. There are separate queues to buy tickets and enter with tickets.

Most spectacular building I have ever seen!. You will walk away with many photos of this spectacular building. Unless you are on the river, or across the river, it is hard to get it all in one shot, as it is so large. You must make an appointment ahead of time to visit the inside.
Excellent. Go!. Very interesting. Interiour with gold and glamour. Really good guided tour. If you do 1 or 2 things do this first!

Didnt get in. we intended to spend a few hours with a tour here inside, unfortunately even though we got there an hour early the queues we extensive only allowing 2 people into ticket office at a time and by time we got to front of queue we discovered that the 1pm tour we wanted had been filled up by 10am so the next was for 3pm...sadly this was too late for us....so advice is........if you want to go either prebook or go day of arrival and queue to get the day and times you want.

Astonishing. It will leave you breathless for the richness and the gold paintings of the interior. Everything is gold except the floor. We reserved a guided tour at 15.30 and we were lucky enough to see the change of the guards. You must reserve your ticket in advance on the Parliament website and you'll enjoy some of the magnificence of the Austro Ungarian empire

Short tour.. Went on a 45 minute tour of Parliament. Wish you could see more, but worth it. Very informative guide. No restrooms available inside or nearby so be aware. Helpful hint is to go see the Holocaust memorium of shoes by the Danube when you leave. They are a short walk from Parliament on the shore of Danube. Facing front of Parliament would be to your right.

Not been in the British one so this was good to see as based on it!. Lovely building which we visited on a public holiday so it was free to go in. We got there early and only queued for about 5 minutes. Bags through the scanner and we were in. I liked the crown jewels - basically a crown with a crooked cross (bent when smuggled from Budapest in a baby's cot apparently) and an orb. Well placed and guarded inside a beautiful building. Loads of Hungarians there too.From the river the Parliament building is perfectly symmetrical - great architecture.

Short tour. We had a good guide (we took the english tour at 15.45) and the parliament was beautiful. But, having spent 10 minutes in the security check, our group only had 25 minutes inside the parliament. This was a huge disappointment. Our Hungarian friend had been there several times before and had always been able to see more rooms than we did, so probably we got a shorter tour than usual. Make sure you book tickets in advance, or else you will be standing in the queue for a very long time.

Buy tickets in advance!. You can buy tickets by joining the queue outside the building but expect a long wait. The queue moves very slowly as only a small number of people are permitted to go inside the small ticket office at a time. We waited over an hour and then were allocated an early afternoon slot which meant we had to return later in the day. Security is very strict so do not take large bags or penknives. Also in the room where the Crown Jewels are on display, it is forbidden to kneel to take photographs or to touch the barrier. In spite of all this, it is definitely worth a visit.

Main attraction on the Pest side. The most impressive building in the city as far as I am concerned. Absolutely stunning and great to visit if you are on the Pest side as due to the eye-catching nature of the building I personally found it incredibly useful as an orientation feature for all of my travels around the city even on the Buda side.

nice to see but... internally and externally this is a beautiful building. We were very let down with the inside tour which isnt cheap. It lasted 40 minutes and we only got to see the main hall and were quickly left by the guide. If we knew then what we know now, we would have simply taken in the building on the outside.
Book or risk disappointment. We queued for over an hour for the 12 noon tour then at about 12.05 a small sign was put up saying that there were no tickets available for this day! :-(

A MUST. If you interested in Architecture, it is a MUST! One of the most beautiful architecture I have seen (and I have seen a LOT) The tour guide is well spoken and cheerful. Was really nice to see, it is only a big shame the actual politics & goverment is killing the people and the country. The building itself is well worth a visit.

Puts the Houses of Parliament in London to shame!. A breathtakingly stunning building both inside and out. Walk along the Danube to visit this monument to opulent architecture and take as many photographs as you can!

Shame we could not go inside. By the time we got there, all tickets for the Saturday had sold out and it was closed on the Sunday and Monday. They are doing a lot of work to the library and around the outside of the building, which was rather messy. It is an impressive building, modelled on the UK Houses of Parliament. The only consolation was overhearing someone coming out, saying the tour was boring...

a bit expensive for such a brief tour. We visited the Parliament building today, having prepurchased our tickets online before we left (recommend jegymester.com.hu or something like that). The tour was short but admittedly what we saw was impressive -- the grand staircase, the crown of St. Stephen, and the session room. See this only if you want to see the crown; otherwise you could pass on this considering the cost of the tour. There was no time for questions at the end. A bit impersonal. Buy your tickets before as there was a long queue for those without tickets.
Stunning building. After a terrible queuing system despite having tickets in advance, we entered the beautiful building. Although a short tour - about 45 minutes it was worth seeing.

Crown jewels at the parliament. The Hungarian parliament is a beautiful old house, which carries a lot of history. We had a short tour with a guide, who was very informative and showed us interesting spots. Most impressive is the huge hall, in which one can see the Hungarian crown jewels, dating from the 11th century onwards, on display (picture attached).

Beautiful building not free anymore. First time I visited it was free for EU. The system has changed and now EU citizens pay to visit it, half price compared to non EU. I really reccomend you to book your ticket online to avoid queues and dissapointments, specially during the holiday season. The tour was a big group of 45/50 people so it wasnt easy to follow the explanations of the tour guide who spoke quite fast and soft, and look at the things at the same time. The tour is scorted by a soldier to hurry you up if you slow down or stop longer for a picture. They need to learn about customer service but as it is such a big demanded attraction I guess at the end of the day they dont really care much about it as they will always have more demand for tickets than supply.

Poor organisational skills compared to EVERWHERE!!!!!!!. First the pros; the building is very pretty from the outside (without taking a tour or talking to anyone), the decor inside is beautiful and they have a lovely carpet.Now the cons (of which there are many) per advice from tripadvisor we had prebooked ourtickets online which was easy. However being organised people we thought we would go early to get through security. BIG MISTAKE. We were twenty minutes early and there was actually very few people there when we arrived. They made us wait outside in the pouring rain for twenty minutes, across the road from the actual building. The staff did not explain this and if you stepped off the footpath to cross towards the building were very rude. At the appointed time and not a minute before they came out to collect the tour groups for English and German at this time there were at least 200 people waiting some of whom didn't have tickets and didn't realise you needed to cross the road to get the tickets. Then they take you into the building, we waited 20 minutes to get through security, and were still out of the building by the appointed 45 mins therefore the actual tour lasted 25 mins.Only saving grace it was quite cheap. However I would never waste the time to go again.If you do want to go I would advise people to get the tickets before and going straight to the top of the queue as there were so many people there when we were leaving that both the queues for people with tickets and those without had joined and they don't shout to the back of the queue annoucing tours are starting they just expect people to know.P.S. just to warn people there are no public facilities like a bathroom in the building.

Rubbish ticketing system. We arrived at the parliament, to realise it was closed for the day. This was actually a stroke of luck, because we saw a website advertised, with which you could book tickets online. This is exactly what we did. When we arrived the day after, with our tickets, we saw a huge queue of people waiting to buy their tickets, at the door. However, we were told that we could go to a smaller queue and wait for our tour. We had to wait a little while and in this short period of time, we learnt a lot about the ticketing system, if you hadn't pre-booked. The queue was still very long, when people were told that the tickets have been sold out. The people at the very front of the queue must have been waiting for at least an hour and were very angry to say the least. The tour was very short, but informative. The building itself was stunning. Would really emphasise the need to pre-book and to go on a warm day, as there is a lot of waiting around, even if you pre-book

The parliament building 5/5 but tour is rubbish. We had booked our tickets online in advance of the tour but still confusion at the time of where to wait etc, eventually a woman came out and brought us to the security check which is a bit ridiculous in my opinion as my girlfriend was frisked by a very ignorant individual, the Hungarians need to relax a bit over their parliament its not that interesting definately not worth the grief.The tour itself was pretty awful but thankfully it was very short as I was about to fall asleep, the crown of St Stephen was nice to see but that was all, again some of the group were man handled by some guards in the dome room, in fairness they need to get a grip and cop on. I can't overstate how rubbish the tour was with a guide who I had mistaken for a somnambulant due to the lack of interest even she had. There is nothing to see in this building. I gave it 2/5 solely because the parliament architecture is outstanding but appreciate it from a distance no need to enter. Also EU persons must now pay so I believe.

Beautiful place to visit and a must see. We did the guided tour. Bought the ticket on internet a week before. Guided tour was very interesting and the parliament is very beautiful full of gold decorations. Inside building is as amazing as the exterior structure. well worth the time if you could visit inside.

Elaborate & beautiful - shame it was a bit foggy. The palace is very grand and beautiful, unfortunately it was not an entirely clear day which ruined the view slightly. To get the best view you need to see the palace from across the river. Unfortunately we were unable to visit as there was an event on during our visit, but I believe you need to queue at least the day before for a ticket although they are free for EU members!

Worth it despite the hassle. The Parliament building is one of Budapest's most famous landmarks, with its beautiful riverside setting. The guided tour of the interior is interesting but quite limited - you only get to see five or six chambers inside the building. Not surprising, given that it is a working building, but perhaps it could be expanded (eg. a brief view of a debate). 45 minutes isn't really enough.It's best to buy your timed tickets before you go (quite easy by doing a web search) - even then entry is quite a hassle. You need to be at the eastern entrance (more or less opposite the end of Alkotmany u.) in good time. The guide will let you through the chain fence, then you have to queue up for a security check. It's a bit of a scrum as there can be several groups trying to go through at the same time.

Average. Its OK but most of the time is taken queuing to get in then more time wasted getting through the airport type security just as well it was dry or we would have been socked. Better things to see in Budapest especially if the time is short the best part can be viewed from the Danube.

Majestic Houses of Parliament. This magnificent building is both majestic and awe-inspiring. Buy your entry tickets online, and remember to take some form of ID with you (passport, driver's license). The Hungarian Crown is housed here, and is well worth a look. The tour guide was pleasant and informative, and you are given a large souvenir postcard featuring the Parliament as you leave the building.
See if it was like Westminister??. I have ot been to Westminster but a couple in our party had. We were very impressed with the building and the informative tour guide.

eye catching. If you look from the Buda side of the river the first thing you see is Parliament building as it is the biggest building in the city (691 rooms) Don't know how long it took them to build this but is is eye catching in anybodies book

Third largest Parliament building. Has a Neo-Gothic architecture which looks magnificient from outside.The interior is also very impressive.The staircase leads to the Hungarian Crown.When we went there it was Hungarian Revolution Day so the entry was free.And we saw the Hungarian troops perform their duties.Overall its a nice place to see in Budapest.

Tips for getting your tickets. I cannot add more here to what has already been said about the attractive building - it is very impressive, no doubt. However, I hope to offer some tips on getting into it in the first place, which is not obvious!There is a “waiting area” in front of the Parliament on the Kossuth Lajos ter (near where Alkotmany street meets the square), where many people are milling about with or without tickets. Zoom into the square on Google Earth and you see a crowd of people at the edge of the small park - that's the place. In order to purchase the tickets (if you have not done so online), you need to pass a chained entrance in the fence which is guarded by a soldier to get to the ticket office, which is in the Parliament building itself. Many people wait, expecting that there are specific times when you are allowed to pass, but we found that you just have to be a bit bold and ask the soldier to pass and then he usually lets you through no problem. At the ticket office, you are asked for a passport to buy the ticket – I think there are different prices for locals, EU citizens and others… but I am not 100% certain of that. But it is best for at least one person in the party to have a passport on hand. After buying the ticket you go back out to the “waiting area”. This is the place you need to be to start your tour, arriving 5-10 minutes before your planned tour time. You will be called by your guide and escorted back through the chained entrance to your tour. Best not be late for the tour time since the group all passes at once and disappears into the building.Our tour was on a Friday morning and we had an hour to kill before our tour started and luckily found an interesting outdoor food market under the arcades of the Rural Development Ministry – the big building on the right facing the Parliament on the square. Not sure if this is a daily market but it is worth the short detour if it is going on while you are nearby.One last remark - the tour does not appear to be handicapped-friendly. There are many stairs and I did not notice alternate wheelchair routes!

Imposing Gothic Building on the Banks of the Danube.. The Hungarian Parliament building is truly impressive especially if viewed from the Danube when lit up at night. The Gothic style building is truly a landmark on the Danube.

Beautiful building. Once inside, the interior is stunning. Personally I thought the tour was a bit short. Theoretically the tour is free for EU residents, but in practice unless you want a long queue (which you don't if time is limited) you have to buy a ticket in advance which costs about £10 per person. It is a major sight though, and shouldn't be missed.

Order your tickets before you go!. This is only possible with a 45 minute guided tour, but well worth it for 1750 HUF (EU citizens).Wonderful building with amazing internal decoration.The highlight was probably the Sacred Royal Crown guarded by two soldiers with drawn sabres, closely followed by one of the Chambers.Make sure you book online before you turn up. We waited in the pouring rain for 45 minutes before a guard explained the procedure which entailed queueing again and booking with a single, very fastidious clerk - not a quick process. The only tour left that day was with a Spanish language guide (we are English) but we took it and it was worth it.The airport-like security will stop you if you have inappropriate articles.
Sign up early!. You'll need to arrange in advance for tickets, and buy them early as possible since they sell out FAST.
Get your tickets in advance. We asked the concierge at our hotel to get us tickets in advance, ok there was a charge but it saves the hassle. Nice guided tour and you can take photo's inside.

Majestic building. Viewed the building from the outside it is magnificent. Wanted to take the internal tour. Queued outside in the driving rain for 20 minutes before we gave up, little information available, no one to ask. Perhaps would have been better to book online before we went and saved a soaking!

Must-do visit. I was surprised just how much I enjoyed the visit. It didn't start well with a lot of queuing in the rain for tickets and then having to wait for our tour, but it was worth it. Amazing building and seeing the famous crown of St Stephen was very special.

Get there early. A visit to the Parliament is a must when visiting Budapest. If possible take the 1st tour of the day and get there early. Off Peak get there ½ hour before the tour – Peek at least and hour. The key is to get there ahead of the tour busses that usually start arriving around 0930.

Wow. What a fabulous place. The tour takes about 45 minutes but you could spend double that time just gazing at the amazing interior. Our tour took us into the House of Lords chamber which was fascinating. You also get to see the crown jewels which are remarkable bearing in mind their age. Tip - book your tickets on-line as the queuing system to buy tickets at the venue is bizarre and takes for ever. You are then not guaranteed to get on the next tour and have to return later. Booking on-line save all that bother
A beauty. Take your time to see this building either by day inside or at night from the bridges or from the other side of the river. It is beautiful!!

Pricey for an hour's tour. First of all, you must pre-book your tour - numbers are very limited so do this on your first day in Budapest.What do you get? Well it's undoubtedly a very impressive, huge building, still undergoing some restoration. My problem with the tour was two-fold; in the first place, you don't get to see more than 20% of the place, and in the second, we got unlucky and had a tour guide whose English was so heavily accented, we missed half of what she had to say. It was particularly difficult for the Swedes and others on the tour.The whole thing was over in an hour or so. If anyone from this attraction reads this, you could resolve many issues by loaning a printed guide of the key points at the start of the tour. Get there by tram.

Great!. The Parliament in budapest is beautiful! something you have to see going into town! its right by many restaurants and bus stops. Right now many repairs are going on and they are cleaning the building which is making part of it pretty but you may not get the full picture (because of repairs) but hopefully you will like it!

BUDAPEST PARLIAMENT Cruisers Ships on the Danube By Zoran Slavic. BUDAPEST PARLIAMENT Cruisers Ships on the DanubeBy Zoran SlavicI went many times to Budapest. So I stayed for a while, and more often if I just went through this town on a trip to Vienna, Bratislava, Prague or a some German city. I knew that this large and prominent city of Hungary and Central Europe created by merging two smaller, barely separated longtime habitat. Of course it was a Pest and Buda. Therefore, it was not a little surprised when I learned that in all this unification participated and a third of the village - Obuda! However, it is more about the etymology, I would say, ethnic and linguistic story, but the existence of the third segment in the creation of Budapest. Obuda is actually part of the historic village Buda or Serbo-Croatian Budim: The name means Old Buda in Hungarian. The name in Croatian and Serbian for this city is Stari Budim, but the local Croat minority calls it Obuda. The name "Buda" they use for the fortress in settlement Buda.The island (Óbuda Island) next to this part of the city today hosts the Sziget Festival, a huge music and cultural festival. However, formally and legally Budapest has made the three communities. And all of them legal, legislative and monumental connects Parliament! This mighty edifice, on the banks of the Danube, it can be seen from any place on one side or the other side of the river. Any bridge to go sight you must stop at the impressive outlines of Parliament. I had the impression that me through Budapest continually monitors its physiognomy. It is located in the Lajos Kossuth Square on the Pest bank of the Danube. It is currently the largest building in Hungary, and the second largest Parliament in Europe. Similar in design to the Palace of Westminster, it was built in Gothic Revival style with a symmetrical facade and a central dome by Imre Steindl. It is 268 m long, 123 m deep and 96m high, the number 96 Refers to the nation's millennium, 1896, and the conquest of the later Kingdom of Hungary in 896. Construction was started in 1885 and the building was inaugurated on the Millennial anniversary of the country in 1896, although only completed in the 1904. Architect Imre Steindl unfortunately blinded before its completion, so never saw the result of his grandest architectural plan which includes 40 kilograms of gold.When entering the Parliament, can go up great ornamental stairs, see frescoes on the ceiling and pass by the bust of the creator, Imre Steindl, in a wall niche. Other statues include those of Árpád, Stephen I and Hunyadi János. One of the famous parts of the building is the hexadecagonal (sixteen-sided) central hall, with huge chambers adjoining it: the Lower House, where the National Assembly meets today, and the Upper House. The Holy Crown of Hungary, which is also depicted in the coat of arms of Hungary, has been displayed in the central hall since 2000. Further features include the stained glass and glass mosaic paintings by Miksa Róth. In the wake can be crossed with suburban railway, but I decided to move to the other side through Árpád Bridge or Árpád híd. From the top of the Buda hills I looked at the Pest, which is just getting ready for the night. I saw my first Parliament. What looked like a great ocean Cruise ship. What is strayed on the Danube.
Beautiful Architecture. This beautiful looking building is worth paying a visit to. It is truly awe inspiring and a great back drop for photographs up close or from the other side of the river.

Amazing building, shame about the size of the tour group. An incredible building, with some amazing architecture - worth a visit overall. However, the size of the English-speaking tour must have been 75 people, so huge that we couldn't all get into the Parliament Chamber to see the feature the tour guide was explaining. This was a shame.In other spaces, such as the impressive hallway for example, this wasn't a problem as there was ample space.Buy your tickets early in the day as queues quickly build. Remember your passport or ID card when booking them. There's a one-in-one-out method for entering the ticket office (rather old fashioned these days), so be prepared to wait a while.
Beautiful building. The views of this building from across the Danube are magnificent. I am told it is also excellent inside, but I have not had achance to tour it.

Nice visit. Had a tour in june. It was interesting even if I couldn't understand a word from the tour giude but my friend was interpreting to english for me. So it was very interesting, it is a beautiful place, is cool to see the guards doing their moves and marches around the holy crown. Stunning the view from outside, nice location along the Danub

Side facing river is now clean; back is being cleaned. We only went around the outside, but it is a beautiful building. See the side facing the river, and you'll see how beautiful it will be once its completely cleaned. The communist party did no favors in letting the buildings get so dirty and unattended. However, Budapest is cleaning up as they can.
Parliament. Beautiful building, great architecture, more beautiful if you get an opportunity to see it by night.

Being cleaned right now.... It was being cleaned when we visited so there was a lot of scaffolding. The view of it is best from across the river, especially given how little there is around parliament itself in the way of cafes..!

If it's raining, you'll get wet.. The english guide was ok, the interior is quite nice, but you have to wait outside to enter. If it is rainig, you will get wet. Check the weather forecast before buying tickets!!!

I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THIS ATTRACTION - UNLESS YOU HAVE A SLEEPING BAG TO WAIT UNTIL THE NEXT DAY. This would have been one of my worst attraction visits ever. I have travelled on many continents and many such locations. You stand in the hot sun in a clue to acquire your ticket. Only two people at a time could enter the ticket office quite some walk from the clue. They had quite burly men organising this process. It seems once you get a ticket you stand again to wait for the tours. I was very keen to see this building. We arrived over an hour early for the 12 noon tour (which is advised on travel brochures). The line never seemed to get shorter. After awhile we noticed people coming along and just "jumping the clue". The clue only got shorter closer to the cut off for the final tour of the day at 2:00 p.m. It came to my notice a women handing brochures for a restaurant was also assisting the clue jumpers. The alarmingly it came to my notice that this woman and one of the men looking after the clue were assisting these people. In other words bribes or kick backs were being paid. So after 2:00 p.m. we are told no more people when you have finally reached the head of the tour. After seeing many people "jumping the clue". I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THIS ATTRACTION - UNLESS YOU HAVE A SLEEPING BAG TO WAIT UNTIL THE NEXT DAY.

Breathtaking Icon of Hungary. You can't miss this. It is lit up beautfully at night. Would recommend viewing from Fisherman's Bastion after dark. It reflects in the Danube at night, the view is spectacular.
awesome. woo It is the most beautiful parliament i have ever visited. Take the englisgh tour, make sure you have tickets from the internet before you go

Attractive architecture.. We passed by and took some photos. A lot of work going on around it when we were there, scaffolding on one side. Our purpose was to find the Shoe Memorial on the river bank near the Parliament. Would be interested to get a tour if I went back to Budapest.

Amazing Parliament!. The Parliament building is an amazing piece of architecture inside and out. So beautiful and so much to see. Beautiful interior, many statues, paintings, massive Persian rugs, and some really amazing stained glass windows! Too much to really describe about this building. The grounds around the Parliament are very nice also. Large lawn with beautiful flowers. So much history. I really enjoyed the tour and got some great photos.
parliament. i think it is the most impressive building in Budapest,very nice at day, magnificent by night...absolutely number one for taking photos with all those lights

Great outside and inside. Even though the tour might be a little expensive, it's worth doing it. Inside you can see the Hungarian crown and jewels, and a few more amazing sites of the building, including an outstanding replica made with matches by a local family.

Beautiful! Nice tour!. Ask your hotel to make a reservation for you when you check in as you really can't show up without one and expect to get in. It looks just like Westminster Abbey and the tour is well done. The sights are worth seeing inside! Afterwards: make sure you go to the back of Parliament and cross the road (at your own risk) to see the Shoes on the Danube memorial. It is quite moving but necessary to absorb what went on here!!!

Interesting!. Great tour and fabulous bulding in side. Recommend booking tickets on line before you go as complicated buying procedure - just missed out on one tour so had to wait an hour for the next - but certainly worth the wait. Fascinating!
Wow..... We'd visited our UK Houses of Parliament recently and this place is SOO much grander, impressive....They were in the process of cleaning the exterior stonework which was interesting too.
At the Donau. The Parliament house is a very impressif of buildings . We went twice to see it . Its a beautiful building from the donau or from the street you cant forget it .
Stunning architecture outside and in. Excellent female guide brought the place alive, sounds a great place to work. So ornate yet it managed still to look stylish and not to appear tacky.
beautiful outside. Didn't go inside but the outside is gorgeous . Fun to walk around-the architecture is beautiful. Would have liked a tour

worth a visit. We walked past the Parliament and took lots of pictures and then decided that we would visit for the tour. Its about 50mins long and you have to buy tickets before the tour - give yourself at least 20 mins to do this. tours are in English, French, German etc. We went when the soldiers who guard the crown jewels were practicing. Our guide was very good with excellent knowledge and you get to see the equivalent of our House of lords.

A magnificent late Victorian nationalist fantasy. Well worth the guided tour from a very competent youngwoman this is a stunningly beautiful building - a must for all lovers of Victorian and Edwardian neo-gothic.

Well worth the wait.... Although its only a 45 minute tour and not particularly cheap, a tour around parliament is definitely worth it. The building is stunning and the guide very informative. Be warned though, we had to queue 45 mins to buy our tickets there as the soldiers are very particular when you can enter the building to buy tickets. We then had to queue again for our chosen tour...you need to leave plenty of time. Also, only one member of your party is allowed to go to the ticket office and you need some sort of ID to buy any tickets. We really enjoyed parliament!

Stunning building, prices to match. I can only review the area as when we arrived the queue for persons without a ticket was huge and i didnt fancy paying more than double which other museums cost. Absolutely magnificant building though and worth a vist on your way to the Shoes on the Danube memorial!

fun, but OK. the building itself is amazing, but i took the tour which starts at 10, 12 for the english ones and some later times which i don't recall, tickets were not that cheap for what you get to see, but still nice to see the crowning jewels and interior decor, but not as amazing as some museums with same price, definite take lots of pictures outside of the building itself and across from the river too, at night it is really nice as well.

Short tour. Very weird system to purchasing your tickets, It's a one in one out system and only 3 people at a time allowed in the ticket room. You have to queue and a guard lets you through the fence where you then walk across the courtyard to the ticket room. Don't expect to turn up 5mins before the tour is due to start and be able to get a ticket on time. Large numbers of people on one tour so you are hearded like sheep. Very nice and grand building inside, tour last about 40mins and you walk up the staircase, see the jewels and then one of the parliment rooms and that is it. Wouldn't be missing out on much if you didn't go on the tour.
Very fine. Well worth the money. Buy your ticket in advance (queue on the left) then turn up for the tour of your choice. Easy.

Short guides tour but very informative. Bought tickets on site they requested id which I wasn't aware we needed , luckily we still got our tickets perhaps it was down to been from the European Union.On your ticket your given a time if your tour arrive 15 mins before hand.After going through a security check your brought through a section of the building where you will see the Crown Jewels and where the current government conduct business.The tour lasts for approximately 20 minutes but is very interesting .

Beautiful and Educational. Took the English guided tour first thing in the morning. We had a wonderful time walking through the Parliament, viewing the Hungarian crown of St. Stephen, and learning about the political history of Hungary!

Amazing architecture, no queues when we visited, ticket office unfriendly, but great guide. The Orszaghaz is an impressive parliament building, but the best view and pictures is truly from the other side of the river, around subway Bathany Ter !!When we visited we could get tickets without queues just for a visit one hour later. The excellent French speaking guide took us around an entrance hall, a site where guards guard the crown (if you are lucky, you can see them changing positions with their sabres), some other rooms and finally the big room where the Parliament does the voting.The inside of the building is beautifully decorated with wood and marble. Visit lenght is somewhat short (around 40') but the price is not too high (around 1750 HUF).

Piece of art. Hungarian Parliament is one of the most beautyful buildings in the World. You can go in - with guided tours. I had attended one tour and it's very interesting I cannot describe the beauty of the building itself, it's - in my opinion - undescribable. Of course, when you come to Budapest, you will come and see it - it simply cannot be missed, like the Chain Bridge and Buda Castle.

Parliament. Me and my partner took a long walk around the parliament building, it's beautiful in its stature, being renovated at the time and being totally cleaned up, in the evening all lit up and looks stunning on the Danube

There is no more beautiful a building. A dream of mine was seeing the Hungarian Parliament at night, with its gothic grandeur and lights reflecting on the Danube. I was lucky enough to see this building at all times of the day and each time it was more beautiful than the next. We didn't book online for tickets to see inside (and the line up was huge!) but the outside is a masterpiece in itself. A great way to see it is from across on Castle Hill on the Buda side, or via tram #4 or #6. This tram takes you across the Danube and you can see the building from here as well. It is stunning and grand and elegant and imposing all at once. Take your time here to enjoy it.

Poor info = didn't get to tour inside. Really wanted to take the free guided tour (both have EU passports). Info on website incorrect for tour times in English. Complicated and long system to access and get tickets. Very disappointing. Recommend getting tickets in advance and double checking time of tour in your language. Also, it can be confusing where to actually get in to the building! There is a car park with a low chain roping the area off. On the right hand side of the car park/building, there is a small signpost and should be two guards who will hopefully point you in the right direction!

worth visiting and a great view at night from Buda side. In a cold and windy winter day , after some minutes of queuing to be able to buy the entrance ticket, we were allowed by the security guards to go into the small office on the right wing of the building to buy them. There are 2 types of fees , for non EU citizens (3500 HUF) or for EU citizens (1750 HUF) ID required. We joined an english speaking group (more than 50 persons) and the guide spoke good english. The building from inside is imposant and the tour itself is worth that money. A great view of the Parliament building can be seen from Buda side and depending on the weather either from the palace, St. Stephen church or just from across the blue Donau where specially at night and with the help of an stativ you can get great shots !!Enjoy the city

One of the most beatiful things human ever created. It is pointless to go to the Budapest and have not seen Parliment. With no doubt this masterpiece of architecture is one of the most spectacular buildings in Europe. From the outside size and richness of this building is breathtaking. I recommend to take a guided tour inside to get some historical informations (very interesting) and glimpse at splendid interiors which are filled with gold and marble.
average no acsses. there was no acsses when we were there due to building works there was snow on the ground and lots of mud so we walked past but did see it from buda side of river

Beautiful building. The building was fantastic with the guide giving a good commentary. Well worth the the time taken (about 60 minutes).
You now have to book tickets on their equivalent of ticket master for a £5 instead of free in 2012, still very much worth the cost but the web site is rubbish

Parliament. This is a must attraction to visit when in Budapest. This building is magnificent and the out side of the building was just being renovated when we visited. When looking at the building from the other side of the Danube river it truly looks gracious and great photo point. Really enjoyed visiting this attraction.

Breathtaking. The parliament building was breathtaking. I didn't take any tours that others have written about. There was some construction taking place, which blocked off walking around and in front of the parliament along the Danube bank. We crossed the river and viewed it from across and were able to fully appreciate this architectural masterpiece!

Beautiful gothic. Similar to the Palace of Westminster, the Parliament Building is in the Gothic Revival style; it has a symmetrical facade and a central dome. Also from inside the parliament is symmetrical and thus has two absolutely identical parliament halls out of which one is used for the politics, the other one is used for guided tours. It is 268 m (879 ft) long and 123 m (404 ft) wide. Its interior includes 10 courtyards, 13 passenger and freight elevators, 27 gates, 29 staircases and 691 rooms (including more than 200 offices). With its height of 96 m (315 ft), it is one of the two tallest buildings in Budapest, along with Saint Stephen's Basilica. The number 96 refers to the nation's millennium, 1896, and the conquest of the later Kingdom of Hungary in 896.

Interesting tour of an impressive building. We visited Budapest in January and there weren't many tourists around, so we had no problem going to Parliament at 10:30 and getting tickets for the English tour at noon. The tour was very informative, and the tour guide seemed quite knowledgeable about the history of the building as well as Hungarian history. The tour wasn't particularly long (about 45 minutes) and only really hits on 4 major rooms in the building, but they are impressive. Given that the outside of the building was covered in scaffolding for renovation, it was worth going inside to see how impressive it truly is. My only complaint is that it would have been nice to have a smaller tour group and possibly see a bit more of the building.
