Worth it, here is how to get a ticket. This building is beautiful, as the other reviewers described. Really worth a visit!It's hard to get in though, and I want to give my fellow travelers some advise on that. There are tours in a few languages, check the website for the times. My boyfriend and I waited in line monday morning at 10.50. In 40 minutes we only moved a few yards. We left. I got back the day after at 8 in the morning (thats the time the office opens). Only seven people waiting. When you live in the European Union, the tour is free. Take a passport or your drivers license to proof it. When you come back at the time you've got the ticket(s) for, you wait in the smaller queue next to the big one. They will come and get you.Enjoy your stay!

Book before you visit. Overlooking the Danube, the building looks superb.I was really looking forward to my visit and what I saw did not disappoint me. I had not appreciated that Hungary has the third highest number of members of parliament (behind Argentina and the UK) - hence needing a building and facilities to accommodate a large number of people.The inside of the building is both very well looked after and looks very good with a large amount of marble and red carpets. Although the building is very much worth a visit (inside and outside), the queueing system needs to be completely rethought. We were advised that advance tickets were not necessary. Having arrived 30 minutes before the first scheduled tour, we waited almost two hours to obtain tickets and then had to wait a further 30 minutes to be admitted. People were queue jumping and the ticket allocation process was very tedious.In addition to recommending pre booking your ticket, you should also bear in mind that if you are an EU national, you will be admitted free of charge on production of your passport.

Great building, from the outside. Its a gorgeous building from far away, and even up close it is very impressive. But it seems difficult enough to get into it. The queues are very long and seemed quite disorganised. Probably still a budapest MUST see though.

Fantastic. Astoundingly beautiful, both inside and out. The guided tours are well worth the somewhat long wait. Tour groups can be large, so keep close to your guide if you want to hear details about the building's history.

Breathtakingly beautiful building.... I had seen a few pictures of the Parliament building before visiting Budapest but it's even more magnificent in real life. I must have taken a silly amount of pictures from different angles during my stay. We were very lucky to see it come to life during the August bank holiday with lots of celebrations in front of the building. I was also really interested to find out that this is the 2nd largest Parliament building in the world, beaten only by Romania.Definitely worth a visit if you go to Budapest!

Only a tiny part of the parliament is open to visit!. No doubt that this building is superb and magnificent. I was overwhelmed to see this building every day and night from old town.But unfortunately, I was disappointed when I visited inside since they only showed us entrance hall after long waiting in the queue! Therefore, I think this attraction is over rated when it come to visiting inside!
Badly organized. Visits are only allowed with a guide, but finding that guide is quite a difficult task. Very poor information and long queing nder the sun for more than one our

Magnificent building. Wow! What an eye catching building. We didn't manage to go inside but if the outside is anything to go by, then it is probably worth a visit. It looks great from the Buda side of the river, but even better close up!

Astonishing. It's a must see for sure. The huge government building can be seen from many other famous tourist places like the Buda Castle for example. Marvelous both at night and during the day it's no surprise that this is the most famous attraction. Unfortunately, you can't even walk on the sidewalk next to it which is forbidden for tourists ?!
An other beautiful Building.. I did a tour of this building after having seen it in the Evening whilst cruise on the Danube, the architecture inside and outside is amazing well worth the visit
Fantastic architecture - interiors. Everyone should visit the magnificent building and when you see the building you realise it's symmetrical. It's a 45 minute tour and it's free for EU nationals.

A Stunning Masterpiece. Even if you are not into historic buildings you cannot help but stare at this building. We loved staying across from this grand building and were spoilt with the view for 3 days.
As you drive and walk past you realise the size and magnitude of it.

Largest Parliament Building in the World. This building is tremendous. It is the biggest Parliament building in the World and it is beautiful. It is lit at night and because it is located on the shores of the Danube river it can be seen when taking a boat ride down the Danube. UNBELIEVABLE!!!!

Impressive Gothic building. A huge neo-gothic style building dominating the Pest bank of the Danube. A better view of this enormous building can be seen from the Castle Hill. Free visits on the inside for UE citizens.
Such a great building!. One must see it personally!! During the day and by night... it is marvellous!! So huge... and white gargoyles.

Beautiful. We didn't go in, but the architecture on the outside is stunning. Check it out from the chain bridge. Better yet, take one of the last river cruises tied to bus tours -- we did one at 10 o'clock at night and the Parliament was lit up with warm yellow light.

Most beautiful thing in Budapest. What an amazing blaze of color. The stained glass windows actually looked like real curtains by the way they angled the glass. Everything was amazing. We got to step on this ancient rug, see gold paint on the walls, the changing of the guard that was guarding St. Stephens crown. This is the most beautiful sight from the Danube. This is a must see.
Great value. The English tours are 3 times a day and if you take your passport you get in free. Great history lesson, superb building plus you can take photos !

Great outside, worth to see the inside. If you want to visit the Parliament Building inside you should be careful, the opening hour to get a ticket is 08:00 and closes when the tickets end. So plan the day before to get your tickets early.During the visit you get to see the old crown of Hungary, in the room with the statues of the old kings of Hungary, and the room of the parliament. The interior is beautiful and during the 40 minute visit, most of the time you will be standing and hearing the guide.

No where else!!!. Nowhere else will you see a Parliament building as beautiful as the one in Budapest. It commands a presence on the river front and cannot be avoided. This building was my favorite architectural piece in Budapest. At night it gets even better by the awesome lighting of the building. I advise to see it at night and during the day, but if time is limiting see it at night.

Beautiful building. This is such a beautiful building. The guide gave us lots of interesting details on the Parliament's history. Tour around the Parliament takes about 50 minutes but before the entrance you'll stay in huge queue (I spend in the queue more than 1,5h).

夏場に並ぶのはきついかも. I joined the tour the Houses of Parliament on July 15 PM12:45.Parliament and the crown are just amazing with so gorgeous.I' was really enjoyed this tour.But things.I get a ticket, was in line for about an hour !!I think pretty bad and tour guide is too.End of tour, She had been greeted with a smile to the European was in front of me and behind European. I said “thank you” to her.But she stopped smiling and she didn't speak anything.

Very beautiful, but touristy. Visited the parlement today. Had to wait in line for an hour and a half to get my (free!!, for all EU citizens) ticket to come back after three hours. I can imagine that that would suck but as Budapest is such an amazing city I strolled down the banks of the Danube, seen some sights. Was great fun too.Then my visit to the parlement: absolutely beautiful! Not much more to say! As stunning on the inside as is the outside! It is a real extreme touristy thing though, needs to be said.
impressive!. i couldn't get in the parliament but from the outside it's really impressive, especially the side on the danube
Amazing. Architectonic marble, the Hungarian Parliament is the crown jewel of Budapest. Visit inside for the better feel and to see the real Crown!
Gothic Marvel. The parliament building is a gothic marvel and worth keeping an eye out for. It's right on the banks of the danube and the riverside tram passes right around it.

Only do this tour if you have plenty of time. If you only have one day in Budapest, then skip this tour - there are much better ways to see more and learn more about the city. The free city walking tours are much more informative.However, if you have plenty of time, the inside of the parliament building is truly magnificent. Its opulence is more like that of a royal palace or a cathedral. The genuine, original Crown Jewels are also on display and can be photographed which is a rarity.The Queue Facts:It took us two hours to get to the front of the queue and when we did our 2pm tour was solde out. Luckily, they had more tours available than were listed on the website, so we got a 3.30pm tour.No information is given out during this time, there is only one staff member who manages moving people from the queue (outside in the heat) to the ticket office (inside - there is only one ticket counter). You have no way of knowing if your tour is sold out or when the next tour will be.The queue might look short, but dont be decieved. Expect about two hours (August). You cant buy tickets for the next day.The tour is free for EU citizens, for an Australian it set us back 3,500 HUF.Bring some form of I.D.Once you have your ticket you can leave and come back 5 mins before the tour without rejoining the queue.Once your tour starts, 10 minutes is spent going through security, you then have about a 30 minute tour and then 10 minutes for questions and to file everyone out of the building.So as i said, if you are patient and have time to spare (going at 8am would probably be wise if you are determined to do it and dont want to use the best part of a day), then do the tour. Otherwise try something that gives you a more thorough history of Budapest, like the walking tour or the House of Terror.

Very interesting. The building is based on the British Parliament House and is of similar style. The tours are interesting though the area seen is understandably limited.There are two key things to note. Firstly, you need to get a ticket before the tour and they are limited so make sure you get to the ticket office when they open (on the right hand side of the opposite side to the river). Second, the tours are free for EU passport holders, so if you have one, take your passport along.

Spectacular building and free tour for EU citizens. We have just spent 3 days in Budapest. The city was very busy as there was a music festival on. Nonetheless we went along to the Parliament building at 9.15am on Saturday morning. After a 10 minute wait we had free tickets for the 12 noon tour that day, the 10am tour having just sold out. Just go to gate x and show your passport. Tour was in rapid Hunglish. The lady's English was technically good but with an accent and spoken fairly quickly. Sumptuous inside. Saw inside dome and inside upper chamber. Magnificent building which seems totally out of place in former communist country. Well worth the visit. Non EU citizens pay about 7,500 ft I think.

Parliament a twin of London's. Very grand building, lots of pedestrianised space in front, reasonable queues to go inside,BUT you walk around the perimeter of building due to renovation works going on

Long lines. We have been there at least a half dozen times, and yet to get in.
The lines are either very long, or the tickets are all sold out.

Wow.... One of the main landmarks of the city of Budapest. The neo-Gothic building alsways seems to amaze me in it's granduer. Tours are available of the Parliament, but I have never taken one. I have read that the origional white limestone it was built of, is slowly being replaced by a more resistant stone dure to the extensive damage from air pollution. Definately also worth seeing at night, all lit up.This is what I think of when I think of Budapest.

Tourist Trap - Non-Europeans paying for Europeans. First of all, we went in April - in a relatively not very touristy season. First time we had to wait for over an hour to get tickets and then we just lost patience. Second time we got up at 7am to get there at 8am. We still had to wait almost an hour to get our very, very expensive tickets for what you get. Apparently EU citizens get their tickets for free, while others have to to foot the bill and it's obvious because the tickets are crazy expensive for a city like Budapest especially - $14, more expensive than the most expensive European museums. The tour is disappointingly short and we felt like we got ripped off and our money went to subsidize our fellow Europeans. If you only include the time that they actually explain things to you, it's probably not longer than 10 minutes. Although the building is beautiful and history intriguing it was built only 100 years, by European standards it's brand new.
Nothing like it. I only have these to say about the Parliament Building: There's simply nothing like it. It's grand and stunning!
Spectacular. There is a lot of work going on to refurbish this monster of a building. Very special place indeed. Fantastic features, very busy when the tour bus arrives
Lovely. Lovely building, I haven't seen it from the inside but I've heard loads of stories about how stunning it is. Just seeing this building lit up at night, across the Danube, what a view!

Lovely building and free for EU citizens. we email few days before to booking three passes for the spanish tour. All the visits are with a guide, and at least in our case the woman for the Spanish tour was so nice, and with very good explanations of all the buiding.Do the reservation sending an email with a particular date and hour to avoid large rows. It is free for all the EU citizens but you need to have a ticket before entry.

Breathtaking colors inside. What a beautiful place to visit! This was my second time inside the Budapest Parliament, but it took my breath away the same way like the first time. I just absolutely love the way it is decorated inside. It is undoubtably opulent, but not in an overwhelming fashion. It is tasteful, yet grandiose. I also enjoyed the anecdotes our lovely English language guide shared with us. I wish that they made the ticket purchase process and the wait outside smoother and more efficient, but over-all it was very enjoyable and one of the highlights of our Budapest trip. You should not miss this!

Truly stunning. The parliament building in Budapest is truly stunning, breathtaking really. I took photographs from everywhere -- from Castle Hill, from a boat ride on the Danube, from the approaching street. A highlight of my trip.

Grand tour. On a beautiful sunny Spring morning we went to the Parliament early to book for the 10am tour, free for EU citizens. While waiting, we walked around Kossuth ter seeing the eternal flame monument marking the 1956 revolution plus the lovely Ethnographical Museum and Ministry of Agricultural buildings. The Parliament is a magnificent Neo-Gothic building with impressive statuary around it. It is fabulous inside and the accomplished tour guide gave a great presentation. It was fascinating to hear that for Nationalistic reasons in the late 1800s only Hungarian architects, artists, workers etc were involved in its construction, which finished in 1902. The great staircase and ornate ceilings and columns are most impressive. Some Hungarian treasures are on view in the central hallway. The debating chambers with their circular wooden seating are very decorative. It was interesting to see the numbered cigar holders outside the debating chambers for MPs’ cigars in the olden days before non-smoking within became the norm.

Impressive. Looks just great :). They do not deny it is copied from the Parliament in London, but they never forget to add, that their parliament is 1 meter longer :D.Tours are quite informative, including funny facts and contribution of many nations on the building. The only disadvantage is, that you need to book in advance (soon in the morning, no online booking or booking few days in advance), most of the staff knows only few words in English. And if you are EU citizen and plat to buy tickets for the whole group, remember to bring all the passports/IDs with you.
Great insight. Absolutely worth joining an organised tour (every hour I think) where the history and the buliding (one of the most iconic in the world) are explained extremely well. A must!

Spectacular. We got spectacular photos of the 3rd largest Parliament in the world, despite the part of the wing being renovated. I wish we could have had an opportunity to go inside some part of it though

Interesting history, but a little pricey.. We attended the Parliament today and managed to get in line and get some tickets after approximately a half hour wait in the sun. The first Sunday of the month is actually 'free day' for some members of the european union, so I felt it was a little steep when coming from another country, not part of the union, we were charged 7000 ft (approx $35) for two people! Never the less the sights inside were amazing and we were fortunate enough to see a rotation of the guard and some great photographs inside. TIP: All persons are scanned with metal detectors and all bags are also scanned. To go and buy tickets, all persons have to have some form of ID - no ID, no ticket. Tickets do sell out fast - tickets today sold out just before 10:30am for the day!

very well lit in the evening. we got there in the evening, so we could not get in, but we admired it from the outside. The building is very well highlighted with spot lights and you can see it from afar. Very nice, will definitely visit it next time i'm there!

The best attraction in Budapest. Budapest offers a lot of interesting sites for a tourist and the opportunity to chose what you prefer for the time you have. The Parliament is a must. Beautiful architecture to admire at day and night time as well. The visit inside is an outstanding experiance, but make sure to have a reservation and the passport available.
A real treat.. An absolute must-see, the tour is really worth taking the time. A note of caution there are no toilet facilities on site.

Impressive architecture and interiors!. Definitely worth a visit! Magnificent building with lavish interiors! The domed hall is amazing and the first and the oldest hungarian crown is kept there. The main staircase is splendid with frescoes and tapestry. You will laso visit the upper house hall which is not used by the officials now. A guidied tour in English is several times per day. They also have the tour in French, Italian and Russian. I arrived at 8.50 a.m. and there were only few people waiting, at 10 a.m there was much more people queueing. So, arrive earlier for avoiding the queue! The earliest tour starts at 9 and lasts for ab 40 min. The ticket for non-EU costs 3500 HUF and for EU it is free of charge. The best view to the buiding itself is from Buda side or from the river.

Now 3rd largest parliament building!. The building interior, exterior, and history are all a 5! The problem is you can't buy tickets in advance and have to wait in a long line to buy the ticket the day of your tour and may not be able to get the time you want. All the guides say to buy at gate X (10) and enter at XII (12). Those happen to be beside each other and are across the parking lot behind a chain and security. I recommend going there as soon as the ticket gate opens to get your ticket for the tour you want, then go about your day and come back at your tour time. Also REMEMBER to bring your passport or drivers license with you. ID is required to buy tickets. Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful building with a nice tour. Really nice building both outside and inside! With EU-passport you will get the inside tour for free otherwise 3000 HUF, students 1500 HUF. To get tickets to the tour we were there at 9am and got a ticket one hour later. the queuing system isn't the most logical. Be there early, this was our third day trying and we got tickets to the last English tour at 2 pm. The tour was for 40 minutes, and you besides see the inside you got a brief introduction to Hungarian history and their parliamentary system.

beautiful building. Free to EU-citizens upon showing your passport. Getting the tickets was a bit confusing. Make sure you are there about half an hour before your tour starts. People are let onto the square by sets of 2 to 3 to buy the entrance tickets at a small booth. Then walk back to where you came from and wait in the other line until your tour starts. You will have to go through a security-check (bag will go through x-ray machine) when entering the building. If you have items in your bag that are not allowed inside, you can leave them there and get a token to reclaim after your tour.

Beautiful, expensive tour.. This is a gorgeous building--both inside and out and if you're interested in the beautiful windows and the gilded interior. The tour was nice--it was 45 minutes of descriptions of the building's history, and a peak at the crown of the monarchy (bent cross and all). However, the tour was a little pricey and they expect you to be PROMPT for your tour--we were almost not let in and we arrived at 9:59 for our 10:00 tour! It is also a little obnoxious to get to the building (gate X, you'll see the line that forms as the office opens up at 8 am) early to get your tour tickets for the day, but it worked out well as our hotel was 2 blocks away. These are really small points, but still, FYI!
Most beautiful building in Budapest. We only walked around the outside which is beautiful and very ornate. The tours were recommended by many.

An Amazing Place. Any advertisement you've seen for Budapest includes a picture of Parliment and with good reason. It is magnificent inside and out. It dominates the water front. It's fantastic from the rear. And inside it is sumptuous. Getting inside can be a problem. If you go it alone you have to go around 8am and wait on line for a turn to buy a ticket for later in the day. A better way is to link up with a tour company who will give you a guided tour and purchase your tickets in advance. It will cost about $10 more but worth the investment.

Short tour, but crown jewels are worth it. They have several English (and many other languages) tours Monday - Saturday. I would recommend buying a ticket earlier in the day and then coming back...sometimes they will sell out of the time that you would like to reserve.The crown jewels are directly under the dome and are guarded. Neat thing to see, tour about 45 minutes.

oh lala - so beautiful, especially at nights. Worth going and visiting. Everything that the Austrian-Humgarian empire was all about is depicted in this building. Well I must admit I liked it more at night than in the day time since it is the only building sufficiently lit in the area and it really stands out. Do not miss it. It is especially beautiful from the other side of the river.

See it at night,. Probably the most beautiful illumination I have seen with the reflection in the Danube River. The Parliament was huge and beautiful; but totally recommend seeing it at night on a river boat or cruise.

no big ben. One thing we never read in any tourbook is that you can get there as early as 8am and pick up tickets for any of their tours. It's also really recommended, as these tours book up fast. The lines are long, even though the tour really only covers three or four main rooms. There are more than three english tours of this place too (as apposed to all signage and books that we read).
magnificent building. i was awed to know that the British Parliament building in London actually has a twin in hungary only with a twist, in UK, it doesn't have a dome.
Very impressive. The architecture is simply stunning especially at night. Didn't go in as it was always very busy for tickets but do try.
Beats Westminster. This building is a must see and hard to miss if you go on the river or up to the castle. Unfortunately I didn't get time to go inside but the outside was amazing.
Nice place but unconfortable waiting. Very nice guided tour, with a girl who spoke a perfect spanish. But we were supposed to wait outside in a very hot sunny weather uncovered.
Must see. An amazing building, get tickets early since they tend to sell out fast. We managed to get the 3pm tour, and it was worth it.

A very beautiful place. This place is really worth visiting! However, you should buy tickets in advance. There are different guides for almost all basic languages. As far as I know it's better to buy a ticket one day before but we bought it two hours before the visit and there was no problem.

We couldn't get tickets. We loved seeing Parliament from the outside, but after waiting for an hour to get tickets for an inside tour, we were told that the tickets were sold out for the day. It turns out the way to get tickets is to sign up for a group tour with a travel agency because the tours get priority.

Not worhting. We stayed more than 2 hours in the line, to visit the Parliament. The organization is really really bad. It was only one person providing the tickets. They know there are many tourists coming to visit it, but still, they keep only one person. There is no shop around and if you want water or food, there is someone nearby selling them, but it s a totally rip off. So, if you decide to stay in the line, bring the water with you before.Finally, we got inside and it is nice indeed. But we were allowed to visit only the lobby and two rooms. The tour itself is not 50 min as advertised, but only 30, and this because the guide is telling the history of the place. Otherwise, 15 min. It is very beautiful on the outside, but think twice before waiting at the line. It s not worthing....

Gorgeous view. No questions. This is the best object I have ever seen in Budapest. I watched Parliament from all the sites. It is beautiful from Buda bank of Danube. I strongly recommend to take a night Danube cruise along city of Budapest and enjoy the view of illuminated Parliament.

We finally got in on our 3rd attempt. You have to line up first on the day of your planned visit. When it's your turn, a guard will let one person of your group walk in to the ticket office. Well, on our first day in the line we couldn't get in, because at 2.20p.m. all the spots for the English tour were sold out. We went back earlier the next day, only to find out that due to an official visit to the building, all tours were cancelled that day. We were nice and early the third day and scored 4 tickets for the English tour. Mind you, European citizens go free (so my 2 dual citizen kids and I didn't pay, but of course we still had to be included in the headcount and issued a ticket); my husband paid 3500 Forints.The building and the Crown Jewels are beautiful. It was a relatively short 45 min. guided tour, but my kids were becoming a little restless towards the end, maybe because our guide was a little difficult to understand in English.
Impressive. I only viewed it from the outside, as you have to book tours in advance but what an impressive building!

I guess the most beautiful building in Budapest. The hungarian Parliament is a great building. I haven't been inside yet. If you want to see the nicest part of the building, it is on the river side (all other part isn't cleaned yet).

Amazing building; hard to get inside. The outside of the Parliament building is beautiful. So ornately detailed you could spend ages looking at it. Was especially beautiful lit up at night and viewed from the river. We tried twice to get tickets to tour the inside, arriving by 7:30 am the 2nd time, but were told the tickets were sold out; even though they don't go on sale til 8 am. We were later told that the tour groups are able to book ahead on line so buy out most of the spaces ahead of time. One of the workers at the parliament told us to book online too; but when we went on the website there was only a place for groups not individuals to book. There was an address to contact them by email, where they might have been able to give tickets to individuals, but we ran out of time so were unable to test it out.Even if you can't get inside I highly recommend you see the exterior.
One of the impressive buildings in Budapest. The tour at the parliament gave an insight of some of the Hungarian history and the building itself during day and night is very impressive.
Huge building, interesting architecture. This cathedral-like building is definitely worth visting while in Budapest.

Budapest Parliamment. The Palace of Westminster in part inspired the design, but a well-known Hungarian architect, Imre Steindl, laid out the plans in their entirety. The building stretches 268 meters in its length, along the Danube embankment. Ornamented with white neo-gothic turrets and arches, it forms the most outstanding landmark of the Pest side horizon. Statues of Hungarian monarchs and military commanders decorate the outer walls. The unique interior design includes huge halls, over 12,5 miles of corridors, a 96-meter high central dome, and 691 rooms. When the Parliament is not in session, all these can be visited (cameras are allowed but with restriction at certain places to take the photos); tours are offered in English, French, German, Russian, Hebrew, Japanese, Italian and Spanish.One has to buy the tickets early and there is always a long quque for the same.It give a different pleasure to see it in night in a boat cruise

Worth the wait in line for tickets. The Hungarian Parliament tour was worth the wait in the long line. Tickets sell out so you must be there by noon to get tickets. If you arrive early morning the line is shorter but if you arrive any later than noon to buy tickets you won't get them. Tickets are sold for same day visits. However, you can reserve to buy tickets online at www.parlament.hu. You pay a reservation fee and then you skip to the front of the line to go in and buy tickets. We didn't think it was worth that so we waited in line which took about 30 minutes. They only allow a few people in at a time to buy tickets so that is why there is a line. Cost is about 3500 forint (approx $17.00) per person. Make sure you ask for tour in the language you want and they will give you appointment time to come back for your tour. Take an umbrella with you in the summer as there is no shelter area to wait in line and it is HOT. Umbrella will help keep you cooler. Inside it is beautiful. Be sure to watch the changing of the guards - it is really neat. This event take place each hour. The guards are their to secure the area that holds the Hungarian Crown. It is a huge glass encased centerpiece at the top of the stairs. The crown itself is supposedly original and was sent by Pope Sylvester II to crown Istvan on Christmas Day in the year 1000. Over history, the crown was stolen, lost, and hidden. The US government kept the crown in Fort Knox between WWII and 1978 until Jimmy Carter returned it. The Parliament was built from 1885 to 1902. The architecture and carvings are amazing! It is both neo-gothic and neo-renaissance. All built with Hungarian hands and Hungarian materials. If Parliament is in session you will only see the House of Lords side. It is amazing and very worth the tour. Enjoy!
Great but not that great. Yes, it is a magnificent building but you only get to see a fraction of it... I was more impressed with some of the other public and private buildings around the city.

average for the price. This building is very pretty. However, the cost is about $15, and the tour does not last long, once you get past all the security. It is beautiful inside, but you can see similar beauty inside other buildings in Budapest. You MUST get advance reservations, and carry some sort of identification. If the tour lasted longer and involved more rooms, I would give it a higher rating.

Magnificent. What a great building. I'd go at night and if you can go up the Danube and look at it as well. What a cool building. I heard the tour is great, but wasn't able to talk my family into going.
Parliament Buildings. Amazing building can be viewed from high up on the castle buda side or from a boat on the danube or from the city bus We did all three.
really excellent. This is a really impressive place! Be sure that you would have a chance to see it at night - it is twice as nice.
This a must see when staing in Budapest. Experience history up close and personal. Take a fast lens for photos.
most beautiful building of Budapest. so many beautiful buildings but this one is definately the most beautiful one. did not visit it but will do next time

Really a masterpiece inside and outside. The parliament is really a big artistic symbol of Budapest. The visit of its rooms is f. Really a masterpiece inside and outside. The parliament is really a big artistic symbol of Budapest. The visit of its rooms is free of charge for the EU citizens but you cannot reserve the guided tour via internet or in advance. At 10:30 ee were on the queue for 30 minutes and we got the tickets for the guided tour at 17:00. But the tour is really interesting. I can only advice it. A visit is a must.
Impressive. Wow! What an impressive building, unfortunately you have to book in advance to take a tour around the interior and we didn't have a long enough stay to allow us to do this.
Awesome and impressive. Jaw dropping but with a bit of scaffolding which by the way is made of wood!
What an impressive building. Well I suppose that the Austro-Hungarian period meant this was one of the most affluent places in Europe ...and it shows.Take a trip at night.{2006}

Take city tour. Take city bus tour combined with this tour. You pass all the tourists waiting got tickets and go right in. Fabulous building and lots of interesting historical details. You are given free ticket for danube boat ride that was quite enjoyable with good audio guide.

Beautiful inside and beautiful lit up outside at night!. Worth the tour to see the interior of Budapest's Parliament, but don't miss viewing the building from the outside at night when it's all lit up!

Well organized and well worth a visit. I was a bit worried after hearing all the negativity about the ticket service, but my experience went very well. The process was very efficient, despite a bit of a line, and we were able to get tickets without any trouble. In addition, the building is free of charge to EU member state citizens, so be sure to bring a passport if you qualify. The tour is rather short, but the interior is very beautifully decorated and our guide was friendly and knowledgeable. A bonus is that the Hungarian crown jewels are housed in the building, guarded by four sabre bearing olive clad guards (a sight in itself).Definitely worth a visit in the city.
Parliament. We observed the parliament from aboat as we cruised the Danube, its a magnificent building
Very Impressive. We only saw this from the outside, but it was very impressive! It dominated the area and was very beautiful.

It's a short tour, you don't see a lot, but it's worth it. Taking a tour of the Parliament was a "must do" on our recent visit to Budapest. We arrived at 8 AM when the ticket office first opens to beat the rush. We purchased tickets for a 9:15 AM tour in English, and toured some of the surrounding area until our scheduled tour time.There were about 12 people in our group and the tour guide was very "bureaucratic", almost like a holdover from the times of communism. The building is extremely impressive, but you only get to see the grand staircase, the Hungarian crown, and the legislative chamber that is no longer used. That space is rented out for meeting s and conferences, and lucky for us we were able to see it. They were in the process of setting up for a conference and the tour guide told us that later that day it would be off limits. So, future tours saw even less than us.The tour is only about 40 minutes, which for about $15 US per person is kind of steep, but the interior is amazing.
Parliament Building Tour. We took a tour of this facility and I was amazed at the artistry and care that went into it's building. Be sure to check out the tile work and the stained glass windows.

The building that defines Budapest. Even if you haven't got the patience to queue for the (rather limited access) tour of the building's opulent interior it is still a truly wondrous sight to behold from the outside. You would need to be on the Danube side of the Széchenyi Rakpart to get an appreciable view of the sheer scale of this magnificent building (be careful crossing over - the traffic is seemingly non-stop and at speeds that would nearly sweep you off your feet). The Parliament is about equidistant from The Chain Bridge and Margaret Bridge so do take a look and be mesmerised not only by the bridges but by the majesty of the Danube.
Parliament in Budapest. This is a beautiful, awe-inspiring building. So much history here. We had to wait outside in the cold but it was worth it!

A must see in Budapest. The Hungarian Parliament is beautiful and a must see on your Budapest trip. The Parliament can been seen only though a tour, but they have many tours in many languages. We took the English tour. It is a bit chaotic getting tickets, but it is worth the hassle as the building is magnificent once you get in. The wood carving and the stone work are both lovely. While the building from the Pest side ( away from the river ) is average looking, it looks beautiful from the Danube and Buda side, both by day and night.

A wonderful glimpse at the Budapest Parliament Building. We took the tour of the parliament having seen this magnificent building on the banks of the Danube. With a British passport the tour is free but does need to be advance booked. The tour lasts a sensible 45 minutes and in that time you not only get to walk the main entrance staircase used by Kings, Queens and Presidents from around the world, but affords a view of the most spectacular rooms. The Crown Jewels are alos on display and you get to see the parliamentary chamber were the current government sit. A very well thought out tour that gives you a taste of the building but does not drag on for hours going into minutiae that would only be of interest to a historian or serious academic. Highly recommend this visit to the second largest Parliament building in the world with the worlds second oldest constituation, the largest Parliament building and constitution by the way, is England!!

The building itself is impressive. As a matter of fact it looks like a palace. Even though we had tickets (get them in advance), standing outside in line waiting for the last group to leave in the 101 heat was daunting. Then when we got in we found that we had to wait again for a tour person and another 45 minutes in scorching heat. We left!

Book Ahead. This is one of my favorite places in the city. However, there has been a semi-permanent sign stating there are no tickets left for the day.Try the tourism office to book ahead of time. As the 2nd largest parliament in Europe, it is well worth the visit. EU citizens used to get in free, but they are changing that to a small fee.
Beautiful architecture. I just walked around the outside but it's a beautiful building worth a detour. It's also a very nice spot by the Danube.
Breathtaking. This was most impressive during the day, but absolutely breath taking under lights at night. One of my favourites
Very nice building. Worth visiting: amazing mix of religious atmosphere and political functions...
Wow factor!. Gorgeous interior especially of the dome. Must see for every tourist to Budapest. Make certain you have a reservation and carry your passport with you. Security is tight.

Scafolding around the outside. Didn't go in Building outside is remarkable plenty of piccy's taken very large I was bitten on the ankle with a flying ant so couldn't walk far as it was far too swollen shame we couldn't take photos of the whole building together as you would get run over on the busy road we took whole pictures from the boat ride and the view from top of Buda
Beautiful building, showing also the Hungarian crown. Another must-see; if you have time see the Hungarian insignia - this is free of charge but you should have an ID.
Awe struck!. Transported from white washed building exterior to such indoor opulence and beauty! Well worth a visit. Couldn't stop photographing inside.

Looks beautiful from any angle. The Parliament building is stunning day or night. Two of the best ways to view it are by a cruise on the Danube or from Castle Hill. Interior tours are also available which are strongly recommended.
Beautiful architecture.... Beautifully restored with all the grandeur a parliament should have. Get a tour so you hear all the history.
WOW!!!. I did not go into Parliament on this particular visit to Budapest, but I have several times in the past and it is magnificent. It is definitely worth a visit. It is truly "grand."
Must see. Probably the most famous building of Budapest. Best seen from the across banks of Danube.

Worth it - plan ahead and appreciate that this is the Parliament. Visiting the parliament was a great experience. Yes, tickets sell out in the morning and the tour is short, but how often do you get to visit a country's seat of Parliament, see their most precious treasure (the crown jewels), and get shown around by relaxed and friendly people?I showed up on Thursday morning at 11am. After queuing for 10 minutes, I was let in to buy tickets. Earliest options were the Spanish language tour at 2.45pm, French language tour at 3.15pm, and English language tour at 3.30pm. I went for the French language one. As a EU citizen, I had nothing to pay. The Hungarian tourism board has a tent next to the line, distributing water for free and providing helpful advice with a smile.The tour starts with a brief overview of the history of the Hungarian parliament, and a general description of the architecture. You are then taken straight to the Hungarian crown jewels, arguably the object that has the most significance to Hungarians. Sure, it is not shiny and glittery, but it is significant, and quite beautiful in itself. The guide then takes you to the seat of parliament itself. Again, a very beautiful room, and obviously very significant to this young democracy. After a brief annecdote, the tour ends.In summary, it is a very interesting and very beautiful tour. Yes, it is brief and you must book your ticket in the morning, but I was grateful to be shown such historically and politically significant object and rooms - for free! Keep in mind that this is the seat of the legislature and you are being shown Hungary's most precious artefact.
BIG queues for tickets!. Beautiful building but crawling with tourists (obviously) and BIG queues for tickets!

Minimal tour of Building when you get in But def still worth doing. After getting a ticket to take part in an English guided tour through the bizzare ticketing system, I found the tour amazing and a little bit disappointing if that makes sense. I will try and explain..... When you get into the building, you really only get brought to 3 areas, the main hall, crown jewels and main parliment rooms. These were amazing but I guess for such a huge and amazing building, I thought I would get to see more such as maybe the library, ministers offices, other function rooms. Definitely worth getting into see, you won't see anything like the decoration, detail, pictures, architecture and opulence. It's free also once you are an EU citizen.

Could not get in!. Note that there are VERY few tickets available for visiting the Parliament. To visit, you have to stand in line at the ticket office before 8:00 AM to secure a ticket. You can only get a ticket for the same day, and the scheduled tours are hours later than when getting the tickets. Showing our passports was required. If the building is in use, the schedule may change, or tickets may be unavailable altogether.Even if you succeed in getting a ticket, the scheduled tour you have tickets for may be cancelled without notice. We visited the ticket office for three days, but we never went on a tour.
Amazing. Just to see it from the other side is great, but walking inside on a tour is amazing, get a tour that includes ticket to the parlament, staying outside in line you will wait for hours

Must Must Do. I did the Parliament Tour, which is a guided 30mins tour. Please don't miss this. Not many countries allow visitors in Parliament all the way until the speakers seat! One of the most beautiful architecture I've seen in Europe.
Don't forget your passport!. Guided tour free with passport. you can book on the day and English guide provided. Superb inside the building cannot be missed.

Parliament. Very limited tour inside. They only allow you in a couple of rooms, and you have to go early (by 8am on the day you want to visit) to get tickets for a same day tour only. Probably not worth it.

free if u can get tickets. if u are an EU citizen then u are suppossed to be ablke to get free entrance , i tried twice but was told u have to be there at 8.00am to have a chance , anyway paid to go in with an organised trip , was fantastic inside but the price £16 was not worth it , my advuce is to shop around for a better deal.

GORGEOUS BUILDING!. I would have to say that this is my favorite building in all of Budapest. It's simply gorgeous.The tour we took inside was a bit short, but the interior is stunning! Well worth the price of admission. Gold leaf everywhere, a grand staircase at the entrance, very high ceilings, very grand overall. I would recommend a tour of this building to anyone!

Be prepared to wait for your ticket!. We arrived on a day when temperatures were in mid thirties, and the square where you queue must have been way hotter there.they start selling tickets at 08:30 for the 10:30 visit and we missed that, getting there about 11;00 such a long queue infront of us and the next one was at 12:30 we could not wait an hour and a half with no shelter from the heat, so reluctantly we decided that we would not wait. The building was incredible, but a cooler time of year would be better to do the visit.

Horrible waste of time. We waited 1.5 hours in the 90 degree sun for tickets which cost us $35 American for two and then got a lousy half hour tour with hardly any interesting details. Of course the building is beautiful but I'd definitely take a pass on this unless you want to get up at 8am when the ticket office opens and you can buy tickets without waiting a ridiculous amount of time.
Wonderful. Lovely buidling and the tour was very infomative. The Prime Minister walked by as we were on our tour; a little suprise for us

An architectural feast!. This is a magnificent building if you can get in to see it! The line to buy tickets went VERY SLOWLY and once you buy tickets you once again have to wait a long time to take the tour. If you don't mind waiting an hour or two just to get in then to see this is worth it.
Could not go inside.... Unfortunately, you're not allowed to go inside this beautiful and historic building; at least not while we were there.

The tour was great. I got there at 8am to buy the 12pm tour tickets. When we arrived at noon, I found that all tickets of the day were sold out. I guess you should do the same if you want to visit there.The interior of the building was gorgeous , especially for a parliament building, not a palace. The tour was about 45 minutes long and I found it just about the right length.

Free tour for EU citizens and a postcard view from the river. Arguably the main attraction of the city, Parliament building is a postcard sight that improves with every step. Having received a free guided tour for over forty-five minutes, we were treated to several spectacular sights, all narrated in impressive English. One of the most enjoyable sights was that of the coronation crown which was saluted every five minutes - entertaining to say the least!
Good historic about this place. I love that they have 365 towers that mean the 365 days of tyhe year and in front of the Danube river is a monument about the shoes that have so sad moments.
Impressive!. Another must-see. Very impressive with a sobering message that communism and oppression do not work!
So beautiful!. The most beautiful buliding in Europe?? It´s fantastic and looks a bit like something from Disney :)

Get there the day before the day before!. I think it's such a lovely building. I lost count of the number of photos I took of it.You can visit it, but you need to be at gate 10 at 08.00 in the morning, and, even then you're not guaranteed to get a visit as loads of tour groups scoop up available places.Best thing seems to be to visit on Saturday or Sunday, when it's open for visits, but tour groups don't seem to go in such numbers.Otherwise, just photograph it from the Buda side.
Long Wait to get in but worth it. Take your EU id with you for free entry. Book ahead via e-mail or queue up from 8am to get a ticket. We had to return at 5pm to get an English tour. Great building
well worth a visit. the opulence and history is amazing tour is only one hour long ,you have to get your ticket early i9n the morning ,we went at 9 and could only get on the 12 o clock tour
Parliament. Unbelievable, breath taking,,a work of artistic beauty, etc, etc. At night it is even more spectacular.

The outside is one of the most beautiful buildings I've seen. Have lived in Paris and London, and visited Rome. This building's beauty and grandeur rivals any building on those cities. I miss not going in for a tour and heard it was well worth the time.

Be organised and you'll be fine. Ignore the winging about tickets. Like others have said if you get there bright and early at 8am you can secure a ticket for the 10am English tour. Take your EU passport with you and get free entry. You need to bear in mind that this is still a sensitive building in terms of security so you can forgive the prying eyes and slight air of suspicion, but it is great that it is opened for public viewing as the interior is a veritable feast for the eyes. The tour lasts about 45 minutes and you are taken up the main staircase dripping with gold and displaying iconic Hungarian figures. You are then shown the Hungarian crown guarded by two soldiers who could be mistaken for statues (this is the only part of the tour where you cannot use flash photography). Finally you are taken to the centrepiece and highlight of the tour the upper house chamber. A quirky little aside is the cigar ashtrays outside that members of parliament used in the past. The shorter the cigar the better the speech was inside the chamber and vice versa.
Superb architecture..... Wow!! What an amazing sight......enjoy! You must go on one pf the guided tours.

A real focal point of architectural beauty. You on prior appoint if you are an EU citizen can gain access to this parliment building for free. Otherwise buy tickets there . This is again one of the very focal and historical building s of Budapest. It is on the Pest side and tram 2 takes you right past it from behind the building as nothing passes in front of it as it would destroy the views from the Buda side.
Huge building. Large building, the best views of this building are from the river, you can get some great photos from there

Book Early. Sadly we didn't manage to get into the Parliament, tickets go on sale at 08.00 each morning, but seem to be snapped up by the hotel concierges the night before. You do get in free if you have a EU passport, but you need to get hold of that elusive ticket first. The outside of the building is stunning and well worth walking round.

Don't bother coming here expecting to take a tour. The parliament building is architecturally stunning, particularly from the river, and although not a 'must see', I did make the effort on three occassions to take the tour. On my first visit, during the morning, I saw the boards indicating that all tours were booked for the day. On my second, the same boards were showing and with no other information displayed, I caught the eye of one of the attendants standing on the other side of the rope. He quite dimissively tapped on the very board I had seen whilst looking in the opposite direction, showing utter contempt for me. When I told him that I could see the board but wanted more information he said that it was not possible to book a tour but the next available tours were at 8am and 4pm the following day.I did return a few days later only to see that due to official business, parliament tours were not available. What I cannot understand is the total lack of information available to visitors when it is quite clearly a major attraction.

Worth to wait for the tour. If you're UE citizen, the tour is free, but you have to wait on the line to get the ticket. I reccomend to get there at 7:30 in the morning, because the english guided tours are at 10, 12 and 14, and if you're coming at 7:30 you will not wait too long to get the tickets. Don't forget your passport! The building is amazing from outside and from inside as well, the guide tour was very informative and the best part of it is that you can see the Holy Crown of Saint Stephen (you are allowed to take pictures, but with no flash).

Impressive. This building is impressive apparently it is larger than the UK Parliament and in a far better location, it is lit up at night so definately worth a visit at night as well and the shoes on the Danube is not far from here.
Looks even more awesome from a river boat!. An amazing building that is even better when seen from the river, and also from the Castle, one to put on your not to miss list.
Best view!!!!. The best view of the parlament is frome the opposite site of the Danube!

A great walk. Haven't been inside, but from wherever you are staying in central Pest, the walk down to the beautiful Parliament buildings should be the first thing you do. Then find some great food and drink closer to the Cathedral or go party on Margarit Island.
Amazing place. Anazing place from every side you can takes non stop photos even in the river for the place
Wonderful interior. A wonderful place to visit - interior was glinting with goldleaf. Entry free on sunday.
Spectacular building. This building is an excellent example of fantastic architecture and well worth going to visit. Looks even more awesome on an evening all lit up.

Beautiful from the outside. Europeans can get in free, but should make reservations. Non-Europeans have to pay. Apparently there are not many rooms that one can visit. So looking at the building from the Danube or from the Buda side is more than enough.

Nice building - no tickets. Don't bother trying to understand how to get in - we really couldn't go in. Maybe groups have a better lack than us because there were visitors going in. We went there on two consecutive days and were refused entrance. The internet site also says something about sending a letter (???). Unfortunately couldn't figure out how to make sense of the ticket system - are they bribed or something? We couldn't figure this out.Anyway, the building is really nice but don't waste your time with people who don't speak English and are clearly not customer/citizen-oriented...

A mix of European history & architecture.. A wonderful building with an excellent guide. A little bureaucratic to obtain tickets - queue up at 8 in the morning, though I understand you can apply on-line in advance.

Pretty Building. It is difficult to get in here, and a bit unpredictable. We arrived one morning, and all the tickets for that day were already gone. The following day, we showed up, waited 2 hours, then got a free (albeit) short tour. We did get to see the crown in the center of the building, which was beautiful.
Very interesting to see amongst the crowds. It was very hot and busy so more than anything it was a respite from the crowds - but worth a visit anyway.

Great tour - they need to do something about their complicated ticket system. Ticket system was a bit weird. The website clearly stated 3 tours in English daily at 10am, 12pm, 2pm. We heeded the advice of someone on TA and got there just before 8am. There were about 6 people in the queue, some waiting for multiple tickets for friends etc. There seems to be a permanent sign saying no tickets available for that day. Please ignore this. At 8am, a worker came and allowed 2 people into the ticket office. When they emerged, he allowed another 2 and so on. We got into the ticket office about 8.18 and were told there were only tickets available for the 8.45am tour! I asked about later tours and was told there was none. Fortunately we were able to do the 8.45am which worked out better as it meant we didn’t have to leave and come back. The American guy in front of us had to buy his tickets (ours were free with EU passport) but wasn’t sure he could get back to the hotel to get his daughter and make it back in time for the tour. It seems he didn’t make it as I didn’t see him on the tour.Anyway, once you’ve got your ticket the interior of the building is impressive. Our tour guide, Livia, was a friendly lady very knowledgeable in all things relating to the history of the building and the Hungarian government. Tour lasted about 45-50 mins and you can ask questions as you go.If you get the chance, also view the building from the river. We did so on a day cruise and a night cruise – it’s gorgeous when lit up. Now, I’ll go see how easy it is to arrange a tour of Westminster….

don't do the tour. Tickets to the tour were sold out when we got there. We planed to go back the next day and our concierge said don't bother so we didn't. Gorgeous building on the outside. We tried to walk along the river to get to it and realized we couldn't cross over the highway so must enter from a specific side.

Must see. This place is amazing. The key is to get there early for tickets to the English Tour. The first tour is at 10 am. You need to get there at 8 am according to the guard. I believe there are tours in English 10, 12, and 2. We got there at 1 pm and the 2:00 tour was sold out. We went to the Spanish Tour which worked out well since we speak some spanish. I would go even if you have to go in a language you dont understand. Its the best sight in the town.

Stunning. Loved the actual tour, it is beautiful inside. Poor organization for people lining up for tickets. There is nobody to talk to and no one knows exactly what is going on. If you hold an EU passport, remember to bring it along as you get in for free.

plan ahead. We went to get tickets for the Parliament tour and found signs that told what time each tour would begin according to the language. We had missed the English one so we decided to try to get tickets for the next day. After some waiting at the fenced off area, trying to get the attention of several men standing nearby to make sure no one come in, we gave up and left. We went back early the next day, thinking we would get tickets for later that day. We had the same challenge in trying to get in to get tickets. The men standing near the entrance would not attend to us. Finally, one came over and said all the tickets were gone. I later overhead someone say that tickets could be obtained by going on line. We ran out of time and never ended up seeing the inside of parliament. From the outside, the building is incredibly beautiful. It is also spectacular at night.

Beautiful architecture. This building is a walk back through time. It sarchitecture was brilliant and very gothic. Lights surrounding teh building really lit it up to the best quality. I never went inside as we were heading a different direction and on a time scale, but will be next time im in Budapest
GREAT. Fantastic building. I didn't go inside...but the outside is beautiful
Visit at Night. Beautiful old building that is lighted so beautifully at night. Right now one side is covered with wooden scaffolding. It looks like toothpicks. Be sure to go at night.

Worth the early morning queue. Free with EU passport - take it with you. Only very limited tickets which can't be per booked unless you pay for a group guided tour. Trick is to get there at 0730-0745 that morning, start queuing behind the section of fence labelled "for buying tickets" at gate X. Only 2 or 3 English tours a day, prob only each 50 people. They let you through the fence 4-5 people at a time and you walk across to the ticket office. They give you a ticket with a specified time on it, then just before that time come back to the section of the fence labelled "have ticket" which is just to the right of the section to buy the ticket. A guard will open the fence at that time, then you have to go through x-ray. Tour last about 45 mins. Very beautiful and ornate inside. Can take photos. By the way if you arrive early in the morning at 7.30am and the sign by the buying tickets says "no tickets let for today" don't necessarily believe it, as today they had just not turned the sign around from the day before, and I got a ticket. Highly recommended if you have time, but the ticketing system is a real pain!

Unclear on access. When we arrived, there was a sign saying there were no tours that day. Yet there were people everywhere. Our guide talked her way in and emerged with tickets for us. She had they often close tickets to foreigners to make sure that Hungarians get access (fair enough). I am sure that without a guide we'd never see the interior, which was fabulous. And a guide is a necessity to learn all about the details.

The greatest monument in Budapest. The Parliament is the greatest monument in Budapest absolutly amazing for inside and outside. To visit the inside you need to go soon because they only sell tickets for a short period in the morning. To see the outside and take great pictures I recomend the view in the other side of the river.
Wow. Saw it during the day the sculptures were amazing. Then sailed past it at night just as it was all lit up an unforgettable sight.

Budapest Parliament. Few government buildings can be as beautiful as the Hungarian Parliament Building, modeled after the Parliament Buildings in London. It is fascinating to tour, but also interesting to walk around on the outside as well. Sitting along the Danube, it is lit up at night, and provides endless photo ops, either night or night. There is also a number of significant buildings or points of interest in the square or area immediately surrounding Parliament, such as Szabadsag Square with the Reagan Statue, the state of Nagy Imre, the Eternal Flame, and the Ethnographic Museum. Visitors to Budapest should, in the very least, visit the outside of this beautiful and significant building.

Best architecture in Budapest. The Parliament is the one building you really must see in Budapest. It looks stunning from up close and even better when sees from a boat on the Danube or from the Castle Hill.

beautiful.... most fascinating building. The architect has done justice. The best parliament building I have seen so far. The adjoining library building and the ministry building across the street built on the designs of the loosing competing architects are equally impressive.
Wow. Puts Scottish Parlianment to shame. What a stunning piece of architecture. Best viewed from Citadella, Buda Castle or Parliament.

Pre book tickets and take your EC passports. Ticket office opens at 0800am ; advise get there 15 mins earlier with your passports - you can choose 3 timed visits for that day and select the language - for EC citizens with passports its free. Quite outstanding inside; and limited photo opportunities without using flash. This is a must do.
The most beautiful building in Budapest. Majestic, over-decorated ostentatious building... The best view (pictures) of it is from the Castle Hill on the other side of river Danube.

Magnificent building. Best views of this building are from the Buda side of the Danube. On a sunny day, in the late afternoon the building is bathed in glorious sunshine which makes it look like it's covered in gold leaf.

Don't let the sign telling you no tickets for today fool you.. We had reservations to tour the Parliament but because of a conflict could not make our day or time. My husband ran over (literally - he likes to run) early the next morning to see if we could get tickets for that day (or possibly the next). He saw the sign that said there were no more tickets available....usually he would have just left and not pursued it. However, since he thought maybe he could get tickets for the next day he stayed in line and when he got to the window they said no, you can only get tickets for that day. He said, well the sign says your tickets are all gone, they said, no we have tickets for today. He said that many people in line, when they saw the sign, turned around and left. Please, if you don't have tickets go through the line and chances are good that you can get them for that day. It is worth going on the tour to see the beautiful inside of the building.

Tours sell out quickly.. From the outside, this is a stunning bulding and I highly recomment viewing by day and at night when it is all lit up. It looks amazing. Regarding the tour, the guide book we had did not mention about booking tickets in advance so when we turned up we were unable to go on the tour as it was sold out for the day. From reading others comments, it seems the ticketing system is not very practical.

Great view. Marvellous to see from the outside, but it turned out to be impossible to get in to see the inside. This was due to very weird management of buying tickets. But the building looks marvellous from the outside, especially lit up at night from the river side.

incredible architecture. I wasn't able to go on the tour, but just walking around the outside of the building is impressive. I also highly recommend taking a river cruise at night, when the building is all lit up - quite beautiful.

Beautiful Building but Tickets go fast!. This Parliament building must be quite the place to actually work in. gold, gold and more gold. We took the45 minute tour which was very informative. YOU CANNOT PURCHASE TICKETS A DAY IN ADVANCE, SO YOU NEED TO GET THERE BY 8 am ON THE DAY YOU WANT TO VISIT. TICKETS SELL OUT FAST! A Budapest visit must.
Amazing!. To short of a tour in this absolutely stunning parliamentbuildning. Get a guided tour in english or other language - a must when you get to Budapest!

Unbelievable structure!. If you go to Budapest you cannot miss the huge Parlliament Building. It is situated on the Pest side on the river. It is very beautiful and probalby one of the most photographed sites in Budapest.
wonderfull gothic building. very photogenic. understand that they do tours inside, but didn't have time

Good tour tickets hard to come by. We went to get tickets at 11 am andp were told to comeback the next day. When we returned at 9am we had the choice of just 5 or 6 pm. The tour was very worthwhile, free to EU citizens. Beautiful gothic building with impressive stairways and interior.
Reserve Before You Go. So interesting. it is worth the time to visit. But if you don't get there early you may not get in. Our guide got the reservations for the tickets so we didn't wait too long.
Fabulous Building. The architecture was magnificent. The tour was informative. And, we got in for free that day!

Confusing ticket situation.. I arrived at about 8:30 AM to wait in line for an afternoon tickets. I was told that tickets were sold out for the day, but that we could get them on the internet. Checking their website, it very clearly says for individuals to purchase their tickets at the gate. I think they give out most of their tickets to tour groups - they really need a better system.

Parliament tour. The Parliament building is worth to be seen, even if the tour is very short (40 mins?) and covering only a small wing of the whole palace. The English guides are a little boring and not entertaining. It would've been great to have a quiet walk instead of a rush with the group. It was great to see the old Hungarian Crown.
central. Not to be missed ground views outside parliament, also from the river and across from Buda day and night
magnificent. You think that is from fairytale.You dont believe that is parliament. Amazing from ground level but even better from another side of the river.
It's free. Tour was free for EU citizens with a guide who had an obvious pride in the building. Doesn't take long but definitely worth fitting in.
Parliament. Amazing building from ground level but even better from the river

Nice and worth it. It dominates the skyline. You can't take your eyes off of it. Built in 1896. Elegant Neo Gothic design is more than beautiful. Many don't like the mixture of styles with the addition of the renaissance dome. A great view is from across the Danube. If you have a chance to go inside do so. It won't take too long and you will enjoy the jewels. An elegant entryway, the legislative chamber, the Hungarian Crown under the ornate dome. Don't use you flash when taking pictures of the crown or you will be reminded strongly to not do that. The crown is guarded by two guards who don't ever seem to blink.

To get a ticket you need patience. May 1st week-end so alot of visitors but you have to queue up once to get a ticket (at least 1 -2 hours) and then you are given a time of visit and maybe only the next day ... we gave up. Advice is to skip breakfast and get in the queue first thing !
very big building. it is a very important building in hungarian history and there we can found the imperial throne with guardians around it.

don't try if you don't book in advance. The parliament is a beautiful building.However, if you want to visit it, book on the website otherwise you've nearly no chance. We went there at 10am the first day and it was too late. So we decided to go for the opening of the cashier at 8am the next morning... it was too late as well because the groups take all the bookings. very disappointing..

Well worth walking around the whole structure. Don't just admire it from the front across the river. Go across the bridge and explore around it. There are nice gardens as well. I don't think it's necessary to get inside. This huge imposing structure is better appreciated outside
Budapest's most stunning buildning. Budapest's most stunning buildning but it looks best from a distance, for example from Castle hill. Up close, it loos pretty old and damaged. Never went inside.

Didn't get in!. Tours at 10am, 12 and 2pm in English wer advertised. We turned up at 9am and all the tickets for the day had gone. This was our last day so we didn't get to see the building. If tickets are this scarce there should be some warning - however they are available on the day from 8am so if you want to go, you need an early start.

Don't blink. I would consider this tour a "must", although the method for buying tickets is antiquated. The building is quite beautiful, and although the tour only goes through a very small portion of it, the tour is informative about the system of government and the tour includes the chamber where Parliament meets.

Book tickets by email !!!. The building itself is stunning and it's worth a visit. You can only see inside with a guided tour. if you can, book the tickets by email, than go to the room X and buy your tickets (only one person at once can enter this room to buy the tickets, do not forget identity card or passport). If you do not book the tickets by email, then you have to do 2 hours queue and run the risk to arrive to the room X when all tickets for that day are sold out.The guided tours last 30 minutes, they are available in several languages.Anyway, the building inside is spectacular and it is possible to take pictures without flash.Entrance is absolutely free for EU citizens.

Great building. It was awesome Barok Arcitecture buldingAnd enviroment was so greatfulAwesome parks across of the street and lovely BarsGreat parking area for carsIt was awesome Barok Arcitecture buldingAnd enviroment was so greatfulAwesome parks across of the street and lovely BarsGreat parking area for cars
not too godd as london. this building from outside at night very pretty but very different better than london... so you must try to compare it
Book tickets in advance to visit inside. We only managed to see outside as tickets were sold out, but it is amazing architecture.
Viewed from the Danube. What a fantastic piece of architecture - especially when viewed from a boat on the Danube. This will be on my itinerary to visit (if possible) on my next visit.
Impressive. This structure is best viewed from the Buda side, but it is impressive up close as well.

Get there early. As there's always queues to get tickets, we found the trick was to get there just before opening time to avoid a long wait. Then go for a leisurely breakfast somewhere until the start of the tour in the mid-morning.
The building itself is spectacular, so it shouldn't be missed if you're in Budapest.
my favourite site of the city. Amazing building, lying on the Danube banks, where lit up at night just takes you to another time zone

Terrible queue to parliament tickets. Buy your ticket in advance, we did not! So we waited at first one our to buy it and, tickets in hand, lined up in the entrance queue, expected to wait for unknown time. So we gave up.

A stunning sight. The Parliament building is so intricate and stunning it's almost hard to believe it's real. I have some wonderful photos of the building taken from the river on a hot sunny day and will treasure them forever.
By night. It is one of the most beautiful scenes of a Euopean parliament, especially by night.
A must see. Take a tour, this building makes Westminister and the US Congress look shabby. You need to take a tour, as tickets run out very quickly in the morning

it's impossible to visit!. if you want to see it inside you have to be there at 8 a.m.
they give a fixed number of free tickets and when they are over it closes even if there are hundreds people in line.
absurd!

Perfect, but only outside. Beautiful building if look outside of the building. Excursion inside costs 10 euro and wasn't very interesting because of we can see only main hall, and session room and I can't say that something could impress me.
Fantastic building. Best view was from the river on a boattour. The most beautiful buliding in Budapest
Incredible building. Although we did not go inside, it was an incredibly huge building - and the architecture superb.
Beautiful. By far the nicest looking Parliament we have seen. Grand in it's size. Easy to get to. Views up close and from Buda are beautiful. We did not tour inside.

Much too nice for politicians. Through the concierge at our hotel we got a private guide. If you can do likewise it is worth it.The place is impossibly large and dripping with gold and ornamentation featuring Hungarian materials and craftmanship (another building from around the millennium of the Magyars).The place is beautifully restored and the Hungarians are justifiably proud of it. Beyond the big picture of the pure architecture, look at some of the details, consider the Austro-Hungarian context and you might also find this a very worhtwile visit.
Take a tour. This is worth the money for a tour. It's beautiful on the inside and interesting to hear about the history of Budapest.
A lovely building. Athough we only saw the build from the outside it looks magnificent,its architectural style is so different and put the House of parliament to shame
Fantastic building. A wonderful piece of architecture. Also lit up at night which is best viewed from Castle Hill. very much worth an up close view.

LOOKS MORE LIKE A CATHEDRAL. Wow, this is a really beautiful building, has to be the nicest parliament building i've ever seen! I didn't actually go inside but sailed past it on our boat cruise up the Danube and also took lots of photos from the castle area where you get a spectacular view of this building.
If you want to see the inside check the visit hours. Very nice and big building. If you want to go inside you should check the visiting hours.
A Must See. Very grand interior. Hard to image that the building is not as old as the US Capital.
What a sight. The best view is from the opposite side of the river bank.

Awesome Architecture.. One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen! Really gorgeous view from the Citadella if you get a chance to get up there (the open top bus is good value), but you can also get good shots from the bridge or a boat on the Danube.
Very very Big..... We just took pictures of the outside and done the danube cruise where the view is outstanding, But the queu to get a ticket was so long.... no way could we wait for that long.....

Take the camera. We took over 200 photos in 4 days - about a quarter of these include the Parliament building from every angle. It is truly beautiful. It took over a thousand workers 17 years to build and has more hen 2k of stairs! Equally lovey day or night.

Parliament. Unless you book with a tour company there is little chance of you getting into the Parliament buildings as tickets seem to be taken by these companies and individuals get little chance of obtaining tickets. We got up very early one morning and queued at 8am to get tickets (with passports in hand as it is free to EU citizens) to be told that there were no tickets for the day and there was no way to obtain tickets for the next day. The only way to obtain tickets would be to use a tour company at a cost of approximately 4500HUF which we did not do. It was very disappointing as the outside of the building was so pretty we really would have enjoyed looking around the interior too.

Didnt visit, but.... Hell, this part of trip angered me. There are no signs how visits work. Only two fronts of people, one with tickets, second waiting for tickets... but noone tell you where you can buy them or how many people they let in. So, after two hours, we left. Its classical pain of Budapest - lack of instructions for tourists.

Great tour, beautiful buildings, interesting for children. I did a tour of the Parliament with my 3 daughters - aged 5, 7, and 9.In hindsight, I wish I had arranged for the tickets through my hotel, as we waited an hour in the off-season. I'm sure it would be difficult to get the time that suited you in prime tourist season.The whole tour is about 45 minutes long, so very doable with children. The rooms are beautiful.I very much enjoyed this tour and would recommend it to others.

Sure this wasn't the palace. amazing splendor--right out of the movies of a castle--fit for a king. Matchstick replica in foyer amazing. Glad hotel arranged for a ticket as there was a long line and it was really a short visit.
Stunning piece of poetry. No wonder this is a world-famous site, it's beautifully maintained and a gorgeous piece of history!
