wonderful. Didn't get to go in due to Parliament being there, but it was still a wonderful building.

The most beaultiful building of Budapest. It is the most beautiful building i have ever seen; unfortunately you have to book the guide tour in advance and i didn't that, so i don't know how it is inside.

A beautiful building. This building was wonderful to walk around, despite the construction on one side which precluded us from circumventing the entire building. It took us awhile to find the entrance and when we did we found the building "closed for an event". Not surprising as we visiting on Easter weekend. At any rate, this is a site to behold from Buda and deserves a close up visit as well.

Long wait - do your homework. I had a wait of over an hour to buy tickets 3500 Huf. If you have EU citizenship it costs zero = bring your passport. The tour is guided and the tours in English are 10AM; 12AM; 2PM. The tours fill up- for example, I got there at 10 - bought my ticket just after 11 and got onto the noon tour. However, other folks who may not have gotten tours in their languages (Spanish German French etc) opted onto the tour in English so it filled up fast. They sell tickets starting at 8AM. Get there early & pick up tickets for a later time then see other places nearby to make the best of it.The building it impressive - the crown jewels not so much. Don't waste hours in line for this one - it's good but not great.
New Democracy. The building is very impressive from both inside and out. You have a timed entry which lasts around 45mins.

As magnificent from the inside as it is from the outside. I don't think it's possible to actually buy tickets to the Parliament on the day you want to visit, as we were there twice and tickets were sold out on both days. It is better to book with a tour group, and the tourist office can help you make reservations.

Awesome. You can queue up for tickets for a guided tour and if you show your EU passport entrance is free. There are English speaking tours at 10, 12 and 2 o'clock each day but you can only get tickets for the day you queue which starts at 8. Tickets go quickly so arrrive early. The building is fabulous and contains the Crown jewels which are guarded by soldiers with swords. It is the 3rd largest Parliament in the world and to quote the guide

Wish I checked TA first. Waited an hour in line trying to figure out if (a) you can enter without going on a tour (you can't), (b) how long the tour takes, and several other questions no one else could answer until we were finally let inside the ticket office. Once inside we were informed the English tour was full (could wait 4 hours and go on the Italian tour!). Felt a little sorry for the old lady in the ticket office who was bearing the brunt of some pretty angry tourists, who like us missed seeing the inside of parliament. Disappointing to say the least but I guess we should have done more research - be good if they had more information available at the entrance to the hundreds of tourists that visit without a comprehensive guide book or the benefit of tripadvisor.

Excellent. I love these type of tours so this ticked all my boxes. Best to book ahead on line if you can otherwise get there nice and early to book a place on a tour for later in the day. Tours last about 4 mins. Also tours are more difficult to come by on Monday's and Tuesday's because that is when Parliament sits so please bear this in mind.
I think they must have copied the Houses of Parliament in UK. You need to queue at 8am to get tour tickets. We arrived at midday and had no chance of getting tickets.

Impressive Architechture. It's definitely worth taking a tour of the Parliament building and I'd also recommend taking a boat cruise on the Danube where you will get some great views of the building from the river side.

Free for EU passport holders - bring your passport!. To book tickets you need to get there in the morning (opens at 8am, tours start at 10am - the guard at the queue told us that on busy days the tickets can be gone by 10am, so get there early in peak season). Location of ticket office is on signs around the perimeter of the buidling, so it is easy to find. There are two orderly queues - one for people waiting for a tour, and one for the ticket office. Remember your EU passport - then tickets are free! If you don't have a passport, you will to pay 3200 forints for an adult (about 11euros) - so it is definately worth bringing it along. I am unsure if I personally would have bothered to have got to the ticket office for 8am for the tour, but, on my visit (on a Friday in April) I got there after 10am and the queue was short, and I was booked on a tour for 12:45. Tour itself is interesting, and takes an hour including ten minutes getting everyone through the security checks. Building is very grand and ornate and you get to see the Hungarian Crown Jewels, guarded by sword bearers. The guide had a very dry sense of humour which was entertaining and engaging, and he dealt with some stupid tourist questions with grace and speed (such questions as 'is this the parliament building which the parliament uses?' and 'are there elections for the MPs').
River Cruise. Make sure that do take a night river cruise to see the best of the lighting, in particular the Parliament House.

Well worth queuing for tickets. Superb english-speakig guide of a beautiful building. 3 tours daily for which you must have a ticket (free to EU passport holders) Like us, you may have to Q in morning, to get your ticket for later that day (cannot advance purchase)

The tour is worth it. My husband and I took the tour of Parliament when we visited in January 2012. We would highly recommend it to others. The guide was very knowledgeable and personable and it is beautiful. If you visit on a day Parliament is not in session you will get to see their actual chambers. The stained glass windows are original...they were protected in the basement of the building during WWII.
Very impressive. This Parliament is by far one of the nicest I've seen in the world don't miss it

Impressive but difficult.. The Parliament building itself is very impressive but the process to getting in is drawn out and frustrating. Tickets must be booked in the morning, for the afternoon visit, which was something we did not know on our first afternoon & thus wasted time there. The next day we arrived nice and early, just to buy tickets, before moving on with the rest of our day. The Parliament Building interior is interesting, but you get the impression the guide is trying to hurry you through and for 1750 forint (not expensive for Europeans, but expensive for Hungarians) you would at least expect to see more things and have a guide take you around the place in less than 30minutes. Most of the building was closed off & inaccessible. Head off to the markets & Buda instead and save the money!
Viewed from the Buda side. Lovely looking building. Good view from the Castle hill.

Big and nice. It is a very beautiful building. We have seen it only on the outside and it is nice in the morning, and in the evening there are a lot of lights around it. It has a good location next to the others attraction and next to it, we were so lucky, and we found also a car exposition! It was really amazing. The Parliment is a must see if you go to Budapest.
It'll rot your socks!. Both houses. Hungary should have asked Amedeo Duca d' Aosta to be King in 1920 and retained a modified nobility for the Upper house.
Amazing building. Guided tour was great. The guide was friendly and happy to answer questions. Remember to get there at 8 am to book your tour for later in day. Eu passport holders free.

One of the most beautiful buildings of the World. This is the second most beautiful building of Parliament in the World after the one in London, even though, you can't see anything of it in this bad picture.

impressive building. guided tours of this remarkable building in budapest offer a great view of the country's parliament. standing as tall as st. stephens' basilica, the parliament building commands a impressive location on the danube. home to the original legendary crown and scepter of st. stephen (copies abound all over the city) a visit to the parliament is a satisfying experience.

A must see!. With magnificent exteriors and interiors, this is a must to see if in Budapest for more than a day. Be in line at 8:00 AM to buy tickets, no reservations allowed. Tickets are sold the same day of the visit, and it fills up quickly. Visits are guided, so make sure you pick the right language!

huge, stunning. Makes you wonder why a small country needs such a large parliament, but despite that, it's stunning by day and especially when lighted at night. A tour is a historical treat. See the Interior Ministry building across the street where little makers show the many bullet holes where young Hungarians were slaughtered during the 1956 revolution.

Free for EU-citizens!. If you have the time, you have to visit the inside of the Parliament. When you are an EU-citizen you can visit it for free! The best way to do it: go to the Parliament and then you can buy tickets for the different tours that day. Then you're sure if you can visit it that day or not...

Check schedule before visit. A great place to visit. Guided tours are provided at different schedules in different languages each day. You may make reservation online or buy ticket at the door (the ticket booth opened at 8am in the morning; first come first serve)
Beautiful building. Unsurpassed building, impressive artistic architecture. But a rude cop sent us away. Why can't we just walk past onj the pavement?? Maybe old time commy attitude?

Imposing building, with awesome artworks. Very imposing, but yet, despite being in center of town, very easy to find a (paid) parking spot at 100m (300ft) distance.
I did not enter the building.

Wow. I have never actually gone into the Parliment building, but from outside this building is spectacular! Take the red line metro to the Batthyany stop (plz excuse spellings!!) and enjoy the full view from the Buda side of the river. A very cheap way of seeing it!Another nice (and very cheap!) tip is to take the number 2 tram all the length of the Danube at dusk and see all the landmarks illuminated.

The majestous parliament. To visit the parliament, just to visits for day with a guide, we needed to stay in a que first, in the morning and then we made the reservation for a guide at 12 o clock. I´ve seen that it is possible to reserve the visit by the internet, but at the time I did not know that.It is a very grandeous and beautiful monument, with a 97 degrees stairs and lots of rooms. At the day we visit it, the parliament was working, so we just could watch some rooms.the entrance is very nice and we assisted the guard render.The guide was very specific and helpful, he answered all our doubts.The parliament was constructed at a rich epoch, with gold at the walls, and statues. The parliament room was very modern at the time.We enjoy a lot the visit, it is the beautifuler build at Budapest.
Amazing!. Amazing building! Its also a lovely area for a walk around and there is some great local cafes which sell cheap coffee

nice. Nice, but do not expect too much. Internal decoration are fancy (not surprising). You usually get a ticket for a certain hour so you can enjoy the area. Just very that the building is open to public same day.

Outside - amazing, Inside - disappointing. During our trip to Budapest we saw quite a lot of the outside of the Parliament building which was stunning. We saw it from the Castle, from the Danube, from a bus tour, from St Stephen's, so pretty much from every angle. Every time it looked beautiful and made us more and more excited for the tour inside. We knew that there were tours throughout the day in English so turned up around lunchtime one day to try and get tickets. A very abrupt and unhelpful guard told us that all tickets had sold out by 9.30am and that we'd need to get there at 8.00am to get tickets. After much debate - was it worth getting up early and rushing breakfast etc etc - we decided that it would be worth getting to Parliament for 8.00am for tickets. So, we showed up at the end of the already quite considerable queue at 8.00am. After queuing for OVER AN HOUR, we were finally let into the ticket office. The woman on the desk spent literally ten minutes flicking through a spreadsheet and then gave us our tickets for the 12pm tour - apparently the earlier tour was fully booked. Anyway, we came for the tour, which was led by a very strict 'school ma'am' who at one point told the group off for taking photographs when we should be listening to the presentation. In my opinion, it really wasn't worth the effort. Maybe I'd have a different opinion if we hadn't had to waste so much time queuing, but other sights - such as the Opera House and St Stephen's Basilica - were just as stunning (if not more) but without the hassle.
Beautiful building. Fabulaous building that the Hungarian people are justly proud of.A must see at night from across the river.

Architecture. Among the beautiful building near the riverside, you can be witness of a piece of history of the Communist period, where at a little square had been shot to dead several students during the 1956 revolution. There stays the flag that had been raised at that time and his history, also in English.
Just a bit smaller than our Parliament (Westminster). dropped a clagger here went on a Sunday and it was closed but a very nice building.

Great view at night!!. Never visited it inside, but went for dinner in Buda and must say that the view of the Parliament at night, reflecting over the Danube, is simply spectacular! Also during the day, a must see place in Budapest, spectacular building!

Beautiful Building (Book Before You Go !). Beautiful building and well worth a visit. It's free if you are in the EU. Booking before your trip is essential. Get there earlier than the 15 minutes stated to collect your tickets before the queue for the cashier takes forever.

Wonderful, you can not miss it!. After reading all the travelers advices, I decided to get up early and be on time. I visited the building in the middle of the easter, which make things more difficult when it comes to amount of tourists. I dint want to miss this!I was there at 8:30 am and few tourist where standing already there in the line. It took around 5-6 minutes to get in and get a ticket. My tour was planed to be startet at 10.15, so I decided to walk around and take pictures, since it was nice weather I could even sit in the garden right next to the parliament and read some history about the building. Time went fast!They open at 8am to sell the tickets. There are two entrances:1.- The first one is to get the ticket you choose language and time for the tour. 2.- The second one is another entrance for the tour itself. You have to be there 5 minutes before. You show your ticket and then you get in with your group.Before getting into the building you pass a security control (like in airports), this can take some time before all the group is ready.You are allowed to take pictures or film the whole tour, BUT the guide asks you to turn of the flash before getting into the Dome Hall where you can se the Hungarian crown. You still can take pictures but without flash.The building is amazing, with a lot of history and culture, you getEven if the tour last 40 minutes I guess is worth it. My tips:there is an announcement that says "no tickets available, sold out". Don´t believe this, just stay there with the crowd and wait until you get in and get your ticket!Thus, don´t forget your passport if you are EU-citizen (it is for free!), get there early, take a nice camera with the possibility to take pictures without flash and read some facts before getting there, this will help you understand and admire the parliament even more!
A must!. You must make the effort to see the 'Parlament' in Budapest.- it's free to EU nationals and spectacular

Brilliant that it's free!. Parliament tour is free for EU citizens and well worth taking a look. Although it is only a 50 min tour, it is very interesting to see the inside of the building, especially as it is so beautifully decorated. We got there at 11 and queed for around 30 mins for tickets. Make sure you get your tickets in the morning.

Interesting Tour. You need to be organised to get on the guided tour of Parliament. We were aiming to go on the 10.00 am English tour but by the time we got there it was fully booked so we got our tickets for a later tour. To while away our time we visited the Ethnology museum opposite which was a beautiful building but the museum had hardly any visitors! Would also recommend going to Farger Kave cafe which sells great hot chocolate. When we went back for the tour - the tour leader was a real character which made the tour quite entertaining! Well worth a visit - tour lasts 45 mins.

run out of time. we were able to appreciate only from the outside...it would have been good if they sold tickets when we were there....it was a holiday the first day we tried to see it so it was close. The following day tickets were sold out.....so we never saw the inside....the outside was beautiful specially from the river cruise at night.
Impressive. A very imposing and impressive building, fantastic for photos but more impressive if you can get inside to have a look around

worth a visit. Interesting to see the ornate decorations.Worth going if you have an EU passport.Entrance is free.Don,t waste money and book through a company.You can go on line and reserve your ticket. if I had to have paid the full price then probably not worth the cost

Worth a visit to Parliament. you might not be politically minded ...but ... do take a guided tour of the Parliament building. It is based on the English Parliament and is the most amazing gilded building with penty of fasctinating past and current history. Tours have to be booked on site.

Don't miss this!. A stunning building inside and out, but if you want to get in on an early tour, 10am or 12pm, you need to get to the ticket office when it open's at 8am. You can only buy tickets on the day, and you will need to take your passport.It is free entry for EU citizens, and different tours take place for different languages.

Stately - in every way. Go early to get guided tour tickets -- they have many a day in English but other languages have more limited offerings. Europeans students can get in free, provided they show their passport and ID. Otherwise, for non-EU members, the fee is 2520 HUF (~11.50 USD) and half that for students with the appropriate International Student ID card AND Passport (and no older than 26 years old). The building is amazing - inside and out. Gives a great picture to the opulence of early 20th century Hungary. As far as I could tell, there were no elevators for the tour -- and there are many steps (96 to get up to the great hall). Highly recommend!
Free if u are a European. Take ur passport or id card to prove ur european then take an hours tour of this magnificent building,book the day before to get a time to suit you.

Get there early if you want a guided tour. It's a spectacular building - a bit 'over the top' for my liking - but well worth a walk around. If you want to go on the guided tour you need to get there early. We arrived at 11.45 for the 12 noon tour but all the tickets had gone for the whole day.

It looks like a castle. When you look at the Parliament buiding from the Buda side of the city, you get an impression that it is an ancient castle. I took a stroll over the Chain Bridge in order to get to the Parliament, and took many photos on my way there. When I finally reached the building, I enjoyed in the view. It is an old building, very antique and picturesque. You can visit the inside of building rom 11 am. Don't miss it!
Parliament. This place is huge. Could not get inside though as no tickets were available on both days that I tried. Suggest you buy your ticket in advance.

My mouth left gaped........ I was there to visit many many years ago, but I can`t forget how interesting and beautiful was it! I was there with a guided tour, and I strongly recommend it to everyone! There is no such a time that would be enough to walk around enough times inside and outside and to drink in the view.
Very impressive building. A must see in Budapest. Worth going onto the river to get pictures of it from that side. It's huge, but you can't get very close, they have it blocked off.

Beautiful building. Well worth a visit inside for a 45-minute guided tour, offered in multiple languages at varying times. Get there early to make your reservation for later in the day. Americans pay a small fee for the tour, EU citizens do not.

Hungarian Parliament - a must see!. Very impressive example of Hungarian architecture set right on the danube. The only way to see the parliament building is by taking a guided tour which is available in a range of languages throughout the day. It is advisable to buy tickets early in the morning for a tour that day as they get booked up quite quickly. Tickets are free to EU citizens, it was a little confusing when it came to buying tickets, you have to ask one of the policemen to let you through to buy a ticket (you also need to provide ID in order to get through as well) they also only let people through one at a time to buy tickets (not sure how this works in peak season but it wasnt too bad in march)Once you have finally brought your ticket the tour is very informative and definitley worth doing. The parliament building is very impressive both inside and out and you can take as many pics as you long (without flash). During your stay in Budapest it is also worth taking a trip to the Buda side of the Danube and take pics from the other side to really see the whole sight.There is quite strict security before entering, similar to the airport but this only takes a minute or two.

Beautiful place, the tour a bit short. I would really recommend having a go at the guided tour especially if you're from EU, then it's free. The guided tours are in many different languages, English ones are everyday at ten, twelve and then at two. The parliament is beautiful both from inside and outside and you'll get to see the large staircase, main hall with the St. Stephen's crown and the former upper chamber of the parliament and basically that's it. I've had a chance to do a bit more extensive tour as a part of a law students' organisation meeting so probably there was the case. Anyway the tour is quite short, but it takes about an hour due to all the waiting and all security precautions. Well worth a visit though.

Interesting. The tour around parliament was interesting with a very informative guide.We just turned up on the day went to gate x and booked for the next english tour which started half an hour later.Well worth a visit.

Really Nice and Pretty. If you are an EU citizen, like me, you get in for free, but please take your pasport as evidence. However, if like my friend who went with me, you aren't, then the price to visit the attraction is HUF 3,500, which is a little over £10 or INR 800.You need to go at a specific time for the particular language guided tours, we could only go at either 10am, 12pm or 2pm for the english tours, the tours last about 40 minutes and its quite informative if not short. But you are allowed to take pictures inside the building and also allowed to take pictures of the Hungarian Assembly along with the Hungarian Crown Jewels which are on display.

Really impressive building - but don't try foot walk along Danube. walking path along Danube closed by Parliament security. Also air is really polluted by cars there. So don't try foot walk along the river on the Parliament side - instead of that you can ride a tram (#2 I guess) which goes along the river
Do the tour!. The guided tour is for free for inhabitants of the EU (take your passport), and it is fascinating to be inside this building and actually see the rooms etc.

just seeing from outside. we saw it during the night,it is so beautiful,so fine enlighting,a huge castle,a great unit for the capital. really liked it. everynight we finished our walk by passing and gazing the parliament.

Shame that they now charge,. I have always booked a permit in advance when taking groups of students around. There are many similarities with the UK Parliament so it is interesting to visit. This year an entrance fee was introduced so the students were reluctant to pay. A beautiful building from the outside anyway.
Impressive. The parliament is an impressive building, big and tall. If you go to the other side of the Danube, you can get a great look at it from the other side.
Another great sight. We travelled to many of our tour sites on a Sunday when they were closed. However, the outsides of the buildings are fabulous

Magnificent!. I don't know if there is a link between the outfit of the public buildings and the GDP of a country, it's really a reverse relation. This building is so big, so nice and so much oversized!You have to come and visit while in Budapest!

It's a fortress. Set high on a small hill, the parliament used to be a fortress in olden days. I saw it during december when it was decorated for Christmas and New Year. Apparantely i only saw the parliament from the chain bridge but had lots of time to admire it and click some shots due to the traffic on the bridge.
Full frontal view. Although in Pest best viewed from Old Buda to give best effect of frontage. Pretty lit a night. No 2 Tram runs around the building.
Stunning!. This is such a stunning buliding. We didn't go inside as we were running short on time, but at night, when it's lit up, it's incredible.

Very intricate Building!. The Parliment House sits prominently on the Pest side of the river bank of Danube. It is of neo-Gothic with some Renaissance and Baroque style. It makes an excellent Group Photostop. We didn't managed to go for a tour inside the Parliment due to time constraints. But make sure you drop by here as it is one of the most important attractions in Budapest!
See it at night. We didn't go in the parliament but it is an impressive building and is well worth a look at night and from the Fishermans Bastion area which also gives a fantastic view.
history. very ornate and the resting place of the crown septor and orb of the first Hungarian christian King, Istvan.

One of the most beautiful buildings in the world. Built in neo-gothic style at the end of the 19th century, this building is one of my all-time favourite - beautiful, delicate, yet has a weight, love its sight from the river!
Great parliament building. Excellent FREE guided tours. Check times for English ones though. Need to take your passport & you will get security checked/scanned before entry. Well worth it.
Incredible historic building. Be sure to take the guided tour. Be careful not to step over the ropes in the parking lot, the guards will go crazy
great building. Well worth a visiit to see the great architecture and views of the Danube.

A fascinating 40 minutes. As an EU citizen, entry to the tour of the Hungarian parliament was free, and it was a very interesting tour. Plenty of great photo opportunities inside, and a very good guide with perfect English.

nice to see, free for EU citizens. You can only make a reservation for the day that you go - but if you go the day before, and you sent an e-mail(computer is available on the spot), you can book it 1 day ahead. Strange way of working! Beautiful building, 40 minutes tour.
Beautiful!!. The history is so interesting. You have to make sure to make reservations online as you can not just show up and expect to get in. Some of the most beautiful architecture I have seen.

Nice inside. It's really a must see when you are in Buda. It's located near the river. The entrance is free when you are an eu-member. The only thing you need to do is to write your name donw in the register. It's really nice inside.
Picturesque. It sits on the river of Danube and it is beautiful inside outside. Sorry that politicians are ruining the image.
Plan ahead. It's worth going and free of charge, but you have to register in advance. The guided tour is in several languages, so if you know some of them you might get a tour easier!

Wonderful. Our hotel was opposite Parliament so we had to visit it! Tickets are free if you produce your UK passport. The building is magnificent. The tour doesn,t last long but is well worth it. Our guide was very good.
Exceptional atmosphere. Architecture, decoration and history in harmony, home of the crown of the KIng St Stephen.

Super free tour for EU citizens. You make your way to gate X of the parliament building and queue where it says "without ticket". You're let through a rope barrier (don't try to cross it without being invited by the security guard!) and go into the ticket office where, provided you can produce your passport or other photo id, you get a free ticket. The tour lasts about 40 minutes. Our guide was excellent and the visit was really interesting. Recommended.
Stunning architecture. Be sure to book in for this treat. I booked online and just picked up my ticket and was given an amazing free tour of this beautiful building.

Oppulence at Its Best. Worth getting up early to queue for tour tickets, only available for that day.The scale of the building and oppulence of it deccoration and stunning.Amazingly, photos are allowed everywhere.
Interesting place - great shame about the current lot in it!. The building and its position at the Danube is spectacular - just let's get the current lot of MPs out of there - help!
Well worth a visit. Take your passport for free entry and walk about, so much history and a very frank tour guide

good for photos. i went there on an evening walk , it looked interestingly let at night facing the danube river with reflections on the water surface, a good place for a couple of photos, you can go there by tram no. 2

Eye catching. Wonderful architecture, only saw exterior of building, had police in front not letting anyone close to the building, none of them spoke English. Right next to the River, its certainly a Kodak moment from across the river daytime or night.
Big. You have to watch it from the boeddha site and especially at night

One of the most Beautiful Parliments in the World. Great architecture sitting in the middle of the city. Can be seen from most parts of the city and it is stunning in both day and night. It is definitely worth queuing at 8am for a tour of the interior as well. A very informative tour of a very impressive building!
Most Beautiful Parliament in Europe. Stunning interiors and now renewed exterior as well
Very interesting tour. Exteremely opulent building, English guided tour, very interesting and a beautiful building.

Amazing interior. It's well worth visiting the Parliament building (free with an EU passport) which finished in the most amazing marbles and gold-leaf, including the crown jewels on display in the centre. Get there a little early to get your tickets before the start time.

majestic from outside. its an amazing parliament building, the walls are full of details and very nice picture background building.
Inside u can see the crown of hungary and not much else...free for eu citzens, lucky me, if u have to pay, not worth it. to enter.
fine building. not a lot to do its historic and its a beutifull building

Beautiful building.. We were not able to go inside but we saw it from the outside a couple of times and the best view you get is from the river cruse. We did it at sunset time when all the building are lit-up.
it's a pride of locals. And they are right... Architecture is great. Conditions of the halls we saw also great. One of the most picturesqe Parlament building I've ever seen.
Beautiful building at great speed.. Worth the trip - tour is free and building is fantastic. Tour guide full of interesting information but tour was completed in about 40 minutes. Phew!
Breathtaking building. One of the most amazing building you can see not just in Hungary but around the world. A must see while in Budapest!

amazing. Amazing building inside out.
If you are lucky to be nearby on Sunday don't hesitate to take a free (for EU citizens) one hour tour around the Parliament.
One word - it's much more attractive than Westminster...
A glorious building. A great looking building, but, kinda expensive for non EU visitors.

A beautiful building. The beautiful interior of the Parliament building has to be seen to be believed, and to get so close to the Hungarian Crown is amazing because it is such an historical piece and so very different from most European crown jewels. it is well worth the visit.
Under restoration. Like the government and country as a whole. Good to see.
Parliament!. Wow wow wow!! The architecture is incredible! We didnt go inside , however, just the outside itself is amazing!

Beautiful and Imposing Landmark Building in Budapest. The Parliament building is imposing and eye-catching, based on the Parliament building in London. The architecture is fantastic. One gets the best view (and picture) of the complete complex from the Buda side. I had booked via email to visit the Parliament in the morning on a specific date at 10:00 for the English language tour. However, I did talk to people who joined me on the tour who had not pre-booked and there was no queue to speak of since it was January and low-season for tourist travel. By the way, if you are an EU citizen, take your passports with you and you will not have to pay any entry fee to visit the Parliament. I was early so I walked around and admired the first and second runner-up buildings for the Parliament building which are located opposite it and used for other purposes. The first runner-up still has large round bullets in it fired during the Uprising of 1956.I enjoyed my guided tour to this opulent historic building. Information was well presented and the decor was marvelous.I saw the Royal gem-encrusted crown and insignia under a stunning well-lit dome, surrounded by statues of Hungary’s great kings. I visited the House of Commons. Saw a small contingent of guards do a march past into the House of Commons that was occupied by some members.I saw the Eternal Flame in front of the Parliament Building and took a picture in front of it.I visited the Memorial of the Uprising of 1956 which is located on the grounds of the Parliament building. The Flag at the Memorial has a hole in the center where protestors cut out the Communist Seal the Soviets had added to their Hungarian Flag.

The best place to take a picture the all complex you should go to the other side of the Danube.. All the structure is impressive a large complex castle .I got such wonderful shot of all details in the facade . . The best place to take a picture the all complex you should go to the other side of the Danube. I could get tickets a day in advance the hotel concierge arrange all it Once I received a ticket and waited in line . but all it was a mass.. no order to get in , no advices about time to wait .. a pity especially bad for people who have limited time in Budapest.
Wonderful carvings. I didn't get to go inside but just wandering around the outside is fun because of all the intricate carvings
The past and the present.... Beautiful building and a real life changing of the guards! :)
A site to see. Fantastic architecture, and the grave site memorial out front is a real eye opener
Beautiful building!. We toured the Parliament and thought it was magnificent!

Large and Beautiful. This is a large and beautiful parliament building with free tours for EU citizens and a reasonable admission rate for non-EU citizens. Tours are offered in various languages.The main problem I have with this place is the unclear ticketing system. I showed up waited on line for 40 minutes then was told that tickets are sold out and that I should order them online or by phone. It seems that an online ticketing system does not exist and it's impossible to get ahold of them by phone. I went back again and finally found out that I could get tickets a day in advance (I was told earlier that I could not). Once I received a ticket and waited in line again there was no announcement that we could be let in so a group of us waiting in line just made it in time after asking. This mess of a ticketing system needs to be sorted out especially since this is one of the highlights of the entire nation. This is especially bad for people who have limited time in Budapest.I recommend that travelers go a day early to reserve tickets preferably with their EU ID if possible then show up 15 minutes in advance to their scheduled tour the next day. If tickets in your language are sold out ask for another language. You'll still be able to see everything even if the tour guide is speaking a language that you don't understand. :P

Parliament Building - Impressive and Opulent. I had booked via email to visit the Parliament in the morning at 10:00 for the English language tour. I was early so I walked around and admired the first and second runner-up buildings for the Parliament building which are located opposite it and used for other purposes. The first runner-up still has large round bullets in it fired during the Uprising. I saw a gem of an Art Nouveau Building called Bedo-Haz with a curvy green facade - very neat.I enjoyed my guided tour to this opulent historic building. Information was well presented and the decor was marvelous. The grand staircase and lobby are so beautiful!I saw the Royal gem-encrusted crown and insignia under a stunning well-lit dome, surrounded by statues of Hungary’s great kings. I visited the House of Commons and saw a small contingent of guards enter, parade-style. There were some people in the room so I guess it was in session.I saw the Eternal Flame in front of the Parliament Building and took a picture standing in front of it. The Memorial of the Uprising of 1956 is in the Parliament grounds at Kossuth ter. The Flag at the Memorial has a hole in the center where protestors cut out the Communist Seal the Soviets had added to their Hungarian Flag.

where to get the best photo of the Parliament. The Parliament is a large complex. I didn't go inside, I just wandered around the outside. I believe that one of the photos I took of the Parliament will make my annual calendar next year. The best place to take a picture of it is on the other side of the Danube. Take the metro (from the Parliament area) under the river to the other side. You'll get some GREAT shots of the Parliament from there.

pity that the current political junta isn't up to democratic standard. It's a lot more impressive inside than the UK Parliament ( pity that the current political junta isn't quite up to the true democratic standards)and well worth the visit but you have to have read your Guide Book to find "DOOR X" The guide was extremely helpful & pleasant pity the same can't be said for the thuggish security guy who marshalls the visitors

Sumptuous building. An amazing place - particularly given the country's history. The visit only covers the entrance hall, grand staircase, crown jewels and the 'Upper Chamber' - no longer used other than for occasional conferences.BUT be aware that you can only visit as part of their guided tour and there are strict times for such tours, depending on your language choices SO CHECK TOURS IN ADVANCE!
Magnificent Monument. A magnificent monument in Budapest... At night is beauntiful with the lighting...!!!
Breathtaking.. The most wonderful looking building. Well worth a visit.

we really didn't see very much on the tour, but it was with Trafalgar. Not sure if this place offers different tours for different groups, but our tour with Trafalgar didn't show much of the inside. What we did see was nice though.

Worthwhile visit. We passed the parliament building at least twice using the No 1 and No 2 trams to get to other great sights (i.e. Chain Bridge Margaret Island) which is a great way to get some good photos. We did a hop off hop on at the parliament and then spent time walking around. It is a spectacular building provided the crowds are too large.
Amazing building. The best view of the building is from the river. You can book a cruise tour which will takou a good stretch of the river. Take in the view of the Parliament building!

Grandeur. Both exterior and interior are fantastic, luxurious.Take care of getting the visitor tour tickets in advance-earlier the same day as there ar queues and limitation in group numbers.The lady guide -English spoken tour-was very polite,and explanatory.A must of Budapest

Visit the Parliament!. The tour round the parliament was one of our favourite things. The inside is incredible and tour guides are very good. However, we recommend you get to the parliament early to book your tour - you cannot buy your ticket in advance and if you start queuing as late as 10am, you will be standing in the queue for a ticket for at least an hour! However, it really is worth the (very cold!) wait!
Beautiful building. Nice walk along the Danube and beautiful view on both Buda and Pest side. Parliament is on Pest side.

Beautiful building. For photographers going in the afternoon, it is better to approach from the south (Chain Bridge direction) as the sun sets relatively early in the afternoon (during winter), walking along the river will give you a nice angle and warm colours.
Magnificent architecture. This is a wonderfully built building on the Pest side of the Danube.
Take a peek inside. Take a guided tour and visit this monumental building! Fabulous!
Pretty. Didn't have enough time to visit inside but it is also beautiful at night!!

Just beautiful!. This Parliament is a beauty – I can look at it for ages. If you’re a EU citizen, definitely go for the tour as it’s free! I would have paid to go in if I got the extra-time. Remember to visit both day and night as it’s totally different feeling!

Get there at least 20 mins before the tours. Two queues for tickets one to get tickets and then join the other to go on the tour we arrived at 11:45 and couldn't get through the first queue in time to join the 12:00 tour and hence decided not to go in but very impressive from the outside.
So beautiful!. Don't know what to say about this place beside it was just a beautiful place! I could stay there all day and will not get bore with its beauty!

Fantastic Building. We q'ed for about 1hr and half in cold to collect tickets and then returned an hour later for the tour. The building and its contents were excellent but the tour was quite short, which didn't really make up for the length of timing Q'ing. Pity a new system cannot be introduced to try and cut down waiting times. Bonus was that with EU passport there was no entry fee, so I suppose you can't complain too much.

The tour was great. It is a hassle to get into a tour (go early to get sameday tickets) but once in you will be astonished by the history and the architecture of the building, the (for eu citizens) free tour was full of information told in a attractive manner
Somehow too military guidance.. Still can feel the authoritarian way of doing things, even tourism.
Architectural perfection. Loved the idea that you queue for tickets, to allow you come back at a certain time. Very informative, and well worth the wait.

Favourite building in Europe. "Awesome" is overused these days but thats what this building is. I photographed it from many vistas including a telephoto lens from the top of the Erzsebet look out tower on the top of Janos Hill. Looking forward to going back to Budapest and this building is one of the many reasons
A little bit of London. Closed over the New Year period - so no look insidey. Visually stunning from across the Danube!
Closed. Closed all during X Mas, but the outside looked typical of any other Government building in any large city.

Houses of Parliament - without Big Ben and in Hungarian.... Taken out of a fairy tale the Parliament is best viewed in all its splendor from the Buda side. But well worth visiting. Guided tours almost every day (except when the parliament is not assembled). Built around 1900 it's one of the biggest Parliament buildings in Europe. Appropriate then, when the Habsburg was on the throne in the Austian-Hungarian double monarchy. Today, for the small country of Hungary, it's simply too big with its over 600 rooms. Built without budget restraints (!) it has exquisite hand crafted halls, rooms, decorations and art.
The Parliament is a beautiful building.. The Parliament is a beautiful building. Take the tour.
beautiful building. beautiful building on the river danube, great pictures.

Not just another big building. The craftsmanship and character sets this apartment from other “monument” style buildings, and also provides insight into Hungarian nationality. This is also where the crown and crown jewels can be seen. Absolutely fascinating.
Architectural motherload. this is the motherload of architecture. Best way to see it is from across the river at the Fisherman's Bastian.
breathtaking. very nice at night... loved seeing it from danube...

Back to history. It is such a beatiful building! You must go and it is free if you are a EU citizen. A guide will drive you through it explaining to you the history of the country. You can see only 3 rooms but it is absolutely worth to do!
Grandiose Building. Very impressive building but you have to find a place where from is the good view on it from right bank of Danube.

One of the most magnificent buildings in the world!. It may seem irrational, but I simply love the look of Hungary's Parliament building. I didn't have an opportunity to take a tour of the interior and see St. Stephan's crown and such, but the exterior design of the building is enough to make me fall in love with it. I'm far from an expert in architecture, but I can't help but be mesmorized by the Orszaghaz. When evening arrives and the building is illuminated, one can witness it in all of its glory. I highly recommend viewing the building from the Buda Hill or a river boat, if possible, at dusk for the best lighting effects. If you love architectural masterpieces or photographing unique structures, then the Orszaghaz must be on your list of places to visit!

Beautiful.. EU passport holders get in free so take your passport. We asked our hotel in advance (Bohem Art Hotel) to book us onto the 12pm tour in English so we bypassed the huge queues and went straight to Gate X (10) and showed our piece of paper from the hotel and collected our tickets.We still had to queue to do that. We then went to Gate 12 (XII) to join our tour. The people in the queues must have been left waiting for hours. Inside you get to see St. Stephen's crown guarded by 4 guards as well as several rooms and staircases, gilded and ornately decorated and the Chamber of the Parliament. I would not bother queueing for hours to see the interior when you can see the beautiful view of the exterior from the Fisherman's Bastion over on the Buda side of the city.

go early. We waited till our last day in Budapest to visit the Parliament building. Got there at 12 o'clock and there were no tickets left! Make sure you get there early if you want to visit the building ( which is beautiful from the outside) and be prepared to line up.

See beautiful architecture and Hungarian Crown Jewels in one tour. Remarkably large and opulent parliament building for a country of 10 million population. The building borders the river Danube and we visited the nearby Shoes on the Danube memorial afterwards.We booked the tour through the hotel and had no problems.
Gem of the Danube. Amazing historical sight, it is well worth to go inside.

Imposing structure.... i stayed at a hotel close to this so crossed it every day....very neat piece of history and the view from the buda side is terrifice... i also saw the vienna parliamanet and they both are great.. wish other countries also maintained their parliaments..
Super N°1. Don't mis this but be aware to buy the entrance tickets at least ONE day in advance in the office of the Parliament or in a Travel agency in the city.
A lovely experience. The inside of this building was incredible. It glittered like the interior of a palace. Very impressive. The guide was excellent.

Well worth a visit. On a weeks vacation in Budapest we visited the Parliament Building. It is a very impressive structure designed to mirror the House of Commons in London. We took a guided tour with an english speaking guide who made the visit very interesting. Unknown to us the tour was free to E U passport holders but as we had left ours in the hotel we had to pay. The tours seemed to run regular with very little delay. The area sorrounding the Parliament has lovely gardens and monuments.

Confusing entry.. Lots of advice on getting in...best way is to get there early..at 8 am the day of your visit and pick up tickets in person at door X.otherwise it's chaotic with confused people queueing and disappointed. Emails don't get answered! but do visit..a neoo gothic marvel!
One of the best. I think this is the most beautiful parliament of the world, absolutely worth a visit and the price!
Beautiful building. Terrific architechture, when viewed from Buda side

Beautiful. The Hungarian Parliament in Budapest is one of the most beautiful buildings I have seen, aparently they based it on the Houses of Parliament, unfortunately I didn't get to go inside which is free to members of the European state.

A must see. Guided short 1 hour tours offered most days. Do not miss venue near the Chain Bridge/Danube. The second largest parliament in europe after London. Spectacular rooms with many details reflecting its history.

Beautiful Interior and spectacular at Night. The day of our visit, they have some foreign visitors and had to go in at 8 am or else miss the inside tour.We were very glad we did. It saw the original Gold Crown encased in a glass case. The meeting rooms had wooden chairs made from very hard local wood. The inside were heated thru vents under the chairs. Amazing considering that this was designed in the 1900s.At night the lights shone brightly from across the Buda hills. Very nice.
parli. this is once of the government building its old but centre of attraction

parliament building. The forlorn bronze monument to Imre Nagy. An unexpected surprise, took a while to suss out who the guy on the bridge was and why he was staring sideways across to the parliament square. It was quite touching, not great art, but it came from the heart. Living history still.
Informative and impressive. Do this only if you have at least 2 hours to spare.

One of the most important buildings of Hungary. I do not care whether it has 1500 rooms, yes it is architecturally niceish, seems oversized, but what I care is people working inside it are doing their utmost to raise the Hungarian nation, Hungary, to the levels it deserves. I pray the country soon strenghtens economically. If not interested much in hungarian history not worth taking trouble and visiting inside. The parliament building at Vienna is the number one in whole world, even universe !

Outstanding Building. Loved the tour of the Parliament. The guide was very professional and the building was just magnificent. We emailed them requesting an English tour about 10 days ahead of our visit and about 2 days later received an email which allowed us to proceed to buy the tickets and join the tour without any hassles or lines. Take cash for the tour just in case their credit card machine is broken (as it was the case we went)
Very impressive. Very impressive, massive, gothic building. Protected by a little privot hedge! Weddings sometimes held there. Close to tram stops. Well wortha look at.
Parliament. Lovely building only past it on a tram and boat,should of gone on a tour really.

Beautiful building. It is a very impressive building with it's gothic features, we saw it during the day in front and also went over the Chain bridge for a view at night which we preferred, was stunning. Shame we didn't have time to do a tour inside, looks impressive too!
The most beautiful parliament I saw. This is the emblem of budapest. The parliament is so nice, its good to see it from both side of the danube. Amazing place to take pictures.
The most beautiful Parliament in the world. Impressive to see the change of the guards of the royal crown. Fantastic paintings in the main hall

lovely building,bad ticket distribution method. We've heard much worse stories about the lines, here so we were lucky, but the temperatures were close to freezing. We waited about 45 minutes in a line where an armed guard sent in 2 or 3 people at a time across the courtyard into a ticketbooth to purchase the tickets. However, people kept coming to the front of the line and being waved through by the guard. I assume they were private tour guides as they seemed to have groups with them. It was annoying to be waiting in the cold and then have people waltz up go straight in. After purchasing our tickets waited 2 hours for our tour time. The tickets were expensive since we are not EU citizens -- they're free for citizens. The tour guide was very good and the building is very impressive.
Good Photo Ops. I took some great pictures of this building from outside and across the river. The best time is around sundown when the lights are sparkling from the river.
Impressive building. The most impressive building of Budapest. I think that it worths to admire it evening hours from a small distance, like through a trip on a river boat.
Fascinating. What a wonderful building. Well worth a paid tour.

Beautiful but the Tour Seemed Short. We decided to tour the inside and we were really glad we did. It was gorgeous! The only thing is that for the price of the ticket, the tour was fairly short. They show you about 3 rooms in 45 minutes. We would have liked to see more or paid less.

Beautifully Illuminated at Night. Did not tour the inside but the outside is a great photo opportunity and we crossed the Chain Bridge at Dusk to the Buda side to get good pictures of the Parliment Building illuminated at Night. Stunning!

Impressive !. Amazing buildings (from the outside) Beautiful ! Grand.
Unfortunately the weather was a bit misty, so we didn't see it at it's best, but was still good.
Impressive. Beautfull building, full of history, worth a visit.

It was interesting to see the Crown Jewels. We got a tour with Eurama, which avoided the hassle of trying to get a ticket. The building inside is pretty. We saw the changing of the guards at the crown jewel, which was neat. I recommend going inside for a tour.
Great architecture. Another great example of beautiful architecture matched with grandness of the building
stunning. well i grew up next to danube (Belgrade) so seeing it in Budapest as well made it better

Beautiful building. We toured this opulent Parliament. All the gold makes this building majestic. The Hungarian Crown was kept safe in Fort Knox and now is displayed under the main dome. The Upper House has beautiful woodwork and paintings. The cigar holders take you back to an older day.
amazing!. One of the most amazing architecture I've seen! Simply extraordinary! A must for visiting Budapest
Beautiful!. The building itself is beautiful. As all the other sights in Budapest, the Parliment building has been maintained in a pristine manner. The view from afar at night is majestic.

Beautiful and impressive. Get there early when willing to visit the inside. We were unfortunate to show up on an afternoon when all tickets had been booked out. Saw some pictures though and looks stunning
Big Parliament near Blue Duna. As far as I know, it's biggest political building in Europe. Looks magnificent, but my opinion - it needs more lights in the night to have dramatic look.

Beautiful and ugly. The parliament itself is really beautiful (from the outside). We didn't see it from the inside, however. Our guided tour was set to be an hour later than we had expected and we didn't go at last, because we were digusted by rude guards and secret police member who really don't know how to treat people with dignity...

Must see. You need to go on a tour to see this magnificent building.
Touch of history, still center of politics.

Short tour, but very interesting.. The tour of the parliament building in Budapest was rather short in comparison to some of the other government buildings I visited in Europe. However, the inside of the building was magnificent, with some amazing architecture. Getting a ticket for the tour can be slightly difficult, though. There is a set number of tours in several languages each day, and the tickets are sold the morning of the tour. Tickets sell out rather quickly, and the line sometimes assembles pretty early in the morning. So if you are set doing a tour, it's important to plan ahead. Overall, I wouldn't put the parliament on the top of your list of things to do in Budapest, but it is something worth seeing if you have the time.

Most beautiful Parliament in Europe. It is not a one-sided building. You can see it from all sides and you will find , that the Parliament has the same beauty from all sides. Unfortunatly we did not have time to check it inside.

Disappointing, but still.... The Parliament building is very prominent in Budapest, and seeing some of the inside was useful to round out our sense of the city. The tour was quite expensive, however, and very short, as well as fairly short on details about the workings of the government.

Go for the building, not the tour. This is a stunning building and worth seeing, both inside and out. To say it is magnificent does not begin to do it justice. Sadly, the tour (about $16) is not good' the guide's English was poor, it was hard to hear in the cavernous spaces, and it was just about 30 minutes long. although she said she was available for questions at the end of the tour, we asked one question (about the unicameral legislature) and then she quickly ushered us all out of the building. Too bad - it could have been a 5 star but for the tour.
We took a tour. Saw the crown jewels amongst other things. Plenty of English tours, but need to check first. This was a three years ago.
Amazing structure. We went there around sundown. So got to see it without and with the lights on. Looks colossal when you stand right in front of it. Did not go inside though.

Beautiful architecture. I had a pleasure to see this incredible architecture by the day and night. It is really amazing. It looks nice from the close and far away. It is one of the attractions you have to see being in Budapest. You can go on the castle hill and then take nice pictures or maybe plan a walk by Danube Promenade also looking at the memorial ''shoes on Danube Promenade''.
extremely beautiful. we liked the parliament very much. when we were on our danube tour , to watch the alighted parliament excited us .

Absolutely breathtaking. It's a beautiful building both inside and outside. We took the English tour, and it was interesting, although the lady who gave us the tour had a bad English and she was way beside the historical facts. Anyway the entrance is free of charge for EU and Swiss citizens and the is a fee of approximately 12 euros for non- EU citizens.But it is worth it.
Beautiful Building. It was very pretty to view from the outside. We were not able to secure a tour, so it was a very quick stop.

Interesting place. You have to stand in line in order to get yout tickets. There are frequent visits in English and some in other languages. I recommend to go there early, especially if you want to get tickets in a language different than English. When we got there all Spanish tickets had been sold out. It is completely free for European Union citizens. I don't know the price for other citizenships.All tours are guided and you are shown several rooms and the Hungarian crown. You'll also be told a bit about Hungarian History.
Fantastic building. Didn't get to go in, but another fantastic piece of architecture.

Budapest Parliament Building. This is an incredibly beautiful building and a great tour. It is only 45 minutes but is packed full of information. However, it is difficult to get tickets. The concierge at our hotel got the tickets. Otherwise, the lines were very long.
Tour. Inside the parliament was breathtaking, the information given by the tourgide was very clear and concise. It was very valuable experience.
What a perfect place!. Do not miss the Parliament at night, it's one of the most beautiful and inspiring sights you'll ever see.
Impressive. The parliament building(s) look stunning by day and even better at night when they are beautifully illuminated. I wish I'd had time to have gone on the guided tour.

worth a visit. We were unfortunately not able to get tickets for a tour around the building, but we could admire the outside. it is a beautiful building, reminiscent of our own Houses of Parliament. We saw it in daylight and at night - a stunning sight at night, from either Buda or the river trip down the river, as it is lit up to enhance its beauty.
The Long Stand. Queued for what seemed like most of our stay, but well worth it. Building is superb.
the royal charm. the tour is excelent. also in hebrew. beautifull building and desighn

What a beautiful place!!. We ordered a tour to the Parliament building and would highly recommend it!The tour take less than an hour, and reveals a very interesting and beautiful building, well worth visiting.It is very important to order the tour in advance, in your preferred language ( there are many!). Otherwise - it is most likely you will have to stand in line for a long time, and not get a tour for that day because there are so many visitors.If you are a EU citizen, do not forget to bring your passport so you can get in for free. We saw many people who did not know that and were disappointed that they had to pay. Also - come about a half an hour before your scheduled time because you have to wait until the guard allows you to get to the ticket office to buy your tickets ( even though ordered in advance ). The whole process is not too efficient and you must be alert to make sure you have enough time to pay for the tickets.

Get tickets early. The beauty of the building is not to be missed. WE viewed it during the day as we walked around it and at night from a river cruise on the Danube. While we wanted to see the inside, the lines, even in Mid October, were long and the system of admission seemed chaotic and cumbersome. But it's worth walking down to it or seeing it from the river. It's an iconic Budapest building and absolutely gorgeous.
Worth waiting for. Great tour if you can get a ticket. Bring some ID ( passport, driver's license). Free for EU citizens!

Amazing Building. We only viewed from outside as the queue's were so big and we had so many places to visit. But even if you don't get to see the building from the inside it is worth a look during the day and make sure you return at night. The Hungarian flag with the centre piece cut out makes you realise how different the lives of some of our European neighbours were in the not so distant past.
wonderfull. It's a palace really!! Piece of art actually not a building
most beautiful Parliament in Europe. This is the most beautiful Parliament in Europe. Full of golden decoration inside.

Parliament. Unfortunately we couldn't get on the tour. A fabulous site, but try and book onto a tour as soon as you arrive in Budapest. Tourist Office says to book through hotel reception, but they say to go to the booking office yourself and line up. Probably worth doing a tour in any language if your own is not available just to get inside. Don't forget to take passport.

Worth the Wait. Because the Parliament can only be toured in groups, you need to check when your language tour is offered. When we went, English was offered at 10/12/2. But: there are capacity limits to the tours and so you may need to wait for the next available group. It is an interesting bldg. and you get to see the crown surrounded by guards and the old-time window ledge cigar holders. Should take approx. one hour and the interior is very photogenic. Airport-like security before you enter so be prepared, plus if the Parliament is in session additional limitations probably will apply so check in advance. Also, if you have to wait for the next tour, there is not much to do/see/eat in the immediate area. You might get a bite at Szalai Cukraszda patisserie just north of the bldg. complex and then wait in the square near the 1956 memorial to the uprising and people watch.
Stunning by day, better by night. Stunning building but even better at night when lit up.

Interesting and impressive. Did not enjoy the process to obtain tickets. Had to be at Parliament at 8 am to queque, for then to be told there were no tours in English on that day. As we were going to leave somebody mentioned that there would be a tour in English after all - queue again - and we got the tickets. But Parliament was impressive and the guide knowledgeable - definitely worth a visit, and possibly even the hassle to get in.

Bueatiful Building. This is a beautiful building. The story goes that they spent enough on this building to have build homes for 70,000 people. It is a must see! There is a tour of the interior but I missed it because the building was closed for an official visit. A Tip: Try to view this building at night either from a river cruise or from the Buda side of the river. Unbelievable sight!

Beautiful building - the tour too short. A friend and I visited the Parliament building on our trip to Budapest. The building itself is gorgeous and looks absolutely splendid when lit up at night.We tried to go for a tour in the afternoon and they were completely sold out of all the English tours, so we had to purchase the Spanish one and then my friend who understands Spanish translated for me instead. The tour itself was very short, I am still not convinced it was worth the money, it was barely 20 minutes. The building inside though is still gorgeous.Tip: You can get stunning pictures of the Parliament building if you take one of the Danube night tours on the sailing boats, it looks fantastic when all lit up at night and is worth capturing.
Get your tickets FAST !!!!. wonderful architecture. The interior was amazing for a government building and the crown jewels were not to be missed...loved the cigar holder outside of the chamber

DEFINITELY WORTH THE TROUBLE. The interior is so decorative and beautiful. I would never in my wildest dream image that in a parliament. The Bohemia crown is also stored there for viewing. I would go visit again . Even though it involved lining up at 8:30 am for tickets and the tour is only for 45minutes.Also, the guide is very friendly and organized.

Beautiful building. Disliked that it was a bit complicated to get tickets, but liked that it was free of charge if you're a EU citizen.You're only allowed inside with a guide and only for a few occations per day until "the tickets are finished".The building is very beautiful inside and well worth seeing.

Magnificent building, good guide, free for EU citizens. One of the must-sees of any visit to Budapest: a magnifiecnt interior. English-speaking tours run three times a day, are 50 minutes long, and are free for EU citizens. You need to book your ticket in advance by going down to the Parliament building and wait in the ticket booking queue. Have ID with you. You're then directed to door X where you book. We got to the queue at 9am, and got on to the 12 midday tour that day (the 10am tour was already sold out).

Most Amazing Building.. I went to Budapest in July, and I was so excited to see the iconic Parliament Building. It exceeded my expectations. It was so beautiful, right on the Danube river. It is a picture perfect spot. And a must see attraction while you are there. You can see it in many different locations, and each way you look it is breath taking. Also, before you visit Hungary, try to learn some Hungarian. The language is extremely hard to understand so learning some would be helpful.

Get there early. EU citizens can visit the Parliament free of charge. ID is required and a passport is the best form of ID. The tours are operated at 10am, 12 noon and 2pm daily. However, tickets go very very fast.If you wish to take a tour, especially if you can do so free, then you need to being in the queue at 8am or earlier. Despite being told (by an official) that getting into the queue at around 9-9.30am would be early enough, it clearly wasn't. By the time we got there at around 9.15am, all tickets were gone.So moral of the story - set your alarm early.
Beautiful building but all tickets were sold. A beautiful building from all directions, however if you want to get inside and see it book tickets in advance

get your tickets in advance. We tried to go twice, but both times told that the tickets were gone for the day, to come back the next day. Finally just ordered tickets through City Rama, cost an extra $9 per ticket but we got in without waiting in line. Beautiful building worth seeing

Impressive but plan ahead. This is one of the most famous and impressive buildings in Budapest. Many people consider it a "must see" and I would highly recommend it. However, the tours are only about 45 minutes and are relatively expensive compared to the rest of Budapest. We assumed that we could just walk in. However, we had to stand in line for about an hour to find out that all the English tours for that day were sold out and you couldn't buy a tour for the next day. We ended up going on an Italian tour and even that involved leaving and coming back about four hours later. I would recommend doing this as part of commercial day tour. They will already have the tickets and work your tour of the building into the tour's itinerary. You probably also save some money going with a tour company, these tours are by bus and normally have 20 or 30 tourists. You will see the rest of city in addition to the Parliament building.

Really not worth the queues, or the bother. Honest.. If you REALLY want to go here, be at the building (in the queue) to get your tickets from 8am onwards. If you are have an EU passport you get in free, thankfully we didn't have to pay or i really would have been annoyed.So you get your ticket and depending on what language you want your guided tour to be in, you come back again at that time. Tickets are usually gone by 2pm if not before.Our tour guide spoke very good English, but i wanted to hear more history, about the architecture of the building etc. As for the 'crown jewels' have a look at the photo and prepare to be under whelmed.The tour takes about 45 minutes but inevitably you'll be held up at the start by other savvy tourists who can't understand the security process (exactly same as airport) and decide to bring penknives into the building! View the building from the outside, if you have time to kill, then join the queue and wait.

view it day and also nite, from front and back. here is a landmark that tourist should not missed. better view is from the castle hill across the river at sunset and nite. Daytime can enjoy the front entrance view and if visit early morning, can get "inside tour" ticket from the small gate near entrance. I didnt have the opportunity to do that.

Beautiful building. The Parliament building is stunning both by day and by night.We took a late night sail down the Danube and the Parliament shone like a jewel on the banks.We didn't go in but the outside is a feast for the eyes.
Historically important well worth the price of admission have a guide. From the number of stairs to the cigar holders everything has meaning u would do well to hire ur own guide
Stunning. We gained a whole new respect for Budapest in seeing their gorgeous House of Parliament. The line up was somewhat long but the entertaining and informative tour made it all worthwhile.

Wonderful. The Parliament is the most beautiful building in all Budapest. It is a «must» to watch it at night from the river.As to the entrance, i am not shure it is worth it, since it is only a small visit of 40 minutes.

Well worth a Visit. Daily tours take approx 50 minEuropean citizens are admitted free on production of passportYou are required to Q for tickets and guard will advise you when to enter door marked with X There you will get your ticket you are then required to join another Q for those with tickets.You are required to go through security check similar to airportThis is a beautifull building the largest in Budapest. You will only visit a very small part of it but it is worth the wait if you have timeIf time is limited I would advise giving it a miss
Very Impressive. Stunning interior, guide excellent. Great view of Parliament from a boat.

Parliament building. I got to the parliament building at 08:00am on the morning to get my ticket for later the same day.. the queue was not long, and people were already getting tickets when I got there. I waited about 10-15 minutes before I got my ticket... it was free for me as I am English..The tour (about 30 people on it) was actually quite short, but well worth it. The building itself was based on Englands Houses of Parliament, and is one of the top four biggest parliament buildings in the world. After the security checks, we were led up the red carpetted staircase, and in to the room with the monarchs crown in it, protected by two guards. We then entered the Old house of lords... there are two identical House of Lords rooms, the one we saw was the one which is not used. The guide described the setup of the house, and where everyone sat, and how many of each party there were. Luckily I have visited the House of Comons at the Houses of Parliament in London when they were in session, so I knew how it worked. I found the tour very interesting, and well worth getting up early for. The guide answered any questions we had, and then led us out through the exit... it was a very short tour... but it gives you a small understanding of how parliament works. The building from the outside looks wonderful... both from the Buda side of the water, and from the Pest side.
exceptional. the only place that had a lineup to enter; but worth every second

Free if you're in EU. Great experience. Advice - go at 8.30 and go to window X. There will be no queue! Get you're free ticket if you are in the EU then stroll about and come back at 10 for the English tour. Well worth it. The inside is beautiful and the tour-guide was great. A must see!

Amazing building - very short visit. I won't discuss about the building itself which worth five stars but about the guided visit in summer.First you should know that if you want to wait less than 2 hours go early, around 8:30 am.You will get a ticket asking you to come back during the afternoon.Second, don't expect much from the visit.Indeed it lasted only 20-25 minutes. You don't learn much and you visit a tiny (but beautifull) part of the building. You climb beautifull stairs, arrive in a hall and finish with the room where they vote.Maybe if we had know the duration we wouldn't have been deceived.That's why i wrote this review.

impressive. The parliament building is impressive from the inside and the guided tour is effective. There is a catch though , and it is the waiting in line outside , in the sun to buy tickets. So, Either buy tickets through the hotel , if possible , or come early morning. We found that at 9:00 am ( or even earlier , the office opens at 8:00 am) there is no waiting but half an hour later the line for the tickets builds up very fast. The tours are at at fixed times. You can walk arround and come back right on time for the next tour.
Visit at Night!. We did not take the tour but it is worth walking around and visiting this landmark!

Ignore the sign for ticket buyers. We went on a tour of the Parliament building last week, and as others have said, it is a very picturesque building both inside and out. Yes, the tour is expensive, the presentation is dry and full of meaningless facts that you will immediately forget, but the architecture, floor to ceiling marble and gilding aren't something that you will soon forget. Also, the royal crown is on display in the dome room. You can take pictures of it, but without flash.I just wanted to warn future visitors about the misleading signs outside the building. The sign for ticket buyers looks like it was supposed to have a panel that could be flipped up and down to indicate when tickets were sold out for the day. That panel is missing, and so it says something like "There are no more tickets available for today", or words to that effect. Upon seeing that on a Wednesday afternoon, we turned around disappointed. We came back the following day at 8:00am when the ticket office opened, and saw the same sign. We knew that there was no way they could have been sold out so early, so we just waited in line and got our tickets. The moral of the story: Even if you arrive in the afternoon and see the sign, don't give up. Just ask the guard if tickets are still on sale.

one of the emblems of the city. You must see the Parliament because is one of the emblems of Budapest. The arhitecture is impressive, the building is big (second largest parliament building in Europe, after the one in Bucharest). There is a posibility to see it on the inside also, but the hours of visiting are strict and couldn't take the tour.

Nice tour, but expensive. Arrived about 9:30 am and was able to secure tickets for a tour at 12:45. When we arrived for our tour, all tickets were sold out for the day, so go early if you want a tour ticket. The tour was nice, albeit a bit short for the ticket price. Children are discounted, but still charged - I was wearing my baby in sling and they even charged about $10 for him!

Well worth a visit - plan ahead. A wonderful visit with real wow factor. take advantage of free admission by going early morning to door X. Ask the guard for permission to go to the door by showing your UK passport then show it again inside the door at the desk. The lady will issue you with a timed ticket for a tour for free. Then return to same palce at allotted time for a thoroughly enjoyable tour.

Beautiful building, but the only way inside is a lame tour. We are so glad we saw the inside of this building, but the only way in is to attend a tour which seemed awfully expensive for what you get (for non-EU residents; it's free for EU residents). The tour really only shows you two rooms inside, and you'll need to be able to walk up about 80 stairs to do the tour. If the tour had been free, we wouldn't have been so disappointed, but for the price we were expecting much more. It says it is a 50-minute tour, but you spend about 20 minutes getting your group through security, and another 10 at the end of the tour for "any questions".

Gorgeous exterior, but interior tour is a ripoff & waste of precious time. The exterior is beautiful, striking, impressive and as it turns out *very* photogenic, so make sure to get lots of pictures of you and yours outside. HOWEVER. Don't bother with the tour. It is terribly overpriced (US$16), for a very rushed, unfriendly 30 minute tour which is falsely advertised as 50 minutes. They hustle you from room to room as if everyone were on fire and you are constantly scolded and yelled at.
