I for one am a grown adult and don't like being treated like a misbehaving child, especially when I've so overpaid for the attraction. The only noteworthy thing in my opinion was the entry staircase -- grand and operatic. The rest was forgettable. It's also a pain in the butt - it sells out quickly so you are likely to have to get tickets and then come back a while later. Also, if you care about such things, they're very strict and mean, inside and out, from the ticket booth on- you're treated like a criminal asking for a huge favor.

Beautiful exterior, did not plan well enough to get to see the inside!. Their parliament is beautiful! But when we showed up around 1pm, all the tickets for the day had already been sold :( I recommend going first thing to get your tickets (and it's free for EU members.)

The wonder on the side of the Danube. The Parliament is one of Europe's oldest legislative buildings. The Gothic Revival style building is perhaps the best known and most visited landmarks in Budapest and perhaps on the Danube bank. A really magnificent building that must be seen from all aspects, including a view from the opposite side of the Danube, from the castle hill. If having the option, take a guided tour inside as the Parliament building is just as impressive from the inside as from the outside. Make sure to not miss this attraction whenever staying in Budapest.

This is a MUST!. We could not get any tickets by 11 a.m. So we went back to our hotel and booked a tour. Easy thing to do, no stress. Of course more expensive but it was a good investment. The tour was interesting and the inside of the Parliament is most beautiful and pretty exceptional. Even our kids (age 5 and 9) were fascinated and did not get bored during the tour.

Must See..go go.. I have spend considerable amount of time in Budapest and was recently asked if it was only one thing I had to see in budapest what would it be. It would be the Hungarian Parliament was the answer. Its fantastic and if you really lucky like we was you may even get to see the prime minster Victor , which added to the occasion.

Fascinating - but if from EU don't go with tour company. Got massively ripped off yesterday going on the tour of Parliament in Budapest. I know that if you are an EU citizen you can get tickets, but the receptionist at the hotel told me I might not get in cos of the elections. So I coughed up 4000 florints to go on an official tour with one of the local agencies. What a total rip off. It lasted 90 minutes, with over 45 stood outside freezing in the cold as she narrated facts that would have been in the guidebooks. And i read the guidebooks.The inside of the Parliament building is beautiful, and well worth a look around. But pop along to the ticket office and go off your own steam.

A masterpiece everyone has to see. The parliament of Hungary is one of the nicest in the world and thus well worth a visit (not just a snapshot from outside). Guided tours are offered in many languages (free for EU-citizens), but the tickets are limited, so make sure you book a place in advance in the high season (I emailed them my request a week ahead our visit and received the confirmation in 30 minutes). Our guide was very well-informed, besides the facts shared some interesting stories. The tour, which takes about 50 minutes, is a MUST when visiting this city.

Gorgeous building inside and out. I'm not sure why this isn't in the top 3. Once I saw the exterior, I wanted to see the interior. I took the tour, as it wasn't worth the chance of not being able to get in. Getting in without a tour seems to be difficult at best. The process seems a bit shady but it's worth teh tour.Like the Hungary State Opera, this building could be cleaned. It looks like they began cleaning it, and then decided to stop. It would be more magnificent clean.

Gorgeous building, diabolical tour. To begin with get there early, queues can be long and it isn't a case of nipping in and grabbing a ticket...you are let through in two's by an armed guard to get your tickets. So get there early, and don't forget your passport as if you are in an EU country you get in for free!The tour is quite lacklustre, our tour guide was almost silent and as you either follow or are followed by a tour in Hungarian it makes it very difficult to hear. You are taken to the grand staircase, the crown jewels and the main chamber then it's cut rather abruptly short. You see a tiny fraction of the complex, all in all you spend more time queuing to get in and getting through security then actually seeing the building which is tremendously opulent.There are better places to see in Budapest.

Arrive Early for Tours of the Parliament Building. Tours in English at 10 am, noon, 1 pm and 2 pm, but they were sold out for the day when we arrived at 11.00 am. Don't think you can book in advance, so best to arrive early.

Don't forget your passport !. On a recent visit to Budapest my family & i queued for approx 20 mins in the heat outside the Parliament building then discovered when reaching the ticket office that holders of EU passports could visit the place for free. Since we weren't carrying ours with us we had to return to the hotel & then queue up again.However when we did join a tour it was worth it as it is a very opulent building.

Beautiful Architecture. Probably the most famous structure in all of Hungary, this beautiful structure sits on the Danube in downtown Budapest. I took a couple great pictures from a boat tour of this building and also got a couple great "across the danube" pictures from the Fishermans Bastion. When i went here as a child in 1986, i remember Parliament wasn't in session and I even got to go up to the lecturn to act like I was speaking. The outside spires are gorgeous and this is not a place to be missed on your trip to Hungary. Structures like this are why people refer to Budapest as the Paris of eastern europe.

Go With Tour.. Beautiful building out and in. Go with an organized tour (eg part of city tour). It is very difficult on your on. You have to wait in line to get to buy a ticket. Posted times you can go change. Dont rely on tour book or their sign. Ticket agent was rude. And then had to wait 3 hours b4 next tour. Guide did not speak great English.

Need to get there early and queue for a ticket. I arrived at the Parliament building at 9:30am and queued for about 30 minutes before being able to get my ticket for the 2pm tour. The tour is free for EU citizens (if you show your passport).On the guided tour, the tour guide explained that the building is modelled on Westminster. The tour lasted about 45 minutes and the guide explained everything quite well but we only saw a small part of the parliament complex so I was a bit disappointed.

Worth seeing..but only if you book in advance!. Stunning building on the Danube! Definately worth seeing, but beware of the incredibly long lines into the place. And the line does NOT move fast at all as they only allow a certain amount of people into the building at the time. I strongly urge you to book an appointment in advance for a tour! You can skip the entire line and show your reservation to the guard. The tour is only about 30-40 minutes long and you will learn a lot in a short amount of time about the history of the building. The Parliament is really strikingly beautiful so don't miss this during your trip....but make sure you book in advance!

Stunning architecture. It was a non trivial exercise to get into the Parliament such is the interest from tourists and locals to view this magnificent building.There are hordes of tourists around the entrance so if you want to get in be there early, otherwise you will not get in.The guide explained everything in detail and we enjoyed our tour.The only downside is the real exercise involved to actually get in.For one the tickets are expensive but worth every penny.However, I am more concerned about the lack of organization to let visitors to see the building, in an intelligent and organized manner.Definitely one of the top attractions in Budapest, but you must listen to the guide to understand the history of the building and the country.

Worth seeing. We have just been to Budapest for a few days and one of the sights we wanted to see was Parliament.First I will give you an idea of the process to get into the building:you can only approach one gate, gate 10 (X in Roman numerals), where the ticket office is. The rest of the building (even the outside) is off limits and guarded.Ensure you go early in the morning (they are open from 8am) to get your tickets for English-speaking tours that day. As you can imagine the English-speaking tour is the most popular tour so they tend to run out of tickets very quickly. Also availability of tours is based on whether parliament is in session. They can cancel tours at the last minute.There are 3 English-speaking tours a day: at 10am, 12 noon and 2pm. You can only get tickets for THAT DAY so if you are not successful one day, you have to come back the next day. They don't allow you to reserve tickets for tours in advance. The tour itself is about 40 minutes. Once inside you get to see the entrance hall (used for special guests like royalty and heads of state) and you're led up the stairs. There are 8 solid granite columns along this flight of stairs which were a gift from the government of Sweden. You'll notice there is a lot of gold decoration and pomp, and one of the main claims to fame is that the building is the 3rd largest in the world (after Romania and Argentina). The royal crown which is centuries old is stored in the centre of the building. You can see it and take photos but not with flash. Then you get to see the chambers of the House of Lords which is no longer in use, but is identical to the House of Commons so shows you what the chambers look like. You'll get a few minutes to take photos here. An amusing observation: in the corridors outside the chamber there are gold-plated sigar holders with numbers on them; this is where (when they were still allowed to smoke), parliament members used to leave their cigars to go into meetings, and be able to identify which one was theirs when they came out!All in all a sight worth seeing, if only to say you've been there!

My favourite building in budapest. This gorgeous Parliament building in Budapest is among the 3 largest ones built during the Austro/Hungarian Monachy. Beautiful interior, national crown and many hidden jewels that I explored with Cityrama Budapest on a Parliament tour. Great fun!!!!
